story:
Our Story

Hi, My name is Gretchen McLaren and I am a jeweler, blacksmith and yoga teacher from Raleigh, NC. The plight of women and young girls in India is a story that deeply resonates with me.


Currently I am residing in Bangalore, India for 6 months, volunteering with a group of safe hostels for young girls, schools, technical training centers and orphanages in South India, run by the Salesian sisters. The Salesian sisters mission is to help the poor children, to educate, provide job training and food and safe housing for the many many poor and at risk young girls.


I have set up the first, of what I hope will be many jewelry studios at one of the technical training schools (my second site in India so far), teaching the hostel girls how to make jewelry. In 30 days they have learned to make jewelry with a minimum of tools and a scarcity of resources. Together, we have designed a line of jewelry, and produced samples. In the next month the girls hope to produce the samples in silver, and fill their first orders and sales here in India, produce stock for their very first jewelry show and get feedback on the designs to be produced for the Western market. Then, they will produce the finished product line and I will bring this stock back to the US to market, distribute and sell for them. All the money from the sale of the line will go directly back to these girls less material costs, and money for desperately needed tools.


These girls are extremely talented, hard working, and all of their hopes are pinned on this project being a success. They view this as a livelihood, as a way to provide for themselves, for their families, for their futures.

My intention is to be of service to these girls and to create a sustainable, green business for them. So far, we have been able to recycle the scrap copper wire from the on site power convertor shop. This scrap copper wire has a very small return and is extremely expensive to buy. By turning the scrap wire into a product for sale, not only are they recycling, but they are creating a huge return on their investment in material cost.


Right now, we are set up on a porch, the girls sit on mats on the floor, we are still operating out of the suitcase I brought, with a minimum of tools. I am making tools out of anything on hand, like stainless steel wire hangers.

We are desperate for a torch and soldering equipment, more hand tools and money to buy silver sheet and wire to produce the line. We have foreign ladies waiting to buy the jewelry, so the girls will earn money immediately. Needless to say, they are very excited about this, and I want them to have this positive feedback for their hard work.


I am launching a campaign to cover phase two of this project. This will cover material and tool cost for phase two and hopefully a small amount of living expenses for me.


My work is completely volunteer based. This $2,000 that I am asking is for materials and tools to produce the line and a small amount of living expenses to support me while I am working on this project for 6 months. It is my hope that this campaign will exceed my wildest expectations and that I will also be able to upfit their broken language lab and buy additional tools and materials for the studio, and new working computers for the school and community.


All the money for the initial campaign was spent on the tools I brought with me to India, and the remainder was spent on supplies and additional tools for the girls, once I landed in India. To make room for all the tools, I brought almost no personal supplies with me. I am still operating with 3 sets of clothing, and no personal living supplies, so any extra donations so that I can cover living expenses in India is greatly appreciated.


We have started simple and small with one suitcase of tools and materials to set up the studio. The project has proceeded fast and smoothly and for that I am grateful. 30 days in, we are ready to produce the line. I am hoping that the project will grow in time and that the original studio will be better outfitted, and that we be able to replicate the project in 36 other schools, technical training centers, orphanages and villages in this province in South India.


The Impact

I am teaching these girls a marketable skill, giving them a means so that they can provide for their futures, and for their families. The impact of the hope project on these girls is tremendous. Daily I am watching them blossom and grow, gain confidence, joy and hope that they have found a future. With the income they earn from the sale of the jewelry line, they will be able to pay for their own education, support their families and provide a dowry for themselves.

It was my goal to simply change the course of just one life. I now have 5 girls who are very very precious to me. I hope that we will be in each others lives for many years to come, that I get to follow their growth, see them be successful, make sure that they marry well and that they can live a life beyond their wildest dreams. I love these girls. I already feel like this project has been successful.

What We Need & What You Get

I was chosen by a non-profit organization called Home of Hope India to go on this trip and complete this project. I am living with the sisters and the students in very simple accommodations for 6 months. There are expenses that are not being covered by this organization and that is why I am launching phase 2 of this campaign. There will be no salary as this is completely volunteer. I have given up my home, my studio and resigned from my jobs in order to go to do this. To be clear, your contribution to this $2000 is allowing me to have modest living expenses, but more importantly, material and tools so we can produce this line for real.

Thank you gifts for contributing:

$25:  A special surprise Indian gift of my choosing from the Bangalore/Raja Market.

$100:  A special mala chain, inspired from the girls jewelry line, made from recycled materials, in India.  

$250:  A handmade Indian shawl/scarf

$500:  An Indian vegetarian meal cooked by me, from recipes learned during my stay in India.

$1000:  A traditional beautiful sari from India

All thank you gifts will be sent upon return from India.  Please include your shipping address when contributing.  Please note that contributions made through Pay Pal will reach us right away, contributions made by credit card are distributed to us after the campaign ends.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please Please Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, Linked In, email, text or by word of mouth!

Even if you can't contribute financially, your support means so much to me by passing this campaign on to your community.  Thank you!


If you are a jeweler, blacksmith, jewelry tool or jewelry material supplier and you have new, extra or used jewelry tools that you can donate to these girls, please email me at gretchenmclaren@yahoo.com and I will put you in touch with someone that will carry the tools over to me in mid-October.  I'm making tools out of coat hangers so I'll take anything you are willing to contribute.  Thank you, thank you.

story:
The Gallery at John Jay College, located on the corner of 11th avenue and 59th street in the midtown Manhattan gallery district, is dedicated to presenting compelling art exhibitions, performances, as well as educational and public programs.  Our brand new state-of-the-art exhibition space hosts events throughout the year, addressing a wide range of issues including themes of social justice and cultural diversity.  The Center features creative work by world renowned and emerging artists in a variety of media.  The Arts Center's mission is to provide a forum for artistic and intellectual expression, presenting a wide range of ideas and promoting critical thinking and broad participation reflective of today’s globalized world.

September 10, 2012 – October 19, 2012

The Gallery will open with Art For Justice which supports and Exhibits the Art of Incarcerated Individuals to Promote Dialogue and Find Effective ways to: Prevent Crime; Reduce Levels of Incarceration; Improve the Criminal Justice System & Public Safety

With deep respect and reverence for life, Art For Justice acknowledges that for every individual in prison, a crime was committed. It is essential that our society have a Criminal Justice System that addresses crime in ways that ensure public safety. It is also essential that offenders have access to quality legal services. It is in the interest of all that we have a system of laws that are equitably administrated and a Correctional System that is humane.

 

October 29, 2012 – January 28, 2013

Our Second exhibition, Expressing the Social Conscience: Art Prints and Human Rights will coincide with IFPDA Print Fair. The objective of this show is to feature fine arts prints dealing with issues of human rights in order to demonstrate the rich variegation of the medium but also to convey the immediacy of their social message. 

Human rights issues are the most appropriate themes for this medium because the print has been historically used to reach the greatest number of people. This has been the case with Ukiyo-e Japanese prints in the Yoshiwara district that depicted performers, and actors, as well as geishas and sumo wrestlers. It was also the case in Holland as seen in the prints of Rembrandt van Rijn whose objective was to disseminate Christian values to the masses by making prints cheaply and affordable to the masses. In the United States of the thirties we saw a proliferation of posters and prints igniting the fires of many a union rally or political event as well as protest against racism and inequity. Consequently, the print is the most democratic medium capable of reaching the largest amount of people and affecting the most change. It is the intent of this show to impact viewers through its content but also through its medium which in itself is of social relevance.

Some of the artists to be featured:

David Wojnarowicz was a deeply committed gay rights activist/artist who documented his final stages of AIDS.

Willie Cole uses his iron stamping to channel the exploitation of the black population (his mother ironed clothes to make a living) into an aesthetic expression.

Leon Golub represents the classic political art through his unique representation of apartheid.

Kara Walker confronts stereotypical images of black women in our society.

Christiane Baumgartner takes video stills of military imagery and transfers them to the quintessential German medium of woodcut, calling up questions of national identity.

 Sue Coe deals with injustice on an ongoing basis and fights injustice and inequity both visually and personally by working in African villages helping the poor.

Faith Ringgold’s Declaration of Independence and Letters from a Birmingham Jail Suites are powerful visual documents for the fight towards emancipation of African Americans.

Ralph Fassanella, Philip Reisman and Paul Marcus create etchings that deal with the working classes, the unions and labor.

story_txt:
The Gallery at John Jay College, located on the corner of 11th avenue and 59th street in the midtown Manhattan gallery district, is dedicated to presenting compelling art exhibitions, performances, as well as educational and public programs.  Our brand new state-of-the-art exhibition space hosts events throughout the year, addressing a wide range of issues including themes of social justice and cultural diversity.  The Center features creative work by world renowned and emerging artists in a variety of media.  The Arts Center's mission is to provide a forum for artistic and intellectual expression, presenting a wide range of ideas and promoting critical thinking and broad participation reflective of today’s globalized world.September 10, 2012 – October 19, 2012
The Gallery will open with Art For Justice which supports and Exhibits the Art of Incarcerated Individuals to Promote Dialogue and Find Effective ways to: Prevent Crime; Reduce Levels of Incarceration; Improve the Criminal Justice System & Public Safety
With deep respect and reverence for life, Art For Justice acknowledges that for every individual in prison, a crime was committed. It is essential that our society have a Criminal Justice System that addresses crime in ways that ensure public safety. It is also essential that offenders have access to quality legal services. It is in the interest of all that we have a system of laws that are equitably administrated and a Correctional System that is humane.
 
October 29, 2012 – January 28, 2013
Our Second exhibition, Expressing the Social Conscience: Art Prints and Human Rights will coincide with IFPDA Print Fair. The objective of this show is to feature fine arts prints dealing with issues of human rights in order to demonstrate the rich variegation of the medium but also to convey the immediacy of their social message. 
Human rights issues are the most appropriate themes for this medium because the print has been historically used to reach the greatest number of people. This has been the case with Ukiyo-e Japanese prints in the Yoshiwara district that depicted performers, and actors, as well as geishas and sumo wrestlers. It was also the case in Holland as seen in the prints of Rembrandt van Rijn whose objective was to disseminate Christian values to the masses by making prints cheaply and affordable to the masses. In the United States of the thirties we saw a proliferation of posters and prints igniting the fires of many a union rally or political event as well as protest against racism and inequity. Consequently, the print is the most democratic medium capable of reaching the largest amount of people and affecting the most change. It is the intent of this show to impact viewers through its content but also through its medium which in itself is of social relevance.
Some of the artists to be featured:
David Wojnarowicz was a deeply committed gay rights activist/artist who documented his final stages of AIDS.
Willie Cole uses his iron stamping to channel the exploitation of the black population (his mother ironed clothes to make a living) into an aesthetic expression.
Leon Golub represents the classic political art through his unique representation of apartheid.
Kara Walker confronts stereotypical images of black women in our society.
Christiane Baumgartner takes video stills of military imagery and transfers them to the quintessential German medium of woodcut, calling up questions of national identity.
 Sue Coe deals with injustice on an ongoing basis and fights injustice and inequity both visually and personally by working in African villages helping the poor.
Faith Ringgold’s Declaration of Independence and Letters from a Birmingham Jail Suites are powerful visual documents for the fight towards emancipation of African Americans.
Ralph Fassanella, Philip Reisman and Paul Marcus create etchings that deal with the working classes, the unions and labor.

story:
Jeremy Cowart will partner with Exile International and Composite Films to document the prolific use of art therapy for former child soldiers and war-affected children in Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo.  www.exileinternational.org

Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo are said to be among the worst places in the world to be a child.  Our project will show the untold story how art is changing the future of Africa.

So, What’s Happening in Uganda and Democratic of Congo?

In this area, boys as young as 7 are kidnapped and forced to fight in rebel armies. Many are psychologically tortured and brainwashed to commit atrocities against their own families. Young girls are abducted and abused, becoming victims of rape and sexual violence. When these children finally escape or are released, they are left with deep and lasting emotional scars from what they’ve seen and been forced to do. 

 

Our Goal:

       Visit + Listen + Give + Create More Art = Amplify

  • Amplify the voices of these children
  • Amplify funding for our project for 1 year of art therapy and peace program documentation in Uganda  and Congo to show how we can craft a different future for Africa
  • Amplify a future generation of leaders

 

Art About Art:

This is a trip where we will produce art about kids who use art.  The project will be in a country where art, music, and dance are a second language, a huge piece of the culture.

“When the children draw, dance, and sing…we see them come to life again. They begin to forget their wounds for a time.”

Project Deliverables:

Our project will span almost a year

Phase 1 - At the beginning of this project and during our first trip we hope to collect and create several signature art pieces for a traveling gallery exhibit with multiple showings. These pieces will be a part of the perks given out digitally to those that support us.  (see support section)


We will create traveling exhibits of the artwork, digital versions of the stories and artwork, and a short documentary-style, multiple media experience for the gallery exhibits and the web.

Phase 2 – Mid 2013 will mark preparing the release of the documentary highlighting insightful stories of art, music and a culture of art and how they are shaping the future leadership of Africa. The impact and amount we can do on this documentary depends on how much we raise in this campaign.  We will at least do a short documentary in phase two but We hope to exceed our giving goal to pay for a second trip to Africa and for materials for the classes so everyone can participate in the project over the course of almost an entire year.

Our first trip will be in September 2012.  We hope to make another trip in the spring or summer of 2013 to finish up and follow our story of leadership transformation through the use of the arts in Africa.

Jeremy Cowart will passionately create composite art works on the front half and the back half of these trips.   We will show our films and artwork along the way and debut the final film mid 2013.

What your support will create:

  • Photographs for a digital photobook:  Documenting the people, region, and their written stories
  • Drawings and Paintings:  Documenting the history and powerful future these children hope for.
  • Original Gallery Composites:  ‘Jeremy Cowart Original’ curated art pieces will be created on site with the children and will be featured in a special gallery exhibit in the United States.  We hope to help supply art materials to Exile centers so that we may watch and participate in the ongoing stories for a period of one year.
  • Documentary Feature Film revealing the passion, sounds, and vision of a powerful future these children have.  The film will be an inspirational story of children of war becoming leaders for peace while living in one of the worst places to be a child.   How much we raise here will determine our budget for this feature.

Jeremy Cowart will pair his passion for humanitarian storytelling with the art, photography, and filmmaking of this special project.

A special exhibit with unique work from the beginning project will be scheduled first quarter of 2013.   A special Documentary will expand the voice of Painting a Future of Peace and will also be released mid year 2013.

What is Different about our Story?

The story of child soldiers has been told by many organizations.  There are several great international aid groups working actively to end these conflicts in the African region.    The damage to the future has long been done.  These groups are working to stop the cycle.   

Our team and our story are concerned about the next phase.  The “what happens next” question.   We are telling this story about how these same children are becoming powerful leaders of the future.  The big difference in Africa is the substantial impact the arts have on crafting leadership of the future.  

Our ongoing passion for this project will be creating a sustainable and lasting impact on the viewer thru art – composites of art – and film that will perpetuate and celebrate a form of art that empowers child survivors of war to become their country’s next leaders for peace.   It’s a celebration of art.

There is no better way to create a strong future than through the use of art. 

Vision of Exile International - partners on the ground in Africa: 

Our vision for these children is not only that they survive war, but to empower them to be leaders of peace in their communities. We believe that the very thing they thought would kill them can bring life by teaching them to dream again. To be peacemakers.  We believe they are more than what they were forced to do or what has been done to them. In art and expressive therapy they find life again by walking through the rehabilitative process. They find redemption. We invite you into this story of watching pain become purpose. Stepping into a story of former child soldiers becoming leaders of peace, reconciliation, and forgiveness. It's magical. 

Funding for the Project and “Stretch Funding” for Peace Clubs and Art Centers: 

Funding to this project will go to pay travel expenses and production costs for the large format art composites and the documentary.  For nearly a year we will document weekly art therapy groups lead by local African counselors focusing on trauma care, forgiveness, peace-building, and leadership skills for former LRA child soldiers and child survivors of war. The Art and Rehabilitative House in Congo  would be used as a center to provide former child soldiers a safe place to have art therapy groups to paint, draw, create, and dance again. 

"Why do you dance in times of war? To chase away the fear."

Jeremy Cowart, Film Crews, Photography and Art Crews travel End of September 2012 .  We need your help to fund this project and firmly establish a cycle of art coverage for a period of nearly a year.  This includes materials for Art Centers and Peace Clubs in Uganda and the Congo who are our partners in this creative project.

The Future is Before Us:

We would love to invite you into this journey. To become a part of it and watch it unfold.  Empowering children of war to become leaders for peace.

The LRA painted their past. It's time for them to paint their future.

story:
About 2 Blocks of Art

“I’ve yet to find an art walk as unique or grassroots as 2 Blocks of Art, with its truly community driven arts experience. The use of unconventional venues engages people beyond the usual arts consumer, bringing art of a community often overlooked and providing local artists with new audiences and expanded exposure.” -- Deborah Frieden, consultant for arts and culture in communities

2 Blocks of Art are celebratory events conceived and produced by Urban Solutions to promote artists, small businesses and community-based organizations in San Francisco’s emerging Central Market neighborhood. They feature local artistic talent in storefronts, retail businesses, community centers and galleries on 6th Street as well as outdoor street performances along Market Street. With over 100 local artists exhibiting or performing in 25 locations, the art walks strengthen the overall identity and vitality of the neighborhood.

2 Blocks of Art showcases a neighborhood rich in culture and well known for its cutting edge arts community. Now in its third year and growing, Urban Solutions started 2 Blocks of Art on Sixth Street between Market and Howard. With the San Francisco Arts Commission as a partner this year, the events extend to Market Street from Fifth to Seventh Streets with dance, live music and interactive murals. New this year, there will be an arts market and children’s activities on Minna and Natoma Alleys.

A tremendous collaborative effort, participating organizations include Bindlestiff Studio, Inks of Truth, Kularts, Intersection for the Arts, Burning Man, Scrap, and Grey Area Foundation for the Arts as well as galleries Satellite 66, 1AM, Laura Kudritzki Photography, and the Luggage Store.

EXPERIENCE THE NEIGHBORHOOD The events are easily accessible from either Civic Center or Powell Street BART stations in San Francisco.  Come out to Sixth Street between Market and Howard and Market Street between 5th Street and 7th Street on September 28 or October 19 from 4-8pm to enjoy the art and discover something new about the neighborhood. See the map and exhibitions.

About Urban Solutions

Urban Solutions is a 20-year old community-based organization dedicated to creating economic opportunity and building healthy sustainable communities. Headquartered in San Francisco’s South of Market (SOMA), our mission is to strengthen underserved neighborhoods by supporting small businesses, job creation, diversity and sustainability.

In addition to attracting businesses to the area, Urban Solutions takes an active role in the community, offering small business consulting, assistance securing microloans, free workshops and help with adopting sustainable business practices. We also offer extensive services to small businesses from our second office in the Western Addition.  

We have served over 4,800 small business clients, helped businesses secure 335 loans and create 590 jobs since we started. Between 2003 and 2011, we helped to reduce the commercial vacancy rate on Sixth Street from 43% to 9%. And we’ve worked with small businesses to reduce 5,600 tons of greenhouse gas emissions. 92% of our clients are from low-to-moderate income neighborhoods or households.

BUILD COMMUNITY BRIDGES: With California’s elimination of Redevelopment Agencies this year, Urban Solutions has lost a major source of support to revitalize the Sixth Street corridor and Central Market in San Francisco. Your support will help us continue programs to:

  • Unite the historic South of Market community with the booming Central Market area
  • Enrich the neighborhood with a diversity of small businesses
  • Sustain the local artist community by providing entrepreneurship opportunities for them

Thank you for your donation to Urban Solutions!

story:
INTRODUCTION

Digital Images of Boonma's Original Works of Art

for this one-time run of Limited Edition Prints are shown below this Introduction

Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative

My name is Leslie E. Vigerstaff, i am a retired company director based near Manchester in England and have a keen and avid interest in pictorial and sculptural Art. I have always enjoyed life, am a self-motivated person but do need an interest in life, something to drive me, a reason to be. After a couple of years retirement i find i need to be doing something more with my life but, i want my second working life to benefit others who are less fortunate than I. As i was pondering my future i had a revelation, if i combined my interest in the Arts with my ownership of a number of Original Works and used them to benefit other struggling and impoverished Artists around the world, what could be better than that.

My "eureka" moment ... i immediately knew where my future work lay.

Over the years, having observed, listened and spoken to many struggling and impoverished Artists i feel i understand the difficulties Artists have in general. They are "creative people", they need time to dream their next masterpiece, then create it ... but they still need to eat, to pay the rent etc.

My "second working life" i believe, is to create an Artists Gallery, an Artists Cooperative in fact, that will be a "shop window to the world" for all such struggling and impoverished Artists around the world. This project will be a venue for a permanent exhibition, a means of Display, Marketing and Sales procedures handled for and on behalf of the Artists by members of the Artists cooperative and at no cost to the Artists whom we help and assist using this method.

Why the name Gallery Boonma you might ask:

Let me tell you a very true story. A number of years ago, whilst travelling around South East Asia, i came across what can only be described as an Artists Commune and small gallery. I noticed a charcoal and pastel drawing lying to one side, even from such a distance it took my breath away, as i became closer my emotions were running wild, the intricate and finite detail plus the light emanating from the subjects eyes was amazing. I asked to be introduced to the Artist, his name was Boonlert Boonma. He proceeded to show me his work, when you feel the way i do about Art it can be deeply moving, the fascination stirs the emotions, shapes, forms and structures personality, it is able to expose the raw edges of your physche, consume energy, until such time as that image in hung on your wall, in your own in-house gallery.

I am sure all lovers of Art will understand what i am trying to convey in my words:

I was able to purchase a small number of Boonma's Original Works and at that time, arranged and agreed with Boonma that i would employ his services, that i would order and pre-pay for the works he produced for and on my behalf, that way i would have copyright to the works i purchased from Boonma. All went well for a couple of years or so, but since late 2009 Boonma seems to have disappeared, he does not respond to telephone calls, texts or email, friends visiting the area have asked about him, all to no avail, Boonma and his family seem to be lost.

My deepest joy would be for such Works of Art be used to assist other such Artists in their endeavors. Therefore, it is my intention to use Boonlert Boonma's Original Artwork to create a new Artists Cooperative dedicated to Boonlert Boonma via a Limited Edition run of Prints of his amazing work. 

Hence the name Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative:

I believe that all Artists need and avenue of contribution, they need Backers and Patrons [people like you]. Where would the likes of Da Vinci, Degas, Van Gogh, Vermeer be without their backers, patrons, family, friends and acquaintances, they surely would not have survived. We would not have the glorious paintings and sculptures that we gaze upon today, in such reverence and awe, in galleries around the world.

Will you help me, help them:

I have leased space on the first floor of a 18,000 sq ft warehouse and office building at the Riverside Business Park complex in Greater Manchester, North West England. I have started the necessary refurbishment work to create the gallery, have gained the necessary local authority planning permissions and permits, have started to build and fit-out the display areas [photographs below] but far from being a wealthy man we need further funds to complete the work, approximately 88,900 USD. We need high-tech digital graphic printing machines, office furniture and computers, gallery website and optimization services, compliance with the Public Health & Safety regimes that apply to such a venue, specialist gallery lighting, artwork display walls and racks etc, etc, etc.

But one person can only do so much, you the Backer, the Gallery Patron, can and will make a difference to this project, will you help ..?

I truly believe that Boonma's charcoal, chalk and pastel Works of Art are, without doubt, sublime creations and that like minded people will appreciate the artistry, the expertise, the fine exquisite strokes of an artists mind, encompassed and contained in the superb images.

How i intend to raise the funds required to complete this project.

Over the years i purchased 74 Boonma Original Works of Art, i intend to allow sixty [60] to become Limited Edition Prints to a maximum of 500 of each work and size. The Limited Edition Prints will be very high quality, very high resolution digital prints and for the initial Backers and Gallery Patrons will be priced at deep discount to the Gallery Boonma Recommended Retail Price [GBRRP] of a print once the gallery is complete and open to the general public, displaying the Artists Cooperative members pictorial and sculptural artwork alongside Boonma's own work.

Example: 30x20 GBRRP = 99.00 USD each - Backer/Patron x 60 = 52.53 USD each   

Example: 30x20 GBRRP = 63.00 GBP each - Backer/Patron x 60 = 33.25 GBP each

Exchange Rate used is 1.58 USD = 1.00 GBP

Each Backer or Patron of the Gallery will have their choice of Limited Edition Prints from [1] to a maximum of [10] per Backer or Patron. I further believe that every Backer or Patron of the Gallery deserves the highest priority, therefore i have attempted to create the unique "perks program" to suit people from all walks of life and all levels of contribution.

No matter what level of funding we reach, high or low, all is required and every penny will be invested in either the Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative project, and once complete, the balance will fund the Artists of the now and of the future, in there endeavors in the pictorial and sculptural mediums.

Each Artwork will be "Frame Ready" on very high quality 235 GSM Satin Art Paper using eight colour professional print and UV fade resistant inks to ensure the exact  and finite detail contained in Boonma's work.

To ensure that the Backers and Patrons of the Gallery receive their Works of Art in the immediate future, wherever in the world they reside, we have initially contracted with a very high quality professional Digital and Graphics printing company to supply the primary Artwork prints to enable me to fulfill each Backer and Gallery Patrons requirement and would expect to begin shipping the Works or Art within two weeks of completion of funding, target date being first week December 2013.

Each Work/s of Art will be shipped by DHL/FedEx/UPS in specific Artwork Transit Tubes to prevent damage in delivery. If, by any remote chance, damage is caused in transit a simple digital photograph of the damage is required and on receipt of same and the print in question a replacement/s will immediately be sent out to you.

I really do thank you for the time spent in perusing the Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative project. But, i do ask you to spend a little more time in pondering the Artwork [shown below] created by Boonma, it is most worthy off your time, worthy of your investment and a worthy addition to your in-house Gallery, as it is in mine.

There will only be 500 of each, when they are gone, they are gone.

Sincerely

Leslie E. Vigerstaff

All Sixty [60] Boonma Digital Images Below

Guaranteed Deliveries for Xmas:

Worldwide Copyright with all rights reserved:

Images below are very low resolution with Identifier inscribed 

to prevent unauthorized use:

story_txt:
INTRODUCTION
Digital Images of Boonma's Original Works of Art
for this one-time run of Limited Edition Prints are shown below this Introduction
Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative

My name is Leslie E. Vigerstaff, i am a retired company director based near Manchester in England and have a keen and avid interest in pictorial and sculptural Art. I have always enjoyed life, am a self-motivated person but do need an interest in life, something to drive me, a reason to be. After a couple of years retirement i find i need to be doing something more with my life but, i want my second working life to benefit others who are less fortunate than I. As i was pondering my future i had a revelation, if i combined my interest in the Arts with my ownership of a number of Original Works and used them to benefit other struggling and impoverished Artists around the world, what could be better than that.
My "eureka" moment ... i immediately knew where my future work lay.
Over the years, having observed, listened and spoken to many struggling and impoverished Artists i feel i understand the difficulties Artists have in general. They are "creative people", they need time to dream their next masterpiece, then create it ... but they still need to eat, to pay the rent etc.
My "second working life" i believe, is to create an Artists Gallery, an Artists Cooperative in fact, that will be a "shop window to the world" for all such struggling and impoverished Artists around the world. This project will be a venue for a permanent exhibition, a means of Display, Marketing and Sales procedures handled for and on behalf of the Artists by members of the Artists cooperative and at no cost to the Artists whom we help and assist using this method.
Why the name Gallery Boonma you might ask:
Let me tell you a very true story. A number of years ago, whilst travelling around South East Asia, i came across what can only be described as an Artists Commune and small gallery. I noticed a charcoal and pastel drawing lying to one side, even from such a distance it took my breath away, as i became closer my emotions were running wild, the intricate and finite detail plus the light emanating from the subjects eyes was amazing. I asked to be introduced to the Artist, his name was Boonlert Boonma. He proceeded to show me his work, when you feel the way i do about Art it can be deeply moving, the fascination stirs the emotions, shapes, forms and structures personality, it is able to expose the raw edges of your physche, consume energy, until such time as that image in hung on your wall, in your own in-house gallery.
I am sure all lovers of Art will understand what i am trying to convey in my words:
I was able to purchase a small number of Boonma's Original Works and at that time, arranged and agreed with Boonma that i would employ his services, that i would order and pre-pay for the works he produced for and on my behalf, that way i would have copyright to the works i purchased from Boonma. All went well for a couple of years or so, but since late 2009 Boonma seems to have disappeared, he does not respond to telephone calls, texts or email, friends visiting the area have asked about him, all to no avail, Boonma and his family seem to be lost.
My deepest joy would be for such Works of Art be used to assist other such Artists in their endeavors. Therefore, it is my intention to use Boonlert Boonma's Original Artwork to create a new Artists Cooperative dedicated to Boonlert Boonma via a Limited Edition run of Prints of his amazing work. 
Hence the name Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative:
I believe that all Artists need and avenue of contribution, they need Backers and Patrons [people like you]. Where would the likes of Da Vinci, Degas, Van Gogh, Vermeer be without their backers, patrons, family, friends and acquaintances, they surely would not have survived. We would not have the glorious paintings and sculptures that we gaze upon today, in such reverence and awe, in galleries around the world.
Will you help me, help them:
I have leased space on the first floor of a 18,000 sq ft warehouse and office building at the Riverside Business Park complex in Greater Manchester, North West England. I have started the necessary refurbishment work to create the gallery, have gained the necessary local authority planning permissions and permits, have started to build and fit-out the display areas [photographs below] but far from being a wealthy man we need further funds to complete the work, approximately 88,900 USD. We need high-tech digital graphic printing machines, office furniture and computers, gallery website and optimization services, compliance with the Public Health & Safety regimes that apply to such a venue, specialist gallery lighting, artwork display walls and racks etc, etc, etc.
But one person can only do so much, you the Backer, the Gallery Patron, can and will make a difference to this project, will you help ..?
I truly believe that Boonma's charcoal, chalk and pastel Works of Art are, without doubt, sublime creations and that like minded people will appreciate the artistry, the expertise, the fine exquisite strokes of an artists mind, encompassed and contained in the superb images.
How i intend to raise the funds required to complete this project.
Over the years i purchased 74 Boonma Original Works of Art, i intend to allow sixty [60] to become Limited Edition Prints to a maximum of 500 of each work and size. The Limited Edition Prints will be very high quality, very high resolution digital prints and for the initial Backers and Gallery Patrons will be priced at deep discount to the Gallery Boonma Recommended Retail Price [GBRRP] of a print once the gallery is complete and open to the general public, displaying the Artists Cooperative members pictorial and sculptural artwork alongside Boonma's own work.
Example: 30x20 GBRRP = 99.00 USD each - Backer/Patron x 60 = 52.53 USD each   
Example: 30x20 GBRRP = 63.00 GBP each - Backer/Patron x 60 = 33.25 GBP each
Exchange Rate used is 1.58 USD = 1.00 GBP
Each Backer or Patron of the Gallery will have their choice of Limited Edition Prints from [1] to a maximum of [10] per Backer or Patron. I further believe that every Backer or Patron of the Gallery deserves the highest priority, therefore i have attempted to create the unique "perks program" to suit people from all walks of life and all levels of contribution.
No matter what level of funding we reach, high or low, all is required and every penny will be invested in either the Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative project, and once complete, the balance will fund the Artists of the now and of the future, in there endeavors in the pictorial and sculptural mediums.
Each Artwork will be "Frame Ready" on very high quality 235 GSM Satin Art Paper using eight colour professional print and UV fade resistant inks to ensure the exact  and finite detail contained in Boonma's work.
To ensure that the Backers and Patrons of the Gallery receive their Works of Art in the immediate future, wherever in the world they reside, we have initially contracted with a very high quality professional Digital and Graphics printing company to supply the primary Artwork prints to enable me to fulfill each Backer and Gallery Patrons requirement and would expect to begin shipping the Works or Art within two weeks of completion of funding, target date being first week December 2013.
Each Work/s of Art will be shipped by DHL/FedEx/UPS in specific Artwork Transit Tubes to prevent damage in delivery. If, by any remote chance, damage is caused in transit a simple digital photograph of the damage is required and on receipt of same and the print in question a replacement/s will immediately be sent out to you.
I really do thank you for the time spent in perusing the Gallery Boonma Artists Cooperative project. But, i do ask you to spend a little more time in pondering the Artwork [shown below] created by Boonma, it is most worthy off your time, worthy of your investment and a worthy addition to your in-house Gallery, as it is in mine.
There will only be 500 of each, when they are gone, they are gone.
Sincerely
Leslie E. Vigerstaff
All Sixty [60] Boonma Digital Images Below
Guaranteed Deliveries for Xmas:
Worldwide Copyright with all rights reserved:

story:
ABOUT THE RESEARCH

'Batik Sarong Terengganu'  is a research project that aims to contribute to the existing research on batik sarong Malaysia. However, it is intended to produce a comprehensive database of batik sarong Terengganu. Charting its origins, history and stories of its makers and trading.


WHY BATIK SARONG TERENGGANU

Batik sarong is essentially a tube like skirt that is worn with a blouse that forms a traditional attire. Commonly worn by communities in South-East Asia. In Malaysia, it is a garment used across all races and societies produced mainly in the east coast of the Peninsular Malaysia, in the state of Kelantan and Terengganu.

In Terengganu, batik is the heart of the state. It is so much a part of its society that its importance goes beyond a physical attire. It forms a tangible and intangible cultural heritage - filled with oral traditions, expressions, knowledge sharing and generates economy for its communities. So much so it is also a part of our national identity. There is a lack of references on the history and origins of batik sarong of Terengganu, thus, this research would serve to contribute towards this.


WHAT IS THE FINANCIAL GOAL 

The financial goal is (1) to document and publish the history of batik sarong Terengganu and Kelantan into a publication entitled 'Batik Sarong Malaysia: Heritage of Today for Tomorrow'. So generations of researchers, families and art enthusiast would have references on batik sarong of Malaysia.

(2) to provide an innovative and creative platform that looks to merge skills of the batik craftsmen and young Malaysian designers. This merger hopes to promote the transfer and sharing of knowledge of these two skills sets in efforts to preserve a cultural heritage and the cottage industry of the east coast. The product of this merger will be materialised in limited edition batik sarongs transformed into tokens of appreciations for each of our backers.

(3) to make the information accessible through an exhibition and educational programmes on design, pattern making and hands on workshops planned for December 2014 here in Kuala Lumpur. With enough funds it would make it possible for us to transfer the knowledge into a digital format and have it available online for everyone around the world to also have.

WHY YOU SHOULD SUPPORT

We call out to cultural heritage advocates, batik enthusiast, designers, artists, most importantly fellow Malaysians, to come together in this effort to preserve a national cultural heritage. Everyone involved in this research are contributing their effort and time voluntarily. No profit is made by any party involved. 


WHAT WE NEED

We need your help to make this happen.The cost of the research amounts up to USD 7,000.


WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO

Your contribution will be part of this effort in keeping a live a national cultural heritage. The funds raised will go to:

  • visual and audio documentation equipment
  • subsistence for travelling and accommodation
  • hiring a local guide 
  • bridging local talented designers and traditional batik makers to work on the limited edition batik sarong for offered perks
  • additional balance from the funds raised will be used to contribute to the exhibition and publication


HOW WILL YOU KNOW WE'VE SPENT WISELY

Contributors will receive perks for their contributions. The items offered to our backers are produced in limited edition. This means the batik sarong made will be designed specifically for this project by traditional batik makers of Terengganu.

The production process will be documented and updated for you to follow.
You will also be able to see the fruits of your generosity and our research progress through our website updates. 

http://batiksarongterengganu.tumblr.com/


NO MONEY TO CONTRIBUTE. YOU CAN STILL HELP.

  • Help spread the word around through your networks. 
  • Buy a copy of the publication when it's out. 
  • Share your personal story and experiences on Batik Sarong of Terengganu with us. Go to our website for more information.


SHIPPING COST 
Shipping cost is as stated in the perks column. 
If you want to pledge for more than 1 item, your postage may differ. Write to us to enquire on the exact rates. 


ABOUT THE RESEARCH TEAM

Raja Fuziah Raja Tun Uda the initiator of the research project has been involved in the development and promotion of the arts and crafts in various capacities since the 1960's. She was the former founding Director General of Malaysian Handicraft Development Corporation, a member of the Board of Trustees, National Art Gallery Malaysia, founder member and Honorary Secretary of AHPADA, and Regional President of the World Crafts Council Asia Pacific. 

Her professional commitments include UNESCO AHPADA Seal of Excellence for Handicrafts for South-East Asia and the Malaysian National Award for the Arts. Served as Assistant Director General with OIC Istanbul-based Research Centre for Islamic History, Art & Culture (IRCICA) from 1986- 1989, 

Assistant researcher for the project is Erna Dyanty Mad Daluis. Graduated from the National University of Malaysia (UKM) with a Masters Degree in Art Management. Her ten-years professional experiences in the field of both contemporary and traditional crafts gave her the opportunity to work with established institutions such as the Islamic Arts Museum Malaysia and National Visual Arts Gallery. She has contributed her time to the development of Malaysia's contemporary photography through KL International Photoawards and Exposure+ Photography Mentoring Programme.

Through her professional career she has worked on various research and documentation projects such as the Dato’ Hoessein Enas Collection Database with Valentine Willie Special Project, Narratives in Malaysian Art Publication with Rogue Art and Malaysia Day Photography Research for Yee I-Lann.
She looks to continue her PhD in the field of Cultural Heritage Studies. 


Thanks for your pledge and hope that we raise the funds we need.
With your help we can achieve the completion of this research and share the information with everyone.

story:
Catchin’ Babies, Colonizing Black Bodies, seeks to note the historical persecution of Diasporic traditional birthing practices and bodies by providing a historical narrative and illustrative examples of how colonialism and the medicalization of birth impacted southern Black grandmother/granny midwifery and Caribbean midwifery in the early 20th century. We borrow from early Black communities in the American South usage of the term ‘catchin’ babies’ to describe midwifery to offer homage to this centuries-old practice. This collaborative project highlights Prof. Bonaparte’s socio-historical research on physicians’ written advocacy against Black midwives and my artwork on the role of colonialism in Diasporic environs.

Grandmother midwives or granny/nana midwives were an integral part of birthing traditions throughout the African Diaspora, most particularly in the early U.S. South and in the Caribbean.  These midwives were typically older women, had a spiritual “calling” to the profession, held an apprenticeship until the older midwife retired, or followed a matrilineal family tradition of midwifery, and were post-menopausal in some instances. Granny midwives practicing in America in the early 1700s through the early 1900s tended to be African American, functioned as birth attendants, healers and herbalists, were based in rural settings, and served in pivotal leadership positions (and for some religions) within their communities.  Similar to their American counterparts, Jamaican midwives (known as nanas) also served as birthing attendants, healers, and herbalists in their communities.  A common theme between how midwives of color practiced in the U.S. and in Jamaica is a rising concern regarding maternality rates. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, White male doctors in the U.S. pathologized pregnancy and medicalized birth.  Whereas in certain Caribbean nations such as Jamaica and Trinidad & Tobago, due to rising maternal mortality rates, maternity hospitals were established and served as sites of midwifery practices thanks to the advocacy of doctors and other healthcare practitioners.  So, although Caribbean midwives served as primary birth attendants, they like granny midwives in the southern U.S., operated under similar edicts of seeing birth as an unnatural occurrence that required medical intervention thank to the influence of Eurocentric birthing ideals. This post-colonial shift from healing to medical intervention had a lasting impact on the bodies of Black people in both of these regions.  Colonialism functions as an axis of economic oppression which resulted in what Foucault terms a biopolitics that controlled Black bodies and birthing attendants.  This control of Black bodies resulted in a social inheritance of deleterious health outcomes such as diabetes and hypertension.  Noted feminist scholar Dorothy Roberts highlights that since slavery, white supremacy and patriarchy contributed to the early policing of Black bodies and poignantly adds that this policing negatively affected the maternal health of Black women throughout the African Diaspora

We will use the funds to conduct research in Montego Bay and Kingston, Jamaica for 4 weeks.  In particular, we will research archival materials, such as photographs of midwives practicing and medical records such as birthing records/birth books, interview and photograph both past and present midwives, descendants of those children birthed by granny midwives and individuals who work in midwifery birthing centers. We will also locate local plants and foods that were used for medicinal purposes relating to midwifery. We will document our findings by photographing and drawing interviewees, recording audio interviews, and making paintings of medicinal herbs. The research and artwork created with the grant will become part of a larger installation that constructs a narrative surrounding my grandmother Beryl LeCadre, who practiced midwifery for over 30 years. I will illustrate Dr. Bonaparte’s research by using Beryl as a protagonist, in order to acknowledge and celebrate the importance of midwives in the Diasporic communities. Together we are seeking funding in the amount of $3,600.

Budget

Archive photocopying/licensing costs $300

Transportation costs ((LAX to Montego Bay) $900 ea; 6/30/14 to 7/30/14, car service in Jamaica $350

Interviewing materials (transcription costs 8 hrs @ $20/hr): $150 artist materials (supplies, digital production of images):$600

Shipping $400

Andrea Chung explores themes of labor and materials and their relationships with post-colonial countries. Chung is interested in the imbued histories that materials, such as sugar, carry and how they also carry with them the stories of human transmission and the long lasting effects of colonialism on tropical ‘post-colonial’ societies such as the Caribbean and the Indian Ocean. She received a BFA at Parsons School of Design, a MFA at the Mount Royal School of Art at the Maryland Institute College of Art, and received a Fulbright Scholarship to Mauritius in 2008. She also attended the Skowhegan School of Painting, the Headlands Center for the Art and the Vermont Studio Center. Chung’s work as has been featured at Off Color, curated by Hank Willis Thomas and Kalia Brooks at RUSH Arts, Conner Contemporary in Washington, D.C., Arlington Arts Center, UNC Chapel Hill, Columbia University, Deutsche Bank’s 60 Wall Street, MoCADA, the Art Museum of the Americas, Syracuse University and the McColl Center for Visual Art. Her work has appeared in the academic journals, Small Axe, ARC Magazine, Representations, Transitions and was featured in the Jamaican Biennale in Kingston, Jamaica. Chung was a 2013 Rema Hort Mann Foundation Award nominee.

Dr. Alicia Bonaparte, PhD is an Assistant Professor of sociology at Pitzer College in Claremont, CA. She received her BA from Spelman College and her MA AND PhD FROM Vanderbilt University. Her research interests include African American sociology, medical sociology; hierarchical systemS within healthcare, reproductive health disparities, birthing, midwifery, and Granny midwifery. Dr. Bonaparte was the recepient of a Nicholas R. Doman Fellowship in the Social Sciences and a Mellon Junior Faculty research award for her research on midwifery in Barbados. She is currently co-editing with Julia Oparah an anthology entitled Black Women, Birthing Justice.  She's also published within The Journal of Historical Sociology and Social Science History.

Shipping
$400Andrea Chung
explores themes of labor and materials and their relationships with
post-colonial countries. Chung is interested in the imbued histories that
materials, such as sugar, carry and how they also carry with them the stories
of human transmission and the long lasting effects of colonialism on tropical
‘post-colonial’ societies such as the Caribbean and the Indian Ocean. She
received a BFA at Parsons School of Design, a MFA at the Mount Royal School of
Art at the Maryland Institute College of Art, and received a Fulbright
Scholarship to Mauritius in 2008. She also attended the Skowhegan School of
Painting, the Headlands Center for the Art and the Vermont Studio Center.
Chung’s work as has been featured at Off Color, curated by Hank
Willis Thomas and Kalia Brooks at RUSH Arts, Conner Contemporary in Washington,
D.C., Arlington Arts Center, UNC Chapel
Hill, Columbia University, Deutsche Bank’s 60 Wall Street, MoCADA, the Art Museum of the Americas, Syracuse University
and the McColl Center for Visual Art. Her work has appeared in the academic
journals, Small Axe, ARC
Magazine, Representations, Transitions and was featured in the Jamaican Biennale in Kingston, Jamaica. Chung
was a 2013 Rema Hort Mann Foundation Award nominee.

Dr. Alicia Bonaparte, PhD is
 an Assistant Professor of sociology at Pitzer College in Claremont, CA.
 She received her BA from Spelman College and her MA AND PhD FROM 
Vanderbilt University. Her research interests include African American 
sociology, medical sociology; hierarchical systemS within healthcare, 
reproductive health disparities, birthing, midwifery, and Granny 
midwifery. Dr. Bonaparte was the recepient of a Nicholas R. Doman 
Fellowship in the Social Sciences and a Mellon Junior Faculty research 
award for her research on midwifery in Barbados. She is currently 
co-editing with Julia Oparah an anthology entitled Black Women, Birthing Justice.  She's also published within The Journal of Historical Sociology and Social Science History.

story:
2014 Cystic Fibrosis Inspirational Calendar

In 2012, my son Mason (featured image) was diagnosed with Cystic Fibrosis, a chronic disease that affects the lungs and digestive system of about 30,000 children and adults in the United States.

People living with CF suffer a variety of symptoms, including

  • Frequent lung infections
  • Wheezing or shortness of breathing
  • Persistent coughing
  • Poor growth and weight gain

In the 1950s, few children with cystic fibrosis lived to attend elementary school. Today, advances in research and medical treatments have further enhanced and extended life for children and adults with CF. Right now, the media survival age in the 30's, but as a dad I want to do something to imrpove that.

The Calendar

As a new father, to find out that your son has a genetic disease that will affect him for the rest of his life is very overwhelming.  I made a committment to do whatever it takes to raise as much money for research as possible.

The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation was recently recognized as one of the most efficient organizations of its kind. Nearly 90 percent of every dollar of revenue raised is available for investment in vital CF programs to support research, care, and education.

Here's what my plans are for this project:

  • Secure $2,000 in funding to cover the cost of a reputable photographer at 12 different photo shoots.
  • Reach out and locate 12 kid living with Cystic Fibrosis and capture their story and photo of them doing what they love (riding a bike, playing sports, etc).
  • Develop a calendar that features one story per month and also highlights a variety of facts about CF to help with education and awareness.
  • Sell the calendar for $30 via a microsite, at CF events and through social media.
  • 100% of the $30 purchase will be donated back to Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.

I have already secured the following at no cost:

  • Designer - A coworker will be donating his time
  • Programmer - A coworker will be donating his time
  • Printing - Family and friends agreed to cover the cost of the calendar printing so as to maximize our donations

 

If you can afford to at this time, a donation to help cover the photography cost would be greatly appreciated.  Thank you for the chance to tell you my story.

story:
Short Summary

We know Apogaea is hard. And sometimes, when all you need is a good nap, that tent just gets too hot. Hidden Retreat is your temporay autonomous nap zone, and only the determined will find this plush oasis in the woods. But, once found, you will be rewarded with a serene space to rest, nap, create or have an intimate conversation with friends.

Hidden Retreat is a quiet place to get away from the techno music, wild parties and craziness of the rest of Apogaea. Choose from one of three peaceful spaces located in the trees, all within close proximity of each other. Comfy blankets and pillows beckoning you to take off your shoes, sit down, relax and breathe. Lie down under the trees and look overhead. There, beautiful fabrics, garlands, crystals and wind chimes floating from trees will entertain your eyes and ears (if you aren't napping already). At night the trees and ground are lit up with soft lights. This will be a secret space to nap, relax, journal, create, have conversations, do yoga, meditate, or hold a ceremony.

Hidden retreat is just that, hidden. We'll be listed in the WWWW, but the location will not. Wander, enjoy the woods, and stumble upon our hideaway.

We just need a little help funding beautiful decorations so that this space is more than just some blankets thrown on the ground!


Hidden Retreat is: Rraine (former Lamplighter lead, and napper extraordinaire), Caroshine (former Apo President, and cuddle puddle instigator), Capt. Love (BAMF member and professional arborist), and Adena (expert meditaor and lover of love).

What We Need & What You Get

Our plans include creating three areas, each with a different theme, all in close proximity to each other. If we meet our fundraising goals, all three spaces are viable. $700, in conjunction with an Apo art grant (THANK YOU!), will allow us to prepare one space. If we reach the $1000 mark, we can provide two spaces. $1,500 will allow us to bring the entire vision to life, including three spaces with:
 
  • Comfy, clean pillows and blankets
  • Sustainable, solar rope lighting
  • Sustainable, solar ground lighting
  • Sustainable, solar chinese lanterns
  • Garlands, crystals, chimes, and other beautiful tree decor
  • Decorative boxes for your footwear
  • Art hangings
  • Gentle gongs

Feel free to contact us for a detailed budget.

Check out our relaxing, affirming rewards!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for considering helping our project bring rest and relaxation to Apogaea. If you aren't able to help out financially, please consider helping to spread the word, donating any of the above items, or holding your quiet, peaceful workshop at the Hidden Retreat.

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

We love you,

Rraine, Caroshine, Capt. Love, Adena

story:
David Rowe's Art of Knightmare

Hi,

I'm David Rowe and I was called in from producing computer game, book and magazine covers to create the illustrations that formed the core of the labyrinth of Dungeon rooms for that TV landmark, Knightmare which ran for 8 series in the 1980s and 1990s. 
I retained all the documents, scripts, plans, rough sketches, drawings and original artworks that I produced, including a vast volume of Knightmare related work. 
As I ponder the material that I have in my attic, plan chest and cupboards, I fear that it may deteriorate and that my recollections will become muddied with time. I have also learned the hard way about the importance of backing up computer data and so feel compelled to back up all the hard copies of the material that I have while I have the chance. I feel that the best way is to create an eBook so that it is not only a documentary record, but a 'great-to-look-at' art book. 
There is a lot of material and many recollections to put down and this will all take a fair amount of time. Your contributions will help me take a few months out to to put this important record together.

The Campaign and Rewards

I need to raise £3,500 so that I can take a few months out to scan all the drawings and original paintings, prepare the eBook spreads and add my narrative. 
In return for your contributions I am producing some Knightmare memorabilia, most of which will only be available to contributors to this campaign. I will keep adding to them throughout the funding period, so remember to keep a look out. I am including anything from badges and stickers to signed prints and hard copies of the book which will have pages unique to the campaign.
I am going for flexible funding, so if the campaign fails to reach its goal, I will still make this important effort, but it will have to take a lot longer to achieve. So whatever is contributed will be put to good use.

The Impact

Knightmare has maintained a strong following since the last series was aired and interest shows no sign of waning. Material that might otherwise have been lost takes on a much more significant value. The pioneering chromakey techniques that helped to create the atmosphere of the 'Castle of Confusion' can be described together with the drawings and paintings in a form that we hope will enlighten and entertain.

"I am with you all the way. It was your brilliant artwork that gave the show its magic. The kids truly believed they were stepping into a fantastical world. It must be preserved at all costs. To any fan, and I include myself, to have such a book would be a 'must have' item." Hugo Myatt.(Treguard)

Throughout the campaign and the lifetime of the project, I will make regular posts to let you know how the project is developing with sneak previews of the spreads and any fascinating material that I uncover.  I have made a small start already, so please take a look www.facebook.com/david.rowe.art

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution, you can still help to make the project happen, by sharing it with your friends by email, Facebook, Twitter and any other device you can think of. 
You can also share using the Indigogo share tools.
Thanks for looking at the campaign! Wish me luck!

story:
Who is Marguerite Joyce Wood

Marguerite Joyce Wood set forth the intention of DOING GOOD in all her children.  Joy was always engaged in learning or executing a new craft, for several years she ran a small ceramic shop in Missouri, and she always had space at her table for an extra friend.

What We're Building

The "MJ Wood Memorial Short-Term Residency Fund" will support ceramic artists who wish to develop a body of work with a socially-conscious spirit, a sense of community engagement, and the intent to DO GOOD with their creativity and skill. The residency will occur under the umbrella of Red Lodge Clay Center's studio in Red Lodge, MT where residents artists will have the opportunity to work in a first-class facility for one month.  Their project will also receive international attention through the Red Lodge Clay Center website. Supporters of the Residency Fund will be able to follow not only the growth of the fund, but also the work produced by it on Jill's blog at whistlepigstudio.blogspot.com  

 

Who we are

 

Michael Hutton and Jill Foote-Hutton have committed to an annual contribution of $450 to underwrite a one month short-term residency at Red Lodge Clay Center, but would like to see this opportunity take root and grow into an endowment. Both Michael and Jill are vested in the development of socially-conscious craft endeavors, and want to create an opportunity supported by regular folks who believe in the power of craft, a single action, and one dollar.

 

What is Social Practice 

Here are some social practice projects and articles to underscore the spirit of the MJ Wood Residency, and help define the currently trending term "social practice". 

Bowls Around Town

Outside the Citadel

The work of Sharon Kallis

Puppets N People

Craftivism

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The goal is to make it possible to support this residency at whatever fiscal level you can afford.  $1 to $1,000, we don't want to leave anyone out who wants to be a patron for good in this world.  The $450 base will cover the residency fee, monies raised above and beyond that will help defray the costs of firing kilns, ceramic materials, groceries, and transportation.

If you ARE supportive, but just can't manage a fiscal contribution right now-

        *Get the word out about this opportunity to your community!

        *Follow Red Lodge Clay Center or Whistlepig Studio so you'll know when the   residents are in Red Lodge and send care packages to them. Helping defray their out-of-pocket costs!

Thanks, and remember:  DO GOOD!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
The Greenwood Lake Mural Project began as a daydream, and ended up becoming a testament to the American Dream.  Each time I drove by this building, that long blank wall inspired visions of art, community creativity, and tightly knit neighbor networks working together to make our views even more appealing, and welcoming visitor and local alike.


Two summers ago I received a $4,000 grant from Orange County Tourism to help make that dream a reality.  Through crowd funding, I raised another $2,000.  I went about working out ideas with members of our small village community.  Going door to door, getting to know business owners, and my neighbors.  Here are links to the last 2 campaigns.


Everyone was very excited about the prospect, and we went ahead with making these removable panels of artwork by village resident artists.  Each panel depicts a landscape of Greenwood Lake painted right here in our village through different seasons. 


Of course, the first ever big art project in a small village isn't always created without causing some controversy.  You can read about ours in this New York Times article.

 
Once our settlement was reached in early April, it became clear that this series of events has galvanized the community more than ever before.  It has brought artists and art supporters together both locally and beyond demonstrating that our community is replete with creativity.  


People are becoming more hopeful about the future of Greenwood Lake.  There is a feeling that a tipping point approaches for the village, and every small improvement goes a long way towards that point. We are more inspired to participate in the fate of our lake, our neighbors, our businesses, and we support others who do the same.  Rob Reiner even came and made a film here in the summer of 2011.
 

The panels have amazingly survived the test of two brutal hurricanes in their two year residence at Barnaby Prints.  They've also traveled to Newburgh for an event celebrating Orange County Tourism Arts Grant recipients, bringing our Greenwood Lake creative spirit with them.


Our original goal for this exhibit was to represent all four seasons.  What you see in the photo are panels representing Summer, Fall, and Spring in Greenwood Lake along with a panel siting the names of those who contributed to the project (seen in its entirety on Facebook). 


Artists;
"Fall" - Gad Nusinov
"Summer" - Louis Delsarte
"Springtime in Greenwood Lake" - Sonia Centeno Dainty


The Hudson River School began right here in our area attracting the imagination of landscape artists as far back as the mid 19th century.  With this project, we continue that tradition.


This year, we are installing the final season by Mary Jo Ben-Nun.  Mary Jo was born and raised in the South Bronx and has been an illustrator and artist since 1985. She is an Associate Professor of Art at Bronx Community College of the City University of New York. She holds a B.F.A degree in Illustration and Art Education from the School of Visual Arts, and an M.F.A. degree in Graphics from Lehman College.

She has been a resident of Greenwood Lake since 2001.  Mary Jo was moved by the idea of utilizing public art to educate and inspire the community and got involved in the Greenwood Lake Mural Project from an early stage. She was delighted to work on the final Winter Scene panel, weaving family and friends into the painting. The artwork is a tribute to our beautiful Greenwood Lake and the diverse people who call it home.  

 

What we need


-We will be using this money to have a professional billboard company make the mesh PVC panel, and buying all the hardware necessary to hang the art and replace the hooks holding the panels to help them sustain heavier winds.

-We are hoping to add 5 solar lights each of which will illuminate the panels at night


-If we make more than the goal, we would also like to plant some flowers along the bottom of the building prefereably in containers.  


What you get


You get the pleasure of knowing that you've contributed to public art in a small village in Orange County NY.  Hopefully, you also get to visit and enjoy the artwork.  A personalized day tour of Greenwood Lake awaits you if you give $100 or more.  See details on the right side of this page.


Other Ways You Can Help


Please go to our Facebook Page and click the like button.  Tell us what you think of the project there, and share your thoughts on art, Greenwood Lake, and creative expression in society in general.  We look forward to seeing you, and to you seeing us.  THANK YOU for your support.

story:
ROOMS is the husband and wife team of Marrakesh and Todd Frugia. ROOMS is dedicated to exploring and strengthening the relationship between artist and audience by experimenting with the creative process and expanding the vocabulary of language and experience through live performance, installation and video.
 
ROOMS was created ten years ago and continues to experiment, and perform their work in their Pilsen studio monthly as well as other performing venues and festivals in Chicago.
 
ROOMS will be performing their piece RITUAL No. 1: COUNTING BIRDS in the DIMANCHE ROUGE EXPERIMENTAL PERFORMANCES FESTIVAL in HELSINKI, FINLAND on October 17th and 18th 2013.
 
This will be their very first time performing outside of the country. 

What We Need

  • Money for plane tickets from Chicago to Helsinki, performance materials, and trip expenses such as lodging, food, and transportation. 

What You Get

  • ROOMS will be representing the U.S. and Chicago abroad. When you support ROOMS, you support the international exchange of art, and the culture of performance.
  • Various perks are offered in exchange for your donation, including original ROOMS performance photo stills, a DVD of a ROOMS performance, and a commissioned performance for you and your guests!

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to ROOMS on September 7th for our fundraiser!

8-10PM VIP Entry $20 donation
Includes light food and specialty cocktail
RAFFLE
SILENT AUCTION
10PM on Late Night Entry $10
DJ DANCE PARTY

story_txt:
ROOMS is the husband and wife team of Marrakesh and Todd Frugia. ROOMS is dedicated to exploring and strengthening the relationship between artist and audience by experimenting with the creative process and expanding the vocabulary of language and experience through live performance, installation and video.
 
ROOMS was created ten years ago and continues to experiment, and perform their work in their Pilsen studio monthly as well as other performing venues and festivals in Chicago.
 
ROOMS will be performing their piece RITUAL No. 1: COUNTING BIRDS in the DIMANCHE ROUGE EXPERIMENTAL PERFORMANCES FESTIVAL in HELSINKI, FINLAND on October 17th and 18th 2013.
 
This will be their very first time performing outside of the country. 

What We Need

Money for plane tickets from Chicago to Helsinki, performance materials, and trip expenses such as lodging, food, and transportation. 

What You Get

ROOMS will be representing the U.S. and Chicago abroad. When you support ROOMS, you support the international exchange of art, and the culture of performance.
Various perks are offered in exchange for your donation, including original ROOMS performance photo stills, a DVD of a ROOMS performance, and a commissioned performance for you and your guests!



Other Ways You Can Help
Come to ROOMS on September 7th for our fundraiser!

story: didnt have a video of my house truck build .... I built my last house truck from repurposed salvaged material found in Bisbee ,,,,   old tin from roofs, ship lap siding from the early 1900s, a old child's toy box with clowns and such, a cloths hamper from the 40s with embossed roses, Cyprus siding circa 1900 .....drove this on 2500 and it held up perfectly ....   broke the timing chain on this one along with multiple other mechanical issues including no reverse , shifting and starting problems I had no choice but to let this one go ...built this house on a 17% incline, used past carpentry and aircraft building experience , work out perfect ....     i hope to buy a Chevy Suburban at Bisbee Police Auction ..... Tim Hall at Bisbee Bug will go over all the mechanical, especially the timing belt and get it road ready ..... I,ll cut the top off and start building a BEAUTIFUL house truck ....    $2000.00 will be used for purchase of the suburban, screws, glue etc .... 90% of the materials will be found in Bisbee and re purposed ...

story:
An exhibition of works on body and works on paper

I am working with breeding words to create icons that represent the dynamic forms of memory that we carry with us.

I am sitting with architecture, capturing and erasing the history of passing light while balancing gesture, bilaterally.

I am multiplying and mutating the iconic forms I discover through applied techniques.

I am interested in the cyclic degeneration and regeneration of ideas, lives, and materials. 

  My 3rd solo exhibition, CARBON, is being presented by the independent curatorial team MARSO at Polyforum Siqueiros in coordination with programming at MUNAL (Museo Nacional de Arte) and Zona Maco, Mexico City's internationally recognized contemporary art fair.


My residency includes

Two weeks working in Mexico City (April 1-14) in which my flight, additional materials, space, and boarding are granted, as well as a three month solo exhibition (opening April 19) in a beautiful building that was designed around massive murals by David Alfaro Siqueiros.  


     Your donation will allow me to

Enter process and establish my ideas and techniques to generate new work.  I needâ€¦

- time, space, materials, gasoline to sustain a studio practice prior to my short residency period in Mexico City.  

- to orchestrate shipments, and design/construct visual artifacts for performative and installation aspects of my show.

- afford a videographer, photographer, and editor to document the work both for visual presentation and proper archiving.

- to afford food, transit, and my interactions with the community while in Mexico City.


     The Impact

This would have on my exhibition and personal trajectory into the creative unknown is of course, immeasurable.  My current work has received much international attention and acclaim, mostly to the credit of viral activity on art and design blogs and media.  I continue to gain the support of collectors and gallerists, but I have not been able to sustain a studio practice.  My existence has been quite nomadic for the past few years, and while I honor the effects of that fuel, I am eager to make space.


     You can also

Help me broaden my audience by passing my campaign along to a friend who might be interested in my cause, or by posting a link to my campaign on your facebook, twitter, or blog.


Recent attention on my work at

Poptech: Tony Orrico: Symmetry in Motion

NEA Interview: Tony Orrico: Spontaneously Navigating Space

Elle Magazine Editorial (Mexico)




FURTHER NOTES ON PERKS

- any contribution will be gifted a screen saver file of my artwork 

  and CARBON press flyer 

- perks can be shipped domestic and international

- unfortunately, your contribution is not tax deductible,

  and an effort has been made to offer perks as gifts worth their value

- perks will be shipped out in two periods: 3rd week of March, or 2nd week of May.

- inquires welcomed at info@tonyorrico.com

 

PERK 1


5 X 7 (matte) digital print, edition of 100

hartharthart.com
