story:
Short Summary

Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine is a travel book that takes a loving look at some of the less-publicized aspects of life in the Pine Tree State. Our goal: to raise $2200 to print a limited run of 250 copies.

Over the last fifteen years, Heidi Killion and I have traveled in the South and Southwest, documenting our experiences in print and on film. After covering so many miles “away” we decided to investigate the small towns and rural routes of our home state, Maine. Our editor at the time, Sam Pfeifle of the Portland Phoenix, gave us carte blanche to explore the gritty, weird, and often humorous side of Vacationland: we visited the drag races in Oxford and a hunting camp in St. Albans. We stopped to chat with fishermen playing horseshoes near Winter Harbor, and drove five hours north to New Sweden for Midsommar.

In 2013, we decided to compile the essays and photos from our travels into a book. Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine is the result. You won’t see photos of lighthouses or get advice about where to find the best lobster roll here. We love lighthouses and lobster rolls, but there is so much more to Maine! We made it a priority to go places and have experiences—right here at home—that pushed us beyond the comfortable and familiar.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re hoping to raise $2200 to cover the cost of printing 250 copies of Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine. All funds raised (minus Indiegogo’s nominal fee) will go toward production costs. We will be donating 20% of any profits from the book's sale to the Maine Women’s Fund.

What’s in it for you? All donors will receive a deluxe thank you postcard with an image from the book. Contributions in any amount will help support women in the arts, advance the cause of venturesome ladies (why should guys get to have all the fun?), and bring a book into the world that celebrates Maine in all its whacky glory.

But aside from these intangible satisfactions, you can:

·  Be a Blueberry! For a $5-20 donation, you will receive a vintage-style “I Love Maine” button.

·  Be a Bittern! For a $21-30 donation, you will receive a set of five images (dealer’s choice) from the book.

·  Be a Bean Boot! For a $31-50 donation, you will receive a signed copy of Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine.

·  Be a Black Bear! For a $51-75 donation, you will receive a signed copy of Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine and a set of five gorgeous images from the book.

·  Be a Buzzy! (What’s a Buzzy? Have you seen Trailer Park Boys? Much like our favorite character Bubbles, Buzzy is good natured, kind to animals, always game for a new experience, and loyal to a fault.) For a $76-100 donation, you will receive a button, five pics, a signed copy of the book, and two grandstand tickets to Beech Ridge Motor Speedway’s June 2015 Day of Destruction. Feckin’ A Right, Dude.

*NOTE: you can donate any amount (say, $22, because it is your lucky number) and still get the perk for the dollar range listed. You'll have to click "no perk," since Indiegogo doesn't do ranges, but let us know that you do, in fact, really want your nice pictures, and we'll send them to you!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know there are times when, as much as you’d like to pitch in, you just don’t have the cash to spare. But there are ways you can help: tell your friends. Share our campaign link on Facebook: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/two-for-the-road-adventures-in-maine/x/8464730 Tweet it, too: #twofortheroad

Who We Are

We met working at a little bar in Portland, Maine, but Heidi and I became friends the night we both volunteered to Go-go dance for a local band called Stinkypants. A shot of Wild Turkey and several hectic sets of garage punk behind us, we discovered that we had a lot in common. A year later, on a road trip through the American South and Southwest, we realized we were seeing similar movies in our heads: she captured hers on film, and I wrote mine down, but it was only logical that—when a friend adapted a short story of mine for a movie— Heidi was the one who designed the costumes and sets.

When we started working for the Portland Phoenix, our beat included boxing and no-holds-barred fighting, a U.S.O. dance with some of the last remaining WWII vets in Maine, a night of lady oil wrestling, and of course, Maine travel. Heidi was awarded a USM SURF grant to spend a summer shooting new images for Two for the Road: Adventures in Maine, and in 2010 we started a travel blog http://swimminginoppositedirections.wordpress.com/. In 2012, we gave a presentation (at Pine Manor College in Chestnut Hill, MA) on Cross-disciplinary Collaboration, Travel, and Identity.

We’ve seen each other through break ups, bad ideas, career crises, and the challenges of making creative work and making a living at the same time. In a way, we grew up together: I’m now the Associate Director of the Solstice Low-Residency MFA in Creative Writing, and Heidi is pursuing teacher certification for K-12 Art Education. But we’ll always be restless, and ready for a road trip, a dive bar, and the continued conversation that has sustained us all these years.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Chris James. I am 24 years old. I have been passionately pursuing a career as a spoken word artist and photographer since graduating high school. I now live the life of a poet, playwright, author, photographer, father and teaching artist. It is my goal to make art available to all those in my community and to eliminate oppression. For years, I have dedicated thousands of dollars and hours into keeping the arts vibrant in my under-served community. I love what I do. This is what I live for.
  • The Roots Art Connection is an organization that promotes youth and community involvement in Creative Arts and Culture while simultaneously increasing awareness, literacy, creativity, and improving the wellness of life for all. Growing up I didn't have access to such enrichment due to social and economic injustices and barriers. Today, many youth and adults still have the same struggle. I know art has the power to change lives and everyone should have the benefit of experiencing that.
  • Your contribution will help eliminate oppression in the art community. More youth and adults will have access to art shows, poetry events and program services. This space will allow artists who can't afford studio space to have somewhere to create their original work. This space will be a place for poets, youth and artists of all forms to commune. Resources is all we need to create such a home for the arts. Every $1 makes a difference in our progress.


What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We are seeking to raise $5,000 through crowd funding. Our total project cost is $20,000. $6,600 of that is our rent expense for 12 months. Other expenses include supplies ($2,800), furniture(1,250) and contract/consultants($9,350). Crowd Funding will cover rent and furniture for our space.
  • Our gallery space will be a very eclectic place. The walls be orange, red, yellow and blue as well as the furniture. The space will be open daily for artist to come create art and you are welcome to come by at anytime.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, funds we do raise will go directly towards our rent expense.

The Impact

The Roots Art Connection currently has two programs in operation that benefit the youth of Central Arkansas: Poetry Saves Lives and The Roots Theatre Project. Both programs are presently offered to youth ages 10-24.

The Roots Art Connection frequently holds events for adult poets and artists to showcase their talents to appreciative audiences. The Roots Art Connection -Gallery/Youth Hub/Studio will guarantee such programs and events are consistently continued. Once the venue has opened weekly poetry readings, workshops, art shows and more eclectic events will be held throughout the year.

Central Arkansas has yet to have a venue of this caliber that is abundantly focused solely on creative arts in the community.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Please share the word about our campaign so we can be more successful in our endeavors.
    • You can share our link by simply clicking the social media icons.

    And that's all there is to it.

The Roots Art Connection currently has two programs in operation that benefit the youth of Central Arkansas: Poetry Saves Lives and The Roots Theatre Project. Both programs are presently offered to youth ages 10-24. 
The Roots Art Connection frequently holds events for adult poets and artists to showcase their talents to appreciative audiences. The Roots Art Connection -Gallery/Youth Hub/Studio will guarantee such programs and events are consistently continued. Once the venue has opened weekly poetry readings, workshops, art shows and more eclectic events will be held throughout the year.
Central Arkansas has yet to have a venue of this caliber that is abundantly focused solely on creative arts in the community.
  Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help: 
Please share the word about our campaign so we can be more successful in our endeavors. You can share our link by simply clicking the social media icons. 
 And that's all there is to it.

story:
Can you help us Make/Dinner?

We’re humans: we make things. We’re interested in the things we make for one another, from something as complex as a ballet to something as simple as a perfectly grilled burger. And because we know that all creativity is collaborative, we want to explore the ways other people matter to making. 

At Make/Dinner, a new event series, Philadelphia artists present their works in progress to intimate audiences at crucial junctures, the pivot points where solo imagining thrives on collective collaboration. These events take place in Philadelphia neighborhoods with a strong sense of their histories, but where two families living in a duplex might still remain strangers to each other. What better way to get to know your neighbors than to break bread with them -- and chop herbs, and shake salad dressing, and ladle soup, and pour wine. And make art.

The first Make/Dinner event, Feast at Pastorius, on September 8 (rain date 9/15), will feature local artist Vita Litvak, and will welcome a dozen guests to the Pastorius Community Gardens to dine on foods grown in the garden around them and sourced locally from Germantown. Over dinner, the artist will experiment with filming the meal being consumed. Guests will get to know one another while having the opportunity to ask questions about and respond to the work as it is created.

Because one goal of Make/Dinner is to bring neighbors together, we want to eliminate any barriers to participation -- there's no cost to attend. For that reason, we need your support. Your contributions will help to pay for the meal, the materials to create the artist's work, transportation, and a fee for the artist. Because this is a hyper-local event, your donations go straight toward community businesses, artists, and goods. 

Groceries

Here's what it takes to bring a Make/Dinner event to life...

$400 - Artist fee 

$200 - Cost of food and drink

$400 - Artist materials and supplies

$50 - Transportation 

$160 - Project administration

$30 - design and printing of flyers and menus

Total: $1240

All of our donors will be recognized at the meal on our dinner menu, as well as online.

Why works in progress? 

As a society, we still put a lot of stock in the myth of the solo artist: the sculptor or writer laboring alone, the genius implementing their ideas. But by opening up the seams of an artist’s work while it’s still in development, we believe audiences can have a window into the ways that all artists collaborate, whether by collecting ideas and feedback from others, weaving their major influences into their project, or placing their work in conversation with another piece. 

Why a dinner party? 

When we eat together, we become human: we encounter one another's traditions, taboos, delights, dislikes, and loves. When we prepare food together, these elements are thrown into even sharper relief -- the sensory feast of fresh ingredients on their way to becoming a meal can bring even strangers close. Creating a work of art is an intimate act, and we hope that by observing the small intimacies implicit in pouring someone a glass of water, passing them a plate, or choosing the tomato they'll slice into a salad, participants can also channel the artist's relationship to the work.

Can’t donate today?

You can still enter the lottery to attend at no cost!

Spread the word! Make/Dinner is a new type of project, and so we need advocates like you to share why this is a unique idea. You have the ability to share details about Make/Dinner directly from Indiegogo!

story:
Project Background

Since 2013, thanks to thousands of individual donors, several corporate sponsors, and the incredible generosity of The Walt Disney Company, The Walt Disney Birthplace has been completely transformed. Six years ago in 2013, it looked almost nothing like the worker's cottage designed and built by Flora and Elias Disney, Walt's parents, in 1893. Today, the home once again looks like the humble dwelling pictured in its earliest known photo.

But it is not ready to open to the general public. 

The interior Window Sponsor plaques and the dedicated Fence Slat plaques have been installed, and the next round of dedicated Paver Stones will be completed before Winter freezes the ground again this year. As always, we are enormously grateful to everyone who so graciously donated to the project; the home looks as beautiful as it does because of YOU!

 

Next Steps

The Walt Disney Birthplace will be much more than a traditional "stay behind the velvet rope" house museum. A visit to The Birthplace will be a highly immersive, interactive experience that will incorporate state-of-the-art entertainment technology to bring the home to life. 

The first part of making this vision a reality is furnishing the home with era-appropriate beds, chairs, tables, kitchen cupboards and equipment, etc.  (If you own and would like to donate any Victorian-era furniture, please contact us: contact@thewaltdisneybirthplace.org!)
 

Parlor Concept Art

Kitchen Concept Art

 

A Fantastic Limited Opportunity To Get Your Name Inside The Home!

To celebrate this year's D23 Expo — and D23's recent visit to the Birthplace and the local Hermosa community — we are running this "Friends Of The Birthplace" campaign!

You can add your name to the inside of the Birthplace by contributing at this time! For only 23 days, we are offering the chance to support the project with a $200.00 pledge. For every donor who contributes, we will add their names to a donor plaque, similar to the Fence Slat plaques, to be placed on a framed panel inside the home! 

We are limiting the number of these special "Friends Of The Birthplace" donor plaques to 100, first come, first served. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Opening the home for regularly scheduled group tours will still require significant expenditures. Along with completing the immersive guest experience, an offsite visitor's center with parking will need to be developed, as well as transportation trolleys to and from the Birthplace. This will ensure that we do not disrupt the fabric of life in Hermosa, the quiet residential Chicago neighborhood where The Birthplace resides.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to participate in this mini-campaign, we have other ways to support the project! Please visit http://www.thewaltdisneybirthplace.org/contribute/ to find out more!

story:
We MADE It! What's next? 

Thanks to all of YOU we reached our goal. What could we get done with an extra bit of funding? So glad you asked!

+5K: Education/Outreach (15K raised)

+Community, need-based scholarships

+Develop outreach programming targeted at middle and high school students.

+10K: More equipment (20K raised)....all of the above plus:

+Etching press

+Fiber tools: ball winder, swifts, Harrisville floor looms, Schacht Flip Rigid Heddle Looms, and more


Our Mission

The mission of Makers’ Mill is to strengthen the northern Berkshire creative community through infrastructure, collaboration, organization, and education.

Makers’ Mill, the North Adams makerspace, is a space for creative collaboration to foster new learning opportunities and build a community around a shared passion for making. Located in downtown North Adams, Massachusetts, Makers’ Mill is a creative resource for the local community that allows people to work and learn alongside one another. It cultivates an environment ripe for experimentation in new media and processes, boosting economic and creative vitality in our region by empowering people to MAKE!


Who are we?

We are a group of artists, makers, and supporters of the arts. Each of us lives and works in northern Berkshire County. We come from a variety of backgrounds and bring with us unique skills and perspectives. To learn more about the Makers' Mill founding team, check out our team profiles. 


How do we work?


Makers’ Mill is starting with shared resources to support printmaking and fiber arts with expansion plans to include other disciplines. Printmaking equipment will include screen printing, relief printing presses, and, if we reach our funding goals, an etching press. Fiber arts will offer use of a large-format loom, a small floor loom and other weaving equipment, sewing machines, and a shared fiber workspace.

Our all-inclusive membership will provide access to all machines and equipment for $40/month. We will also offer semi-private, micro-studios available for an additional monthly fee. All programs and workshops will be open to the public with members receiving a discounted rate. 

By offering a range of workshops geared towards a variety of learners, Makers' Mill is supporting makers of all ages and backgrounds. We are providing both training classes to certify safe and productive use of equipment and advanced workshops taught by skilled artists. And to create the next generation of makers, our outreach programming targets children, teens, and families. Workshops are a great way to experience what the space is all about, get your hands dirty and MAKE!


Why should you help?

Your contribution is essential for Makers' Mill to acquire necessary equipment for printmaking and fiber arts. Operational funding will come from membership fees, micro-studio rentals, workshop revenues, and grants. Your support is an investment in our makers, in our local art scene, in our economy, and in our community.

North Adams is in the artistic heart of the Berkshires. Home to notable museums, such as MASS MoCA, The Clark, and the Williams College Museum of Art, this area is rich in artistic inspiration. However, it needs a shared space where local artists and the next generation of makers can come together, where they can meet and MAKE. Makers’ Mill will address this important unmet need. 

Sustainability

Over 50 artists attended our very first meetup. We have a mailing list of over 150 interested local makers, and an estimated 500 possible members in the northern Berkshires alone. Thanks to this, and the overwhelmingly positive response we've received from area artists, businesses, and community members in the planning process, Makers' Mill is positioned to be a long-standing member of the North Adams creative community.


Phased Growth

Your generous donation will allow us to launch Phase 1 of Makers’ Mill with a primary focus on printmaking and fiber arts. But we won't stop there. Once we are firmly planted, our plans for growth include expansion into other disciplines such as woodworking, 3D printing, jewelry/metalsmithing, photography, and more! Makers’ Mill will be an ever-evolving space that will respond to its membership base in order to make a continued impact in the North Adams arts community. This campaign is simply the beginning of our mission to MAKE!


How will we use your donations?

Your donation is critical for us to get Makers’ Mill up and running! While we have received generous equipment donations, there are crucial items that must still be secured. The funds raised through this campaign will help buy materials to build screen printing equipment, repair a relief printing press, purchase sewing machines and fiber arts tools and materials, and enable us to properly build-out the space for use. This is how Makers' Mill plans to use the funds secured through this campaign:

● $2,800—Printmaking equipment

● $3,700—Fiber arts equipment

● $2,700—Minor building renovations

● $800—Start-up costs

But wait, there's more!

Have you seen our awesome thank you gifts for contributors? Attend a workshop, get a handmade journal, or have a relaxing weekend retreat in the Berkshires. Many of these perks are unique, handmade, and limited, so act fast! 

Makers' Mill is project of Lever, Inc., a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. Contributions to Makers' Mill are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.


Please share this campaign with people who might be interested in supporting our project and thank you in advance for your support!

This is how Makers' Mill plans to use the funds secured through this campaign:
● $2,800—Printmaking equipment
● $3,700—Fiber arts equipment
● $2,700—Minor building renovations● $800—Start-up costs

But wait, there's more!



Have you seen our awesome thank you gifts for contributors? Attend a workshop, get a handmade journal, or have a relaxing weekend retreat in the Berkshires. Many of these perks are unique, handmade, and limited, so act fast! 



Makers' Mill is project of Lever, Inc., a tax-exempt 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. Contributions to Makers' Mill are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

Please share this campaign with people who might be interested in supporting our project and thank you in advance for your support!

story:
Help Us Show Our Art in NYC this July!

The Baroque Power Group is a team of artists comprised of Alexandra Hammond, Quinn Dukes, JD Reanbeau, and Hovey Brock. We met at the School of Visual Arts MFA in Art Practice program. We joined forces because we wanted to present our artistic research to a broad audience in NYC this coming summer. By working together we think that we can be 4 times more efficient and spread our ideas 4 times further than we could working on our own.

We’ve found an exhibition space that we love in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Because this prime location is expensive to rent, we’re asking for the support of our community to help offset our investment.

As artists of the Baroque Power Group we aren’t unified by a particular style or medium, but by shared values and interests: that nature is not separate from humanity; that individual experience is diverse and dignified; and that consciousness is a gift.

We called our team the Baroque Power Group because we are inspired by the ideas of 17th Century Spanish-Dutch philosopher Baruch Spinoza. Contrary to the Western dualisms of human vs. nature, good vs. evil, self vs. Other, Spinoza believed that all things partake of one substance.

The 4 exhibitions we present in July will be free and open to the public. We can’t wait to see you at our shows! However you choose to participate, we hope that you join us in the ongoing conversations proposed by our art.

We are honored and delighted to receive your financial support, friendship and engagement.

What We Need & What You Get

We are working to raise $5,000 to offset our investment in renting a street-level gallery space at 2 Rivington for the month of July. Each member of the Baroque Power Group will show work for 1 week out of the month. Our total cost for renting this space is $11,000. This does not include the cost for the materials, technology and labor that goes into the creation of our art.

We have collectively made this investment in exhibition space because we want to bring our artwork to the widest, most engaged audience possible. By locating our shows in one of NYC’s most vibrant art districts (1 block from the New Museum and in a neighborhood filled with world-class contemporary art galleries) we are making our exhibitions accessible to friends, colleagues, teachers, critics and collectors.

(The space at 2 Rivington. Image courtesy of Parasol Projects)

As part of this campaign, we offer a variety of artworks (made by us!) in appreciation of your support. This is your chance to claim an original work by a member of the Baroque Power Group. Check out the "Gifts" heading below to see the perks we are offering as thanks for your support. 

This is art history in the making. Be a part of it!

The Impact of Our Work

“The art world isn’t a market, it’s a conversation.”

                                              -- David A. Ross, Chair, SVA MFA in Art Practice 

We believe that art is a kind of laboratory and archive of what it means to be alive in our particular time and place. In his or her own way, each member of the Baroque Power Group uses art as a means to investigate and participate in the disparate community that is life on earth in the first part of the 21st Century.

We have all experienced how art can bring us joy, make us angry and put us in touch with both beauty and suffering. Often, art combines all these elements, helping us to make meaning out of the mixed experience of existence. We believe that art asks questions and makes unexpected connections. Art is the field where we think, act and make, all at once.

Risks & Challenges

Being an artist comes with no guarantees. It is work that we do because we love it and we want to spend our time on this earth doing it. It is possible that we won’t make money on this work, and that it will not be well-received.

This campaign is not only about raising funds for our summer exhibitions but also about building a community of supporters who want to engage with our ideas and the artistic productions that we use to inhabit those ideas.

As artists, we are self-starters, self-organized and used to making few resources go a long way. We have worked hard, juggled responsibilities of graduate school, work and life to bring you our summer exhibitions. We guarantee that your financial support will be put to good use.

Other Ways You Can Help

All forms of support, financial and otherwise are crucial to our success. If you don’t choose to donate, please help us by getting the word out about our Indiegogo campaign and our artwork.

  • Share this campaign on Facebook
  • “Like” and repost Baroque Power Group posts on social media
  • Visit our blog 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to blast us to your millions of friends
  • Most importantly, come to the openings of our shows! (we’ll keep you posted with the details)
You are our community! We love you. Thank you for your support. ♥

♥ Gifts from the Baroque Power Group ♥

We are offering the following gifts in appreciation of your support: 

Tarot Reading by Hovey Brock
(for a donation of $25)

A five minute on-line Tarot Card Reading from Hovey Brock. Questions answered about spiritual, personal or career choices.

++                                                                                                                               Psychic Portraits by Hovey Brock                                                                             (for a donation of $25)

5" x 7" abstract ink paintings on watercolor paper. Each of us projects a persona as distinct as a finger print, Send Hovey Brock a picture of yourself and he will return a portrait of the energy you project to others.

++                                                                                                                         Goldlugger Logo Poster by Alexandra Hammond
(for a donation of $25)

A limited edition hand-stenciled Goldlugger logo poster signed 
by the founder of Goldlugger.

++                                                                                                                         

Snakebit Kitten Prayer Card by Alexandra Hammond 
(for a donation of $25)

Receive a limited-edition Snakebit Kitten Prayer Card (5.5" x 8.5"). This inkjet print on watercolor paper is a token that reminds us of the simultaneous vulnerability and resilience of the famous Snakebit Kitten, who was bitten on the head by a rattlesnake and yet survived.

++
Glitter Splat Pony Drawing by JD Raenbeau 
(for a donation of $25)

Receive an original line drawing by JD Raenbeau. These sloppy yet elegant drawings are an explosion of marker, stickers and metallic paint.

++
Pony Line Drawing by JD Raenbeau
(for a donation of $25)

An original line drawing by JD Raenbeau with bursting pony parts, hearts, and rainbows. Marker and colored pencil on paper.

++
Soundscape MP3 by Quinn Dukes in collaboration with Keller McDivitt
(for a donation of $25)

A digital sound design meant to transport you to a ritual mind-body space.

++

Digital Collage by Quinn Dukes (for a donation of $25)

Receive a limited edition, 11"x15" print by Quinn Dukes. This digital print combines performance imagery from Dukes' current performance series entitled, 'Sensing/Dispersing'.

++
VIP Performance Pass from Quinn Dukes
(for a donation of $50)


Ticket and instructions to attend a secret performance event curated by Quinn Dukes

++
Tits Tee by Alexandra Hammond 
(for a donation of $50)

A silkscreened cotton T-shirt with the Tits Tee graphic designed by Alexandra Hammond and Oakland artist Julia Hamilton.

++
Online Philosophy Performance Lecture by Hovey Brock 
(for a donation of $50)

Attend a 5-minute on-line philosophy lecture performance webinar.

++
Cordelia Fagonard Pinup by JD Raenbeau 
(for a donation of $50)

Limited edition photographic print of Cordelia Fagonard in her opulent habitat (pictured here in Alexandra Hammond's StoryHut)

++
PonyDisneyGlitter Postcard by JD Raenbeau 
(for a donation of $75)

Handmade, mixed media postcard collage.

++
Performance Art Zine by Quinn Dukes 
(for a donation of $100)

Limited edition performance zine created by Quinn Dukes, performance artist and founder of "Performance is Alive." The zine presents work by Dukes and featured Performance Is Alive artists. dimensions: 5.5"x8.5", 24-page zine.

++
Sloppy Pony Painting by JD Raenbeau
(For a donation of $250)

Original "Sloppy" pony paintings are acrylic on paper. 
They shimmer and glitter. 6"x6"

++
Performance art artifact from Falsed, a performance by Quinn Dukes
(For a donation of $250)

Hydrocal cast Falsed rock encased within a vitrine. Also accompanied by an 8"x10" signed print from the performance.

++
Abstract Drawing By Hovey Brock
(for a donation of $500)

Original Hovey Brock pastel abstract drawing on paper, 10" x 14."

++
Watercolor by Hovey Brock 
(for a donation of $1,000)

Original vintage Hovey Brock abstract watercolor on 300# cold press watercolor paper, 22" x 30." 

++
Goldlugger Soft Sculpture by Alexandra Hammond 
(for a donation of $1,000)

Genuine Goldlugger soft sculptures are "cut from the very cloth of Walliecamp". Each is painted with a unique message about the conflation of wealth and happiness. 14" x 21" x 5"
story_txt:
Help Us Show Our Art in NYC this July!The Baroque Power Group is a team of artists comprised of Alexandra Hammond, Quinn Dukes, JD Reanbeau, and Hovey Brock. We met at the School of Visual Arts MFA in Art Practice program. We joined forces because we wanted to present our artistic research to a broad audience in NYC this coming summer. By working together we think that we can be 4 times more efficient and spread our ideas 4 times further than we could working on our own.We’ve found an exhibition space that we love in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Because this prime location is expensive to rent, we’re asking for the support of our community to help offset our investment.As artists of the Baroque Power Group we aren’t unified by a particular style or medium, but by shared values and interests: that nature is not separate from humanity; that individual experience is diverse and dignified; and that consciousness is a gift.We called our team the Baroque Power Group because we are inspired by the ideas of 17th Century Spanish-Dutch philosopher Baruch Spinoza. Contrary to the Western dualisms of human vs. nature, good vs. evil, self vs. Other, Spinoza believed that all things partake of one substance.The 4 exhibitions we present in July will be free and open to the public. We can’t wait to see you at our shows! However you choose to participate, we hope that you join us in the ongoing conversations proposed by our art.We are honored and delighted to receive your financial support, friendship and engagement. What We Need & What You GetWe are working to raise $5,000 to offset our investment in renting a street-level gallery space at 2 Rivington for the month of July. Each member of the Baroque Power Group will show work for 1 week out of the month. Our total cost for renting this space is $11,000. This does not include the cost for the materials, technology and labor that goes into the creation of our art.We have collectively made this investment in exhibition space because we want to bring our artwork to the widest, most engaged audience possible. By locating our shows in one of NYC’s most vibrant art districts (1 block from the New Museum and in a neighborhood filled with world-class contemporary art galleries) we are making our exhibitions accessible to friends, colleagues, teachers, critics and collectors.(The space at 2 Rivington. Image courtesy of Parasol Projects)As part of this campaign, we offer a variety of artworks (made by us!) in appreciation of your support. This is your chance to claim an original work by a member of the Baroque Power Group. Check out the "Gifts" heading below to see the perks we are offering as thanks for your support. This is art history in the making. Be a part of it!
The Impact of Our Work
“The art world isn’t a market, it’s a conversation.”                                              -- David A. Ross, Chair, SVA MFA in Art Practice We believe that art is a kind of laboratory and archive of what it means to be alive in our particular time and place. In his or her own way, each member of the Baroque Power Group uses art as a means to investigate and participate in the disparate community that is life on earth in the first part of the 21st Century.We have all experienced how art can bring us joy, make us angry and put us in touch with both beauty and suffering. Often, art combines all these elements, helping us to make meaning out of the mixed experience of existence. We believe that art asks questions and makes unexpected connections. Art is the field where we think, act and make, all at once.Risks & ChallengesBeing an artist comes with no guarantees. It is work that we do because we love it and we want to spend our time on this earth doing it. It is possible that we won’t make money on this work, and that it will not be well-received. This campaign is not only about raising funds for our summer exhibitions but also about building a community of supporters who want to engage with our ideas and the artistic productions that we use to inhabit those ideas. As artists, we are self-starters, self-organized and used to making few resources go a long way. We have worked hard, juggled responsibilities of graduate school, work and life to bring you our summer exhibitions. We guarantee that your financial support will be put to good use. Other Ways You Can HelpAll forms of support, financial and otherwise are crucial to our success. If you don’t choose to donate, please help us by getting the word out about our Indiegogo campaign and our artwork. 

Share this campaign on Facebook


“Like” and repost Baroque Power Group posts on social media


Visit our blog 


Use the Indiegogo share tools to blast us to your millions of friends


Most importantly, come to the openings of our shows! (we’ll keep you posted with the details)


You are our community! We love you. Thank you for your support. ♥
♥ Gifts from the Baroque Power Group ♥
We are offering the following gifts in appreciation of your support: Tarot Reading by Hovey Brock (for a donation of $25)A five minute on-line Tarot Card Reading from Hovey Brock. Questions answered about spiritual, personal or career choices.++                                                                                                                               Psychic Portraits by Hovey Brock                                                                             (for a donation of $25)5" x 7" abstract ink paintings on watercolor paper. Each of us projects a persona as distinct as a finger print, Send Hovey Brock a picture of yourself and he will return a portrait of the energy you project to others.++                                                                                                                         Goldlugger Logo Poster by Alexandra Hammond (for a donation of $25)


A limited edition hand-stenciled Goldlugger logo poster signed by the founder of Goldlugger.
++                                                                                                                         
Snakebit Kitten Prayer Card by Alexandra Hammond (for a donation of $25)



Receive a limited-edition Snakebit Kitten Prayer Card (5.5" x 8.5"). This inkjet print on watercolor paper is a token that reminds us of the simultaneous vulnerability and resilience of the famous Snakebit Kitten, who was bitten on the head by a rattlesnake and yet survived.
++Glitter Splat Pony Drawing by JD Raenbeau (for a donation of $25)

Receive an original line drawing by JD Raenbeau. These sloppy yet elegant drawings are an explosion of marker, stickers and metallic paint.

++Pony Line Drawing by JD Raenbeau (for a donation of $25)




An original line drawing by JD Raenbeau with bursting pony parts, hearts, and rainbows. Marker and colored pencil on paper.
++Soundscape MP3 by Quinn Dukes in collaboration with Keller McDivitt(for a donation of $25)
A digital sound design meant to transport you to a ritual mind-body space.
++
Digital Collage by Quinn Dukes (for a donation of $25)



Receive a limited edition, 11"x15" print by Quinn Dukes. This digital print combines performance imagery from Dukes' current performance series entitled, 'Sensing/Dispersing'.
++VIP Performance Pass from Quinn Dukes (for a donation of $50)



Ticket and instructions to attend a secret performance event curated by Quinn Dukes

++Tits Tee by Alexandra Hammond (for a donation of $50)







A silkscreened cotton T-shirt with the Tits Tee graphic designed by Alexandra Hammond and Oakland artist Julia Hamilton.
++Online Philosophy Performance Lecture by Hovey Brock (for a donation of $50)


Attend a 5-minute on-line philosophy lecture performance webinar.

++Cordelia Fagonard Pinup by JD Raenbeau (for a donation of $50)


Limited edition photographic print of Cordelia Fagonard in her opulent habitat (pictured here in Alexandra Hammond's StoryHut)
++ PonyDisneyGlitter Postcard by JD Raenbeau (for a donation of $75)



Handmade, mixed media postcard collage.

++Performance Art Zine by Quinn Dukes (for a donation of $100)



Limited edition performance zine created by Quinn Dukes, performance artist and founder of "Performance is Alive." The zine presents work by Dukes and featured Performance Is Alive artists. dimensions: 5.5"x8.5", 24-page zine.

++Sloppy Pony Painting by JD Raenbeau (For a donation of $250)



Original "Sloppy" pony paintings are acrylic on paper. They shimmer and glitter. 6"x6"


++Performance art artifact from Falsed, a performance by Quinn Dukes(For a donation of $250)





Hydrocal cast Falsed rock encased within a vitrine. Also accompanied by an 8"x10" signed print from the performance.



++Abstract Drawing By Hovey Brock(for a donation of $500)


Original Hovey Brock pastel abstract drawing on paper, 10" x 14."
++Watercolor by Hovey Brock (for a donation of $1,000)


Original vintage Hovey Brock abstract watercolor on 300# cold press watercolor paper, 22" x 30." 
++Goldlugger Soft Sculpture by Alexandra Hammond (for a donation of $1,000)


Genuine Goldlugger soft sculptures are "cut from the very cloth of Walliecamp". Each is painted with a unique message about the conflation of wealth and happiness. 14" x 21" x 5"

story:
Over the summer of 2014 while walking home one evening I was interrupted by the distinct vision of an art show featuring dance works. I saw the space, the choreography, the people, the lighting. It was so visceral yet outside myself; I knew I had to take the thought seriously. This vision came to me repeatedly in the following months and I started to delve into the purpose of the show. What was my purpose? What is the show saying? Who is it telling?

NATA NATA NADA

NATA NATA NADA is a dance video installation piece, exploring what it means to be human - as all art does. It is an intersection of art mediums, the body and video as commentary on our evolution, our beginning and our purest form and how they interact. 

The video focuses on five archetypes and their relationship to each other. As humans, we have many parts of ourselves that we hide, or posturize. During different times in our lives different archetypes surface or battle for attention. There are internal roles we take on as characters, and our external world is quick to give us roles to adapt to, step into, or fight to reject. NATA NATA NADA looks at the archetypes of Mother, Baby, Bully, Hero and Sex Symbol, their interaction, relationship, struggle, and triumph. While these five are taken from a personal place, and are feminine in nature, my hope is to create work that is universal to the human through choreography, while making dance as an art form more accessible. The name is a play on words, NATA having different orgins meaning birth, creator, speaker and dancer and NADA meaning nothing lends to the duality of human nature, or feelings and our actions, OUR EXISTENCE, while also paying tribute to my name Natalia, and the personal journey (Caminata) creating this work has been.

BUDGET AND BENEFITS 

-Renting Space for the Show June 13th! (THE SPACE I IMAGINED EXISTS!! A FRIEND PUT ME IN CONTACT WITH SOMETHING THAT LOOKS JUST LIKE WHAT I PICTURED -- PLEASE HELP ME SECURE IT)

-Filming and Editing 

-Lighting Designer

-Renting Space to film in

-Choreography/ Practice Space (I have developed my choreography in open fields, Independence Park, and in my living room furniture pushed aside, as well as a great facility Links Hall, renting to young artists workshopping their pieces in need of space to MOVE for $12/hr. I would love to have the room to continue to practice and clean up before filming)

BENEFITS vary from tickets, post card thank you notes, or a dance class for you and friends taught by me, Natalia, to your name in the credits -----> view right for more details!

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Time, SPACE, and funding have been the greatest challenges. 

The greatest risk has just been ego.

BUT WHERE THERE IS A WILL THERE IS A WAY!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!!!

If you are not in the position to donate, (no amount is too small though! All gifts are truly helpful and appreciated!)  please help by spreading the word! Share the project with your friends and family if you want to be apart of its fruition!


PEACE, LOVE, AND MANY THANKS!

story:
Pinelandia Gallery opened its doors early this spring. We curated three shows in three months to show the need for and possibilities of an art gallery in this region of Mississippi. It was a success! We received only positive feedback. However, we have concluded that we need to expand our offerings and business model in order to continue to grow and pay our overhead. We are working to build and open spaces for other other artists and crafts people to rent for studio or exhibition. We will continue to have the main gallery for art and performance. We also need to work on our little black box theater room to be able to offer drama classes to children.

Your funds will go directly to materials, for we do all of our own construction work. Who are we? Robert and Sloane Cheatham, husband and wife, artists, entrepreneurs, parents, writers and community minded folk. We moved to Mississippi and year and half ago to live a simpler life with our young son and hopefully do good in the world. Please help us make a difference in a real way!

Some of you helped us get started with this project, and we thank you so much. You're a part of a positive ripple effect in an area of our country that needs art and creativity support. We ask for you to spread our request for assistance at this time and help if you can. If we can get this thang really rockin' and rollin' you will receive a t-shirt... one day.

What we are trying is an uphill battle, no doubt. But we are hard workers and feel we have no other choice but to make our best effort at making a positive impact using our creative talents to an area that would not have it otherwise. We feel it is what led us to this point... something greater than ourselves, perhaps.

To find out more, please check out our previous indiegogo campaign:

https://igg.me/at/PinelandiaArtGallery/x/13096991.

We appreciate any effort you may offer!

story:
Before I get to the meat of this....

Contributions to this Indiegogo is a direct show of support to my work. Support can be given by throwing in a buck or two, buying one of the many available paintings I have, or passing this link along to like minded people who would appreciate what I've got going on here. 

Support is so important, especially in the performance piece The Last American Indian On Earth. The social and artistic merits of this project are life changing, and soul shaking as it creates a natural and real look at the way people interact with, view and consider Indigenous people with the advent of the Internet, TV, Movies and basic American culture. Projects like this DIE without support. 

Supporting by donating here, buying some of my work, or passing this effort to friends or family who are like minded.

Here's the meat:

My name is Gregg....

I am an artist. An Indigenous artist. From my last Indiegogo project, you might know my efforts to bring the performance piece The Last American Indian On Earth to fruition. I am in the throws of this performance piece in addition to my regular body of work: paintings, installations, site specific works. These works are my voice, my life and love and I have to keep them going. A contribution to my ability to finish the first phase of The Last American Indian On Earth as well as the continued effort of my gallery work not only keeps my work going, but keeps my family going as well. The life of a full time working artist often ebbs and flows, and that is why your contribution is so vastly important. The goals behind The Last American Indian On Earth are the following:

  • Short film (planning to submit to Sundance for 2014)
  • Prints for Gallery work
  • Continued performance opportunities
  • Various short films for online consumption AFTER initial afore mentioned short film

So, what I need is....

Money to cover small things, which add up. In terms of The Last American Indian On Earth, this cost amounts to various amounts of the following:

  • taxis
  • gas
  • food
  • crew support
  • equipment support
  • fees for submission and accolades

Costs of personal work by Gregg Deal amounts to various amounts of the following:

  • Paint
  • canvas
  • wood
  • other materials (paper, paste, photocopies, stencil materials, etc.)

While all of this is important, The Last American Indian is dire as there are deadlines in place for the short film and it's submision. Nevertheless, the funds all go into the continued production of The Last American Indian On Earth AND the continued production of work for upcoming gallery shows and presentations.

Why the hell should I give you anything....

You shouldn't. At least you shouldn't if you don't believe in me or what I am doing. Ultimately this comes down to people supporting me and my work. It's not just about pressing 'like' on Facebook, or ReTweeting an image I posted on the Internet. It's about putting your money where your mouth is. If you appreciate and support, you can throw in a buck. If you really want to make an inpact, you can buy one of my pieces or pass the link onto like minded friends or family to support this important work.

The voice of my work is incredibly important as it speaks with a true voice of an Indigenous person. My work comments on the social aspects of being Indian in the modern day with a tone of humor and irony. In everything I do, be it paintings or performance art, I confront the viewer with imagery that forces consideration and often works as a mirror to the viewer, illustrating their understanding, their thoughts and feelings and willing interaction with Indigenous people, statements, icons, and images. As a Native person, this ist the most important work I have ever done. If you can believe in that and stand behind that, then support me. I am in the middle of shooting The Last American Indian On Earth with photography and video as well as in my studio creating new visual art for future shows later this fall. It's looking pretty epic overall.

How can I help...

Obviously you can contribute to this Indiegogo. That's probably the biggest thing. But there are other ways too. I'll list them below:

  • indiegogo campaign
  • Buy some of my personal work
  • Pass along this link to others

NOTHING is too big or too small. I am appreciative of all of it. I know that everything makes a difference. EVERYTHING.

story:
Short Summary

Summary

A unique collaboration between the YMCA of the Triangle and Crosspointe Church will broaden service to northwest Cary – the fastest growing region in the state. Crosspointe Church is raising funds to build a 130,000 square foot facility that will provide expanded space for the church. The YMCA of the Triangle will lease space to operate a new YMCA.

Although financing is in place, a fundraising effort to raise $12.5M to help service the debt was recently announced to the church congregation. Donation commitments from church members total approximately $9.8M. Opportunities are now open to assist in raising the additional $2.7M needed to reach the goal through THE WHY Project  (thewhyproject.net).

Mission

A hundred years ago, churches were commonly known for building hospitals, schools, universities, and community centers that served their surrounding neighbors rather than constructing buildings that only served their own purposes. The congregation at Crosspointe Church wants to recapture some of that history. 

Impact and Benefits to the Community

The facility will benefit the community through increased activities for teens, families and adults. The facility is expected to serve as a hub for the community and provide nearly 200 jobs.

Location

The facilitywill be located on 19 acres owned by the church at 6911 Carpenter Fire Station Rd., Cary N.C.

Sustainable Building Highlights

·  Trees cleared for construction will be milled and used as building material for the project

·  Dirt excavated for construction will be used in landscaping the property

·  New vegetation will be primarily fruit and vegetable plants

·  Food harvested from these plants will be used in the food court and teaching kitchens

·  All profits from the food court will be donated to local charities

Specifications

·  Existing building – The church currently meets in 34,500 square feet of space that will be renovated and expanded during construction, with space for future expansion without new construction.

·  Total space – Total interior space following construction will be 130,000 square feet

·  Y space – Initially, the Y will lease 80,000 square feet of interior space and 27,000 square feet of outdoor space for swimming pools and sports fields.

·  Parking – Existing lots will be expanded by two acres, with another four acres reserved for future expansion.

·  Road improvements – Crosspointe Church is financing $1.5M for 1,500 linear feet of roadway expansion around the property to ease the impact of increased traffic.

·  Permits – On November 20 2014, the Cary Town Council 8-0 to approve a rezoning request to allow the YMCA’s commercial development on the property. A Land-Use-Revision permit is pending, with approval expected in early 2015.

·  Groundbreaking – Early 2015 for parking expansion.

·  Construction commencement – Spring 2015

·  Completion – January 2017

Statements of Purpose and Support

“In the spirit of working together and loving our city, we, as Crosspointe, are taking on the responsibility of raising the necessary funds to design and build a state-of-the-art YMCA on our property for the people of northwest Cary that we will lease back to the YMCA of the Triangle to lead and operate independent of the church. To our shared knowledge, this isn’t something that has been done before, but we’re hopeful it becomes paradigm shifting in our city and across the country for how people and organizations can come together to do more than they could separately.”

Jonathan Bow, lead pastor of Crosspointe Church

“This collaboration is the result of a big dream to serve everyone in our community. We know that by partnering with Crosspointe Church, we can do so much more together. This partnership will have a ripple effect across the region. We are excited to serve with others to make a transformational impact on our community.”

Tracey Howe, COO of the YMCA of the Triangle

“We talk to citizens all the time about the value of giving back to the community helping to build it. I just look at this as the most innovative and exciting collaborative effort we have seen. I just think that it’s very exciting, and I’m just so impressed. I met with the church to hear about it. I left there just thinking the members of this church just get it. They get the idea of giving back and ministering to our community in the most relevant way possible. We always used to throw around the word remarkable; I think this is a remarkable collaboration.” 

Jennifer Robinson, Cary Town Council
story_txt:
Short Summary 
Summary
A unique
collaboration between the YMCA of the Triangle and Crosspointe Church will
broaden service to northwest Cary – the fastest growing region in the state.
Crosspointe Church is raising funds to build a 130,000 square foot facility
that will provide expanded space for the church. The YMCA of the Triangle will
lease space to operate a new YMCA. 
Although
financing is in place, a fundraising effort to raise $12.5M to help service the
debt was recently announced to the church congregation. Donation commitments
from church members total approximately $9.8M. Opportunities are now open to
assist in raising the additional $2.7M needed to reach the goal through THE WHY
Project  (thewhyproject.net).
Mission
A hundred years ago, churches were commonly known
for building hospitals, schools, universities, and community centers that
served their surrounding neighbors rather than constructing buildings that only
served their own purposes. The congregation at Crosspointe Church wants to
recapture some of that history. 
Impact
and Benefits to the Community
The
facility will benefit the community through increased activities for teens,
families and adults. The facility is expected to serve as a hub for the
community and provide nearly 200 jobs.

Location
The
facilitywill be located on 19 acres
owned by the church at 6911 Carpenter Fire Station Rd., Cary N.C.
Sustainable Building Highlights
· 
Trees
cleared for construction will be milled and used as building material for the
project
· 
Dirt
excavated for construction will be used in landscaping the property
· 
New
vegetation will be primarily fruit and vegetable plants
· 
Food
harvested from these plants will be used in the food court and teaching
kitchens
· 
All
profits from the food court will be donated to local charities

Specifications
· 
Existing building – The church currently meets
in 34,500 square feet of space that will be renovated and expanded during
construction, with space for future expansion without new construction.
· 
Total space – Total interior space following
construction will be 130,000 square feet
· 
Y space – Initially, the Y will
lease 80,000 square feet of interior space and 27,000 square feet of outdoor space
for swimming pools and sports fields.
· 
Parking – Existing lots will be
expanded by two acres, with another four acres reserved for future expansion.
· 
Road improvements – Crosspointe Church is
financing $1.5M for 1,500 linear feet of roadway expansion around the property
to ease the impact of increased traffic.
· 
Permits – On November 20 2014, the
Cary Town Council 8-0 to approve a rezoning request to allow the YMCA’s
commercial development on the property. A Land-Use-Revision permit is pending,
with approval expected in early 2015.
· 
Groundbreaking – Early 2015 for parking expansion.
· 
Construction commencement – Spring 2015
· 
Completion – January 2017
Statements of Purpose and Support
“In the spirit of working together and loving our city, we, as
Crosspointe, are taking on the responsibility of raising the necessary funds to
design and build a state-of-the-art YMCA on our property for the people of
northwest Cary that we will lease back to the YMCA of
the Triangle to lead and operate independent of the church. To our shared knowledge,
this isn’t something that has been done before, but we’re hopeful it becomes
paradigm shifting in our city and across the country for how people and
organizations can come together to do more than they could separately.” 
Jonathan Bow, lead pastor of Crosspointe Church

“This collaboration is the result of a big dream to serve everyone in
our community. We know that by partnering with Crosspointe Church, we can do so
much more together. This partnership will have a ripple effect across the
region. We are excited to serve with others to make a transformational impact
on our community.”
Tracey Howe, COO of the YMCA of the Triangle
“We talk to citizens all the
time about the value of giving back to the community helping to build it. I
just look at this as the most innovative and exciting collaborative effort we
have seen. I just think that it’s very exciting, and I’m just so impressed. I
met with the church to hear about it. I left there just thinking the members of
this church just get it. They get the idea of giving back and ministering to
our community in the most relevant way possible. We always used to throw around
the word remarkable; I think this is a remarkable collaboration.”  
Jennifer
Robinson, Cary Town Council

story:
IMPRESSIONS Art Project

by FRÉDÉRIC LAGO

HOW TO RECEIVE BY MAIL A COLLECTION OF 7 PHOTOGRAPHIC BOOKS

OU COMMENT RECEVOIR PAR LA POSTE UNE COLLECTION DE 7 LIVRETS PHOTOGRAPHIQUES


concept

7 books. 7 fragments. Each of them is an imprint, and together they will draw the outlines, will print the traces of a perception of the inner world. During the year, you will receive your choice of limited edition signed books (see column for options). Books 1(March), Book 2(April), Book 3(May), Book 4(June), Book 5(September), Book 6(October), Book 7(November).


7 livrets. 7 fragments. Chacun d’eux étant une empreinte et, ensemble, ils dessineront les contours, imprimeront les traces d’une perception du monde intime. Pendant l’année, vous recevrez selon votre choix de contribution (voir tableau ci-contre) les livrets en édition numérotée, signée. Les livrets 1 à 4 seront expédiés respectivement en mars, avril, mai et juin 2015. Suivront les livrets 5 à 7 de septembre à novembre 2015. 


format

The books will be 8.5 x 5.5 inches with 7 photos / 16 pages (numbered and signed editions) on mat paper. They will be manufactured and printed by a Montreal company.

Les livrets seront de format 8,5 x 5,5 pouces comprenant 7 photos / 16 pages (éditions numérotés et signées) sur papier mat.  Ils seront fabriqués et imprimés au Québec, par une compagnie montréalaise.

contribution

Your contribution will help to cover the cost of paper, printing and mailings. Depending on your participation - see column contributions - you will receive in addition to books postcards and/or reproductions of works taken from the 7 series.

Votre contribution aidera à couvrir les frais de papier, d’impression et des envois postaux. Dépendant de votre participation - voir colonne des contributions - vous recevrez en plus des livrets, des cartes et/ou des reproductions grand format d’oeuvres extraites des 7 séries.


About me - My work

Born in 1974 in Sète (France). Works and lives in Montreal (Canada). I develop my artistic research through different mediums: photography, scanning, drawing, and more recently performance. Fragments, pieces : This is my vision of a portraitor a self-portrait. I like to let the viewer imagine what he does not see.
Né en 1974 à Sète (France). Vis et travaille à Montréal (Canada). Je développe ma recherche artistique à travers différents médiums: photographie, numérisation, dessin, et plus récemment la performance. Fragments, morceaux : C'est ma vision du portrait, de l'autoportrait. J'aime laisser le spectateur imaginer ce qu'il ne voit pas.


You could see more here : http://flintime.tumblr.com/

FLINTIME or how to appoach the intimacy in photographic form and on a daily basis.

Vous pouvez consulter mon travail ici : http://flintime.tumblr.com/

FLINTIME ou comment aborder l'ex-timité sous forme photographique et de manière journalière.

story:
The language of art is universal and the conversation powerful. That said I am
committed to making a strong contribution to the dialogue.

As a little girl, I was introduced to the historic artist colony of Rockport, Massachusetts. Yearly visits and gallery walks proved inspirational. A rock, that I found there as a child, continues to fuel my artistic vision. Throughout the years, it functioned many times as a drawing model and remains a symbol of my rock solid artistic conviction. It is no wonder that the first item on my bucket list is to open a gallery space in Rockport. Presently, I am on the precipice of realizing this goal. 

Creating a space to showcase local art and institute art education programs is important in terms of substance, depth and significance.  It will aid in revitalizing this historic artist colony, and in doing so, augment conversations important to our world and how we operate within it. Affordable gallery space in Rockport is a rare commodity these days. Gallery 19 will provide local artisans the opportunity to share their work and join inspiring conversations. 

Suffice it to say, I am between a rock and an art place. I could sure use your help!

Essential needs:

  • Pedestals = $12,000
  • Lighting = $4,000
  • Shelving = $5,000
  • Flooring = $3,200
  • Educational program development = $3,000

            All gifts will be divided to cover these costs. 

Gift acknowledgements:

  • Rock solid thanks and gratitude
  • Gallery certificate
  • Engraved nameplate on a plaque in the gallery
  • Recognized sponsorship of educational programs
Get onboard...gift, share or just post a note of encouragement...together we can create a wave of artistic activity! Thank you for spending this time with me and for your kind consideration.

story:
Greetings Friends,    

The Labor movement needs your help to preserve a magnificent work of  history, the Haymarket Martyrs Monument at Forest Home cemetery in Forest Park, IL. The monument was erected in 1893 and honors the working-class heroes who sacrificed their lives in the Haymarket tragedy of 1886. The monument stands as a shrine to free speech and the right to assemble and present grievances as guaranteed in the 1st amendment. The graves of Lucy Parsons, Emma Goldman and over 100 other progressives are buried in the shadow of the Martyrs.

In the 1980's, the laurel wreaths were stolen from the front of the monument. In 2011, the Illinois Labor History Society hired Andrzej Dajnowski, a master conservator and for $55,000 the laurel wreaths were beautifully recreated. Were a mold of the wreaths to have existed prior to the theft, the replacement cost would have been $6,000.

On the back of the monument  is an intricately decorated bronze plaque. On that plaque Gov. John Peter Altgeld states that the trial of the Haymarket martyrs was not fair and grants an absolute pardon to the three remaining martyrs.

Our campaign is to raise money to create a mold of this plaque. Were this piece of the monument to be stolen, a mold would ensure the affordable replacement of the plaque. Please look at the proposal and see what your contribution can accomplish. We need five thousand, four hundred dollars to create the mold.

All contributions are most welcome.

It is exciting to see people coming from around the world to visit this monument--leaving flowers, buttons and coins.

We all need to preserve the integrity of the Haymarket monument for generations to come so that it can be enjoyed by all. Be a part of labor history and pitch in today.

The Illinois Labor History Society is a not-for-profit organization. Allcontributions are tax deductible and will go directly to the preservation of the plaque.

-Mark Rogovin, on behalf of the Illinois Labor History Society

story:
About the Campaign

Goal: Expand Potters gALLErY in downtown Jamestown with seven additional pieces of student artwork from Jamestown High School.   

Downtown Jamestown’s scenic alleys are a memorable part of the city’s urban landscape. Potters Alley, in particular, offers pedestrians dramatic views of downtown’s sloping topography and a unique perspective on dozens of historic buildings.  

Since 2010, the Jamestown Renaissance Corporation and numerous partners have worked to turn Potters Alley between 3rd and 4th Streets into a showcase for artwork by talented local students. By turning the alley and adjacent areas into a more colorful and interesting space through public art, the project has sought to encourage greater pedestrian use of the alley and to make downtown a more dynamic visual experience for residents and visitors.

Through the fall of 2011, 35 pieces of art by students from Jamestown High School and Jamestown Community College were added to wall surfaces along Potters Alley. In 2012, additional pieces were added to the south wall of Mason Fine Arts, serving as a visual bridge between Potters Alley and North Main Street. In 2013, the gallery jumped across Main Street to Winter Garden Plaza, the host site of Third Thursday summer concerts. In all, 56 pieces of art now comprise Potters gALLErY and its extensions.

To expand the gallery further, seven new pieces have been selected by faculty at Jamestown High School. Those pieces are earmarked for installation at Winter Garden Plaza, beneath the row of artwork installed in 2013.

Numerous partners have contributed to the Potters gALLErY project since 2009, including the Jamestown Renaissance Corporation, Jamestown High School, Jamestown Community College, the Active Artists Alliance, Mason Fine Arts, Vacanti’s Extreme Signs, Volt Vision, and the Gebbie Foundation.

Now your help is needed to expand the gallery and continue a project that is helping to integrate the work of talented young artists into downtown Jamestown’s revitalization.   


The Impact

The 2014 expansion of Potter gALLErY will cost $6,300, which includes high-quality digital printing onto durable material, framing of the prints, and installation onto the wall adjacent to Winter Garden Plaza.

The Jamestown Renaissance Corporation is seeking to raise one-third of that amount -- or $2,100 -- through this crowdfunding campaign to enable the expansion by mid-September and demonstrate public support for artwork in downtown Jamestown.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a financial contribution at this time please consider copying and pasting the link to this campaign and sharing with your friends and family through email and social media.

 

The Artwork

The following are the seven pieces selected by arts faculty at Jamestown High School for the gallery expansion.

Sea Turtle by Kate Tucker (paper mosaic)

A Dog Day Afternoon by Brayton Lydell (digital photograph)

Self-portrait by Jacqueline Southwell (oil on canvass paper)

Dolphin Stained Glass Window Painting by Jessica Pace (tempera)

Color Design by Jakira Maisonet (tempera)


Basquiat-style Diptych 1 by Alex Harvey (tempera)

Basquiat-style Diptych 2 by Alex Harvey (tempera)

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Tanya Davis and I live in Austin, Texas. My art varies between sculpture, illustration and jewelry. Three years ago I began making Steampunk'd Buddies with polymer clay. I have made owls, whales, turtles, ducks, bears, and pigs. At the beginning of 2013 I branched out into vinyl toy customization. The vinyl figurines have been a great deal of fun to work with and I hope to explore using more platforms.

This year has been an exciting one and I hope to go out with a BANG with one final 2013 show on December 6th.

This is where I need your help. I am most grateful for all the wonderful support that you have shown. 

What is Needed & What You Get

The funds will go towards:

  • Printing of the stickers and art prints.  
  • Display stands for the show.
  • Paint for the display stands
  • Clay for the Steampunk'd Buddies
  • Metal finding and accents for the Steampunk'd Buddies
  • Blank Google Droids for customization.
  • Packaging for all pieces.
  • Fees for any unsold tickets, lighting and transportation costs.

The money will also go towards ensuring my clay and paint stocks are not depleted after preparing for this show so that the base cost of the perks is covered. 

This will also give me a solid launch for 2014 which will include a new and improved website, new business cards, and of course more shows!

Now, for the PERKS. 

Perk 1: You are AWESOME, and I will tell everyone how awesome you are on both my Facebook and Google+ pages!

Perk 2: STICKERS. Because stickers are cool and who doesn't love to slap some stickers down. The TDA sticker was designed for me by MBcustomtoys. The horse will be a brand new addition to my sticker pack included first with this perk.

 

Perk 3: Art Print or Steampunk'd Heart Necklace and you get the sticker pack too!

Steampunk'd Hearts. These are made with polymer clay and are approximately 1.5 inches x 1.5 inches in size. **Hearts will be ready in time to ship for Valentines Day!**

   

5 inch x 7 inch fine art prints

    

Perk 4: Steampunk'd Turtle! I make each of these by hand and they never come out the same way twice! You also get the sticker pack and a choice of print or necklace.


       

Perk 5: Customized Google Android and the sticker pack. You will also have a choice of two prints, two necklaces or a combo of one print and one necklace. 

  

You get to choose the base color of your droid. The customized droids may have similar colors but each is a little different from the last. 

Perk 6: Steampunk'd Buddy!!!! Choose from a whale, duck, devil duck, owl, bear or pig. These are examples of what they would look like. There are no two alike. You will be able to choose the base color for your piece. This Perk will include the sticker pack, two prints (your choice) and a heart necklace. 

                                         

                       

                                   

The Impact

The show is being hosted by the RAWartsts Organization. They help support artists as they begin their career. I have participated in two of their shows so far and this will be my third. 

December 6th, 2013 is the date of the show. This is one of the biggest shows of the year where we find out who the semi-finalists are for the RAWards.  I have been chosen as one of the Director Highlights this year. 

With your help I can make this the best one yet!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with friends, family, neighbors and complete strangers! Use the Indiegogo share tools! They make sharing simple.

story:
What is Harmony Project DC?

The Harmony Project was founded in Los Angeles in 2001 as a gang-reduction music engagement program to provide young people with free musical instruments, training, and instruction. What began with 36 students has now grown to more than 1,300, and we want to keep that momentum growing by adding a chapter right here in DC. Our efforts are being motivated by the Do Good Challenge at the University of Maryland, College Park.

Give Music. Change Lives.

The funds we raise before April 6th, 2014 will go toward start-up costs such as musical instruments for future Harmony Project DC students. Any amount, from $5 to $50 or more, will go a long way toward bringing music and all its benefits into the life of a DC child.

If we are able to meet our goal and win the Do Good Challenge, we will receive an additional $5,000 for Harmony Project DC. Please help us reach this key goal!

The Harmony Project Approach

The Harmony Project’s approach to youth development is research-based and views youth issues from a public health perspective. Studies have demonstrated that arts programming may have the most profound and enduring positive impact on youth outcomes, even compared to other extracurricular activities. Arts education has been shown even to change the way in which children’s brains develop, and engagement in the arts prompts students to be more active in other areas of learning as well. Harmony Project programming is held after school because that has been shown to be most high-risk time for youth. Harmony Project has received a number of awards in recognition of its work, including the 2009 Coming Up Taller Award. Through Harmony Project DC, we aim to bring this successful model to the Washington region and adapt it to fit local needs and resources.

"Kids will always rise to the level of your expectation. You've just got to have great expectations." - Dr. Margaret Martin, founder of Harmony Project LA

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, your efforts to spread the word about Harmony Project DC and the value of music education will bring us closer to our goal. Thank you for your support!

story:
Short Summary

  • These days if you have some extra money lying around you can buy a state-of-the-art camera and call yourself a professional photographer. Maybe even read a photography blog or two or buy an ebook.  Photography has been sold to the lowest bidder and the ART of photography forgotten amongst the general public.  I want to change that. 

    I consider myself blessed to know and work with a group of talented and driven photographers.  As a group we elevate each other's creativity, passion and innovation. Thats why I am starting The Orange County Photography Collective. 

    But Hey! We need a gallery for a home base! That's where you come in!

    The Orange County Photography Collective will specialize in fine art photography for purchase,  and also provide a slew of photography services like wedding, newborn, portraits, real estate/architectural, yoga, travel, product, music and fashion photography. Since everyone within the Collective has their strengths, we will be able to cross promote between the members to provide the absolute best product for our clientele.

    The gallery will also be a studio space and workspace where we can come together to work, spend time with friends and bring a strong fine art photography presence to Laguna Beach, Ca!

    We will also be offering photography workshops AND we intend to give back to our men and women who have served this county bravely by offering FREE portrait sessions for our veterans.

What We Need & What You Get

Of course there will be some potential obstacles along the way! Finding the right spot in the right part of Laguna is tough… and space comes at a premium so I want to keep overhead manageable. 

Also, this is my first time running a business but I assume we will have startup costs including but not limited to printing, framing, insurance, installation costs, furniture, and of course the all important marketing and advertising so people know we have arrived! 

We've set up some perks as a heartfelt thank you for helping us get started.  These include official OCPC gear, a framed piece from the gallery, a photo session and even a party! Gotta have a party right!?

The Impact

  • Does Laguna Beach need a gallery dedicated to local Orange County Photographers? 

    A resounding YES!

    This is why:

    Laguna Beach is one of the premiere west coast artist communities. Artists (local and worldwide) come here to show and sell their work. Paintings, sculpture, jewelry, hand crafted goods, and mixed media works of art are plentiful.  HOWEVER… there is a minimal photography presence in Laguna Beach.

    There are a few galleries who include some fine art photography but mostly focus on painting and sculpture. These are Artists Eye, BC Space, Wassman Fine Arts, Townly Gallery, Laguna Gallery of Contemporary Art, Forest & Ocean Gallery, Jo Anne Artman and Sandstone

    There are also individual, more established photographers who run their own studios in Laguna. These are, but not limited to, Clark Little (surf photography), Cheyne Walls (in the canyon), Russ Sanders Photography (surf and beach photography), Rob Gage (advertising) and Mark Timothy (North Coast Hwy).... Plus the various freelance wedding/portrait/lifestyle photographers with or without studio/ gallery space.

    This presents a UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY to show unestablished, innovative, up and coming Orange County photographers who do not have a presence in Laguna.... AND create an opportunity for the 3 million annual visitors to see MULTIPLE PHOTOGRAPHER'S WORK ALL IN ONE SPACE!

    One of my favorite photographers, Henri Cartier-Bresson, said “To photograph is to hold one's breath, when all faculties converge to capture fleeting reality. It's at that precise moment that mastering an image becomes a great physical and intellectual joy.”  Photography is that joy for me… help me share it with you. Thanks.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate then share!

Share this campaign with friends, family, co-workers… friends of friends, strangers, the mailman-- it doesn't matter! We appreciate you getting the word out for us!
