story:
Help bring the Bleachers back to the playa! Join us as we cart nearly 100 people on the spectating journey of their dreams throughout Burning Man. Check out how much fun you can have with us in the video! 


Hi there! Remember The Bleachers? With the help of a ton of awesome people, we had a kickass first year. Got listed as a successful project, made a lot of people laugh, and gave a ton of hugs. 

https://www.fest300.com/magazine/7-existential-art-cars-br-at-burning-man-2013

While we're taking care of a lot of the expenses for getting back in 2014, there are still a few others we're hoping you can help us with.  These costs break down as follows:

1.  Structural Maintenance/Repairs (Support Beams, Cab/Body repairs) : $400

2.  Mechanical Maintenance/Repairs (New Batteries, Air Filter, Oil Change): $250

3. Generator Rental: $300

4. Sound Rental/Transport: $850

5. Storage: $1500/yr

6. Sexy Scoreboard: $850

7. Insurance: $1500

The total costs of the above ends up around $5,650 - with various other expenses incurred that we're taking care of. At this time we're only looking to raise $3,000 because we had some funds left over from last year, and because we're putting a nice chunk of our own bucks into making this thing a reality.

If this is your first time seeing our project, here's what we're here to do:

1. Serve as a recursive joke, putting the oft-maligned act of spectating on its head. A platform to turn Spectators into Participants, and Participants into Spectators. Because when someone plops down to spectate with us, to cheer and laugh and separate themselves from the action, they immediately become an active participant and a creator themselves. They prove that observing, understanding and commenting on art are valuable and potentially hilarious pursuits, with a vitality all their own.

2. Act as a roving stage for improvisational jokes, humor, and general tomfoolery. A place for you to take a break in style at the world's most insane and interactive art festival, unfettered by expectations of actually having to *do* anything, all while enrapt in absurdist play by play announcing and surrounded by people ready to embrace every bit of funny that you want to bring to the table.

The structure is about two and a half stories tall, and can carry 20,000 lbs of sexy spectators like yourself.


Thank you bunches, and we look forward to making jokes with you!

Here's our original video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=enOZgFr8ISI


- The Bleacher Team


This could be YOUR view at the burning of the Man! 

Check out the shit show from the highest perch! 

The Bleachers and friends...

story:
Look what the cat dragged in is conceived in response to the domestic interior of the house. The atmosphere of the space breathes upper-class, traditional heteronormative values and bourgeois decency. But how do we work with/respond to such a charged environment? The 20th-century French thinker Guy Debord coined the notion of détournement: the reworking of an existing cultural element familiar to the audience to give it an antagonistic meaning. Using this as a method, we invite the artists to confront and subvert this environment, and suggest new ways of dwelling and understanding the notion of “home”. Look what the cat dragged in will consist of two parts: an exhibition spread throughout the house and three evenings of performances that will take place in the main living room. 

Final list of artists and programme will be released soon!

 

The space

The event will take place in an old Georgian house located in the Pimlico area in West London. Almost like a time capsule of upper-class domestic life from the 1970s, but also bearing the marks of all its previous lives, the interior of the house remains in the same state as the old owner left it. In April 2019, renovation works will start, transforming the house entirely. Before this erasing of the ghosts of the past, the house with all its history is available as a space for artistic experimentation. It is precisely this environment, including all its ghosts, that was the starting point of this project for us.

 

The performance evenings

Inspired by the 18th-century French literary salons, we imagined the performance evenings as “radical salons” that will take place in the main living room over the 3 days. Each evening will consist of three performances by different artists. In between performances, there will be time for the audience to get a drink, view the exhibited works and have a conversation with the artists, curators and each other. In contrast to the traditional salon, with its strict set of social codes and etiquettes, the radical salon aims at inclusiveness and real intimacy. A setting where the audience can feel at home.

 

The exhibition

The exhibition will consist of a selection of artworks by a few different artists. These works will inhabit various rooms of the house, infiltrating the space to expose its normative power. The audience will be invited to wander around the house to discover it in-between the performances.

 

What We Need 

Your support is essential for this project to happen since its access will be free. It will help us deliver the creative, qualitative, and ambitious project we imagine. In order to do so, we need a minimum of 785£, which we have budgeted as follows:

  • Production costs: £400

    This will cover the basic production costs for the installation of artworks and compensate for performance artists’ material costs.

  • Travel compensation: £100

    This will fund return train tickets to London for artists living in other regions of the UK.

  • Drinks and Bites: £100

    In the spirit of a relaxed salon, drinks and bites will be available to the audience during and in-between performances.

  • Printing costs: £100

    This will cover the estimated printing costs of posters; as well as the leaflet/catalogue including texts by the curators, Guy Debord’s Users guide to Detournement, and creative texts by participating artists.

  • Indiegogo fee: £85

    This fee includes: the Indiegogo 5% fee on all flexible target campaigns, the Stripe 3% fee, and the £25 fixed fee for transferring the money outside of the US.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, it doesn't matter! There are other ways in which you can support us: 

  • Come to the event! Come look at the artworks, experience the performances and chat with the artists, curators, and crowd. 
  • Volunteer your time! For those of our lovely friends in London, we'll definitely need some helping hands before, during and after the event.
  • Spread the good word! Share this on all your social media.

 

Supported using public funding by the Arts Council England

story:
Short Summary

I am an eighth grader and I love drawing and dogs. Every year, I donate some money made from doing house chores to a dog charity. This year, I want to do more. Inspired by Entrepreneur Kids, I have decided to use my talent in art to create a 2018 Paw Calendar. 

What We Need & What You Get

I have set a goal to raise at least $1,000 from this campaign and donate 50% of the profit to humane society.

You will get:

  • Sweet virtual hug from my beloved dog Twinkle
  • 2018 Paw Calendar with adorable puppies of different breeds that I have drawn for each month with fascinating fun facts about the breed
  • For Ultimate backers, I will also design a personalized Christmas card for each one of you

The Impact

Dogs are human's loyal friends. 2018 is the year of Dog. To me, there is no better way to show my appreciation of dogs by creating this Paw Calendar. 

Inspired by Entrepreneur Kid, I have decided to use my talent in art to do something for dogs. I drew all the pictures, researched on fun facts about each breed, got helpers to record a video, studied online marketing, and of course, set up Indiegogo campaign. My younger sister Angela also co-starred the video and committed to promote the campaign together with me . This is the first time that we are doing this. It is definitely not easy, but it is totally fun! We really enjoy it! 

I sincerely invite you to back our campaign. You are not only supporting my first business, but also doing something amazing for dogs. 

Risks & Challenges

We have designed the calendar and ordered sample copies from Office Depot already. You can see the samples in the video. We have borrowed $600 from our parents to place the initial order of calendars. So at this point of time, our biggest risk is if we are unable to sell the calendars, we need to find ways to make enough money to pay back our parents. We will probably have to work harder on house chores everyday then. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand there are many campaigns out there competing for your support. No matter if you will directly back our campaign or not, could you please share our campaign on social media to spread the word for us? Thank you!

story:
I am a second generation American painter and artist born and raised in Los Angeles, California. My work has been exhibited in museums, galleries and showrooms and is represented in a number of private collections. Originally trained in a classical, realistic style. I was mentored at an early age by my father, Chet Marshall and raised within a family of artists. While still in elementary school I was introduced to the LA mural culture by working with Jane Golden on the Santa Monica "Muir Woods" in 1978 which left a lasting impression on me.

About a year ago I was asked if I would be willing to donate a mural to a children's park in the city of Hawthorne. Since then I began working  diligently on the sketches, designs and presentations for the mural and painted a maquette or small version of what the mural would look like on a 80" x 30" canvas.  Painting this mural gives me an opportunity to share my joy and experience of painting with children, their families and passersby in the park.  

What We Need

Excited that the city and surrounding neighbors have approved my mural proposal  I am ready to put the mural into production. Production and painting of the mural is scheduled to begin August 16, 2017 but I need your help. In order to cover all of the production expenses required to make this mural a reality we need to raise $2000. This amount will be used for paint, brushes, tarps and all supplies needed to complete this project. I am personally donating an estimated 25 - 30 hours to paint the mural on the 40 foot by 9 foot wall facing the children's park.

Exciting Rewards

There are some exciting rewards for becoming involved with the " Good Neighbors" mural project. Special edition giclee prints of the mural maquette as well as having your name included in a special dedication on the mural itself.

Spread The Word

Even if you cannot financially support the project, I would be grateful if you can help me spread the word on your favorite social media sites.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any kind of paint or painting supplies that you can donate would be beneficial and greatly appreciated.

As always, for any donations made a receipt can be offered for tax purposes.

I am personally donating an estimated 25 - 30 hours to paint the mural on the 40 foot by 9 foot wall facing the children's park.



Exciting Rewards
There are some exciting rewards for becoming involved with the " Good Neighbors" mural project. Special edition giclee prints of the mural maquette as well as having your name included in a special dedication on the mural itself.

Spread The Word
Even if you cannot financially support the project, I would be grateful if you can help me spread the word on your favorite social media sites.

Other Ways You Can Help
Any kind of paint or painting supplies that you can donate would be beneficial and greatly appreciated.
As always, for any donations made a receipt can be offered for tax purposes.

story:
For the most update info and lots of pictures: https://www.facebook.com/PlayaBeest/



A quick note about or goal: $7500 was my minimum goal to ensure I didn't go too far into debt on this project. I knew up front the total cost will be closer to $15,000.

As of September 9th, we've logged many hundreds of volunteer hours and I've spent over $13,700 on materials. Anyone can still contribute to the campaign and claim any of our awesome perks until we break even and stop accepting donations. We'd also love to upgrade the paint beyond primer, add some LEDs, maybe some speakers, etc. So please keep the love flowing and keep spreading the word about this awesome project!

Inspired by Strandbeests, the original dream machines of artist Theo Jansen, the PlayaBeest will be a 10ft tall, steel, pedal-powered walking machine weighing over 1500lbs that that will be unleashed on Black Rock City at Burning Man 2016!



The key science behind these incredible creatures is the geometry of the leg mechanism. Each leg has 11 segments defined by  13 dimensions that allow the sculptures to glide smoothly across the earth.  Jansen aptly refers to these "13 holy numbers" as the Strandbeests' genetic code.


Jansen released this "genetic code" out into the wild with the hopes that others would continue the evolution of the Strandbeest by making their own creatures in their own vision.

We've decided to take on this challenge by designing, building, and bringing some kinetic, interactive art to Burning Man 2016!

Additionally, we love making kick-ass things we can ride on, especially big, iconic and beautiful things that can be shared amongst our community to enjoy.  Just checkout Nate’s last project where he set a world record flight at Red Bull Flugtag in 2013!

Bringing the PlayaBeest to life requires over 2000lbs of steel, and hundreds of bearings, bolts and nuts.  At the bare minimum, we need to raise $13,700 to cover the cost of materials.  If we exceed our goal we can help subsidize our transportation costs and potentially add some mind-bending lights and boss tunes to allow the PlayaBeest to roam around at night.



This project wouldn't be possible without your support. Check out our awesome list of perks we've come up with as a way to say thank you for your help. If you can't contribute money, please take a moment to share the campaign with your friends and family as every bit helps!

story:
About

For the last year, we have been working closely with talented artists of our community to put on a one of a kind exhibition spotlighting contemporary Assyrian art. Our goal is to take a step forward, highlight the present over the ancient, and celebrate contemporary Assyrian artists whose work developed out of a significant and difficult history.

The show title references an Assyrian idiom, “Spring does not occur with one flower alone.” In other words: a movement does not occur with just one person - it takes a field of flowers to bloom in order for Spring to arrive. Diaspora in Bloom brings together the works of a nation that has been scattered around the globe, and has still found a way to blossom into a movement.

History seeped through the cracks despite their best efforts, Esther Elia, 2018

Focusing on the Assyrian experience, over 30 works of art will be assembled in a variety of media including - photography, painting, video, posters, and graphic design. The exhibition offers a fresh approach to understanding this ancient culture and addresses universal themes of identity, community, diaspora, and cultural continuity. We are excited to be showcasing the work of many prominent artists such as Esther Elia, Atra Givarkes, Rabel Betshmuel.

Ancient Assyrian Patterns, Series 1, Rabel Betshmuel, 2016

Now, this is where you come in. 

We've worked tirelessly this past year finalizing the details of the show. From collaborating with artists, to visiting galleries across the Bay Area, to creating  a one-of-a-kind experience; we’ve done it all, and are on the verge of turning our research into reality. This is your chance to help make it real! 

Where is My Home, Atra Givarkes, 2016

You can bring Diaspora in Bloom to life by donating to this campaign and spreading the word to anyone who might be interested (tell a friend to tell a friend!). If you want to support the arts, or you want to help make ~dreams~ come true, then please consider contributing!

Sincerely, 

Akadina Yadegar & Nardin Sarkis

Project Curators 

 

Risks & Challenges

In order to appropriately execute our vision for this exhibition - we need to be fully funded in 30 days. We feel confident in executing our vision and in our ability to secure adequate partners to fund this project.

All funds will be used to bring this exhibit to fruition. Overhead costs include gallery rental, shipping artwork, travel expenses for artists, installation, & marketing.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us get the word out! Share our project with your friends, family, and network
  • Follow us for updates on instagram at @DiasporaInBloom
  • Volunteer to help us on the ground for exhibit events

story:
Short Summary

My Irish eyes are smiling at the thought of painting Ireland! Cill Rialaig is located on the Atlantic coast of Bellinskelligs, Ireland- a Gaelic speaking town, known for the Skellig Monks who called it "the nearest thing to heaven". Before my two week residency I will backpack the Kerry Camino, a pilgrimage trail in County Kerry close to where my paternal great grandmother was born. I hope this journey will fill my soul with narrative imagery to stimulate a rewarding residency.

Over the years I have attended a number of national and international residencies. These funding campaigns have always encouraged me as an artist; knowing there are friends, family, artists and art enthusiasts who understand the value of authentic experiences and focused residencies for my artistic work.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Brandon Reno and my senior project is called the Great Barrier Reef Re Imagined.

The Great Barrier Reef Re Imagined is a projector experience in which the audience can see all around them the effects of coral bleaching on the reef between the years of 1950- present day.

This will be done by recreating a section of the reef and animating a time-lapse of the created reef all in Maya. I will then take four different cameras and render four different scenes which will be put into a space in my university library that has 4 projectors, one on each wall, that will each project a different scene that was rendered.

What I Need & What You Get

I need approximately 500$ to help with the funding of getting photo-realistic plant and animal assets into my scene. This being my senior project I am on a time crunch to get as many assets as possible since I wont have time to model, rig and animate them myself.

Whats in it for you? You get to be apart of something that has never been done. a virtual experience of the effects of coral bleaching on the most beautiful reef our world has. 

***ALL CONTRIBUTORS WILL GET CREDIT DURING THE CREDITS OF THE PROJECT***

Impact

Your contribution will help create a never before seen experience where the audience walks into the sad decay of one of the greatest reefs. It will be an experience unlike anything else because you will be in the scene and mobile and able to move around and see everything going on.

Other Ways You Can Help

Still want to help but cant contribute? Tell a friend, spread the word or if you know of any free assets out there let me know!!

story:
So whats the deal?

So my buddy has been fighting a workers comp claim both in and out of courtrooms for going on 5 years now. In that time the nerve damage has progressed so far that instead of amputating his foot to stop the spread of the disease. Now the doctors are recommending he amputate the entire leg and even then he's only got a 50% chance that will stop the disease completely.

This is why a couple close friends and fellow artists decided we would do what we could to help out. As the costs for the amputation and the prosthetics will be upwards of 60k. Now I don't think this little sketchbook is going to get him there. But if we can sell a few books to help with costs then I think we can call this a small win towards the end goal.

The first revision of the book is submitted, published and ready to print. If we can make a stretch goal of 3k we will do a second revision before we ship out and add an additional 50 pages of works. With an additional stretch goal every additional 5k adding another 50 pages worth of content.

But if we don't hit the mark all the books will still print and ship out to their new owners. With all the funds going to printing, shipping, and the artists who contributed. With a large portion going to the severely talented Mr Bid to help him through this rough time in his life.

Most of us have never tried anything of this magnitude artistically and this is a huge step for us. So for anyone interested please show your support either by spreading the word, through the purchase of our book, or by donation. It all means the world to have you on board.

So the book is A5 (8.26x5.23) 60# weight on white paper with over 80 pages of concepts, illustrations, and creature designs.

<<Artists involved on Instagram>>

story:
Crosslances is an artistic reality consolidated for many years, we have dedicated ourselves very often to model making and playing miniatures in 28/32mm scale.

This time, however, we want to launch a completely different project, an absolute novelty, our original idea.

In fact, we want to make available to you these fantastic sculptures of ours, which can be printed directly at home, painted and placed inside your bookshelves to obtain stunning effects!

 

If you are a passionate reader, or if you simply think it could be the ideal gift for some of your friends, then you can miss this project!

           -if you already own a 3D printer, it's cheap and also funny, you will print unique and incredible quality models

-If you don't own a 3D printer, it can be an opportunity to buy one! Prices for a printer are already low and accessible to anyone. You can still use a service like: 3D hub, shapeways, or any other that are crowding on the net.

-No shipping cost! Anywhere in the universe, you just download the files and print!

-You can print it as many times as you want, for you and your friends.

-You can decide any printing dimension

 

PLEASE NOTE - This Kickstarter is for digital files (STLs) to make all these items on your own home 3D printer - these are not physical goods **

All models have been sculpted by experienced artists with the help of the Z-Brush program.

These models are designed to be printed without support.

But being complex sculptures it is very important to know how to drive your 3d printer very well.

Crosslances is committed, as always, to help our customers and always find a solution where there is a problem.


Here are our models made!

every sculpture has the possibility to build behind it a structure that allows you to support the books and that adapts to the depth you want.

This is possible with the use of three bars made in three different sizes: long, medium and short that will join to a bottom plate.

All to best adapt to your every need.

For all lovers of horror adventures and mystery tales we have made these two models!

The second series, with two other sculptures, is dedicated to the world of magic and fantasy.

Another series again, this time we go to the classic, entering the fantasy world of dragons and hobbits.

The fourth series projects us into the future, offering these two futuristic city scenarios

The last series is a bit different from the others, we dedicate it to cooking enthusiasts who love to keep their recipes in order!

**the images shown are 3D renderings that represent a simulation of what the final product might look like. Lights and colours are just examples of how to process these sculptures**.


During the campaign we hope to add more new models.

These will be available completely free of charge, along with related pledges.

We decided to create this dice holder (but actually you can put the most disparate objects in it) to create a crossover with a campaign by one of our customers and friends: labmasu.

The project includes a series of nice dice that we carved for Labmasu, and of course you can also find the stl version available.

Here's the link to the campaign, just drop by!

http://kck.st/2Rw6JTI

 

We have decided that the Christmas bookend will be free for all backers who will take a pledge of 5€ or more!

 

Hoping to give you a welcome early Christmas gift.

By buying the rights of these files you will be allowed to:

- print the 3D 

                 - print them for friends

                 - Print in 3D and resell the printed in 3D

                 - use render-prints and other byproducts of the file for promotional purposes.

                 - modify the file according to needs and educational purposes

                 - Modified byproducts files may be sold printed in 3D

                 -use the models as parts of a video game

 

Not allowed:

 

                 - Use the files to create molds for mass production

                 - sell the files for profit

                 - distribute the file to third parties

 

For non-granted points, please contact the study crosslances, with which you can find an agreement.

It is asked in addition to cite Crosslances Studios wherever possible.

For all the remaining details we stick to the creative common .

              Crosslances studios is founded by 3 artists and their commons passion for the world of games. Students at the Comics courses in Florence, made by the greebo games sculptures, they approached the world of miniatures. It has actually become a revelant studio in the world of miniatures and digital miniatures prototyping. Our products can be found in many places, we had collaborations with: Labmasu, Megalith Godslayer, Hidden Dreams, Minuteman miniatures, Fireforge , and many others.

Students at the Comics courses in Florence, made by the greebo games sculptures, they approached the world of miniatures. Our products can be found in many places, we had collaborations with: Labmasu, Megalith Godslayer, Hidden Dreams, Minuteman miniatures, Fireforge , and many others.

story:
Hello!!

I'm Clare, a Kent based artist, who's work primarily surrounds the colour pink.

I need YOU and YOUR HELP to make PINK! to become a reality.

PINK! is going to be a Kent based exhibition in Margate the home of the Turner Contemporary.

I also want to publish the book PINK! that I’ve been creating over the last year, inside it features critical discussions on the colour pink in art and society. As well as featuring the exhibition YOUR HELP will create.

 

WHY PINK?

I’ve gravitated to and from the colour pink. I’ve worked without colour and with many colours, but every time I gravitate back to the colour pink. It creeps into my unconsciousness. I decided to embrace the colour.

The colour pink is a colour without much discourse within art. 

You may find the odd article discussing ‘pink art’ although generally the only structural argument is based on the gender normativity of pink is for girls blue is for boys. 

There has never really been a discussion on the actuality of the colour. 

Pink as an emblem for girls, and Barbie in particular have helped to shape my work. During my childhood Barbie was my lifeline. I think she was for many girls my age and this odd feeling of nostalgia and love towards her as well as anger towards Barbie (although more towards Mattel) due to the objectification and unattainable standards created by Barbie, is to be honest – Sublime.

Working with the sublime, I started focusing on my perception of feminism and gender inequality surrounding my daughter and myself. I started to perceive the world differently, by removing my rose tinted view of the world I started to see even more pink and this imbalance is shown throughout my recent artwork from the limited palette.

This is something much bigger than myself, the colour pink has become to mean something much bigger than its primary context.

Pink is often seen as Vulgar or ‘kitschy, it is one of the most vehemently rejected colour of all which only underscores its unusual biologically based effectiveness.

More recently artists have used Pink as a tool and turn it into an conversation with so many different meanings.

I want to bring the discussion to the forefront, to look at the love of pink as well as the hatred of the colour.

I want to express the excessive nature of the colour, and ask the question why?

I want to open the discussion on the colour pink to different artists all over the world, and I want to combine them all in one place. 

Having an exhibition highlighting the colour Pink just before International Womens' Day is another great way of getting people interested in the discussion of what the colour has become to our society.

I need YOU and YOUR HELP to make this show become a reality.

I want to get artists from all over the world involved in this project, and this is where I NEED YOUR HELP!

 

I am asking YOU to submit work! 

 

If you are an artist and you want to submit your work please email me at

clarechapmanart@gmail.com

To me it is irrelevant when the work was produced, it could be recent or years ago, I don’t want to limit submissions. as long as your art is based around the colour PINK! please submit!!

What to send:

  • Artist Name
  • Artist Bio
  • Artist Statement
  • About the Piece/Pieces
  • Why you created the work
  • When you created the work
  • Size of the work
  • Price of work (if you wish to sell)

Please do understand that not all art submitted can be accepted, as the show needs to work as a whole.

So if your work doesn't get selected, PLEASE don't take that as a comment on your artistic ability.

I have secured the large ground-floor space of The Pie Factory for two weeks which means the exhibition will be easily accessible. The Pie Factory is right round the corner from the Turner Contemporary in the art hub of The Old Town.

In order to allow artists to purely concentrate on creating and submitting work which will fit the brief and inspire you, me and all of us in the process, I NEED YOUR HELP to pay for this project because if everybody puts in a little, we will all get a lot out of this!

Other costs will be for set up, taking down, returning art and the marketing of the exhibit, as well as for all the wonderful help I need to get this project up and running.

REWARDS

Small 3"x3" paintings.

 

Foam Frames - Limited Run

THE BOOK

Here is the contact sheet for the current plan of PINK! the book.
There will be a lot more over time as submissions roll in and the exhibition is underway.
I will keep you updated on PINK! the book as it unfolds with YOUR HELP!

PINK! will come to fruition, I will make this happen! It is already in motion,

It would be so much more powerful and available to the world if you would be a part of it!!

Thank you so much for taking your time to read this!

 

Lots of Love

Clare Chapman

xxx
story_txt:
Hello!!I'm Clare, a Kent based artist, who's work primarily surrounds the colour pink.I need YOU and YOUR HELP to make PINK! to become a reality.PINK! is going to be a Kent based exhibition in Margate the home of the Turner Contemporary.I also want to publish the book PINK! that I’ve been creating over the last year, inside it features critical discussions on the colour pink in art and society. As well as featuring the exhibition YOUR HELP will create. WHY PINK?I’ve gravitated to and from the colour pink. I’ve worked without colour and with many colours, but every time I gravitate back to the colour pink. It creeps into my unconsciousness. I decided to embrace the colour.The colour pink is a colour without much discourse within art. You may find the odd article discussing ‘pink art’ although generally the only structural argument is based on the gender normativity of pink is for girls blue is for boys. There has never really been a discussion on the actuality of the colour. Pink as an emblem for girls, and Barbie in particular have helped to shape my work. During my childhood Barbie was my lifeline. I think she was for many girls my age and this odd feeling of nostalgia and love towards her as well as anger towards Barbie (although more towards Mattel) due to the objectification and unattainable standards created by Barbie, is to be honest – Sublime.Working with the sublime, I started focusing on my perception of feminism and gender inequality surrounding my daughter and myself. I started to perceive the world differently, by removing my rose tinted view of the world I started to see even more pink and this imbalance is shown throughout my recent artwork from the limited palette.This is something much bigger than myself, the colour pink has become to mean something much bigger than its primary context.Pink is often seen as Vulgar or ‘kitschy, it is one of the most vehemently rejected colour of all which only underscores its unusual biologically based effectiveness.More recently artists have used Pink as a tool and turn it into an conversation with so many different meanings.I want to bring the discussion to the forefront, to look at the love of pink as well as the hatred of the colour.I want to express the excessive nature of the colour, and ask the question why?I want to open the discussion on the colour pink to different artists all over the world, and I want to combine them all in one place. Having an exhibition highlighting the colour Pink just before International Womens' Day is another great way of getting people interested in the discussion of what the colour has become to our society.I need YOU and YOUR HELP to make this show become a reality.I want to get artists from all over the world involved in this project, and this is where I NEED YOUR HELP! I am asking YOU to submit work!  If you are an artist and you want to submit your work please email me atclarechapmanart@gmail.comTo me it is irrelevant when the work was produced, it could be recent or years ago, I don’t want to limit submissions. as long as your art is based around the colour PINK! please submit!!What to send:
Artist Name
Artist Bio
Artist Statement
About the Piece/Pieces
Why you created the work
When you created the work
Size of the work
Price of work (if you wish to sell)
Please do understand that not all art submitted can be accepted, as the show needs to work as a whole.So if your work doesn't get selected, PLEASE don't take that as a comment on your artistic ability.I have secured the large ground-floor space of The Pie Factory for two weeks which means the exhibition will be easily accessible. The Pie Factory is right round the corner from the Turner Contemporary in the art hub of The Old Town.In order to allow artists to purely concentrate on creating and submitting work which will fit the brief and inspire you, me and all of us in the process, I NEED YOUR HELP to pay for this project because if everybody puts in a little, we will all get a lot out of this!Other costs will be for set up, taking down, returning art and the marketing of the exhibit, as well as for all the wonderful help I need to get this project up and running.REWARDSSmall 3"x3" paintings. Foam Frames - Limited RunTHE BOOKHere is the contact sheet for the current plan of PINK! the book.There will be a lot more over time as submissions roll in and the exhibition is underway.I will keep you updated on PINK! the book as it unfolds with YOUR HELP!PINK! will come to fruition, I will make this happen! It is already in motion,It would be so much more powerful and available to the world if you would be a part of it!!Thank you so much for taking your time to read this! Lots of LoveClare Chapmanxxx

story:
Introduction

The world has devolved into a state of chronic stress where families and governments alike are unable to resolve conflict. People are held hostage by stressors like violence, prejudice, abuse, neglect and addiction, amongst many others. Fear, confusion and anger – the manifestations of chronic stress – have become the norm.

Throughout human history, we have overcome this chronic stress with art. Be it the Neolithic cave paintings of the Stone Age or 20th century abstract expressionism, we have focused our creativity to peacefully share our experiences and ideas, becoming more aware and resilient.  

The smART Peace Prize

The smART Peace Prize is a global online arts movement competition inviting professional and amateur artists to use smart technology to create/capture and submit original artwork or writing. It beckons the artist within each person to create art that promotes awareness of and inspires action against human destructiveness.

An annual Grand Prize of US$20,000 will be awarded, and each month, selected semi-finalists will be given a promotional marketing campaign for their artwork.

The Impact

The beauty of today is anyone can create and share her art. All you need is your imagination, an idea and access to the Internet. 

The smART Peace Prize will be a lively global forum for creativity, and an inspiration exchange of thoughts and ideas. I invite participants from around the world to use social media and their smartphones to create and submit poetry, photos, drawings, paintings, videos and more. 

By promoting creativity and collaboration against human destruction − issues affecting personal mental/physical health, families, communities, cultures, economics, politics, religion and nature − smART has the potential to reduce the chronic stress and destructiveness built into our current way of life. 

Reaching the Goal

The smART Peace Prize is the culmination of more than 30 years of my work. To make my passion a globally shared one, I need to raise $200,000 to jumpstart the smART potential and launch the first round of The smART Peace Prize.

Any and all funding raised during this campaign will be used to:

  • Hire a small, part-time staff to help me with the management, marketing, coordination and judging of The smART Peace Prize; 
  • Start a prize money fund for competition finalists; and
  • Invest in future Prize needs, such as the development of a smart device application. 

How You Can Help

I do need your help to launch smART globally. So far, I have poured my own resources into this passion project, and to make sure that it has an effective, meaningful start -- and future growth -- any financial contribution you can make at this time is greatly appreciated. 

(And if you so choose, there are some great perks you can claim for your financial contribution! When applicable, claimed perks will be mailed once the campaign ends on February 28, 2014.)

If, however, you are unable to make a contribution at this time, there are other ways that you can invest in the smART potential:

  • You can spread the word about my campaign with your family, friends, colleagues and extended networks. Word-of-mouth would be extremely helpful in getting people to take notice of The smART Peace Prize and to participate!
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to ensure that my message reaches a wider audience via your social media networks. 
Whatever the form of your contribution, I value and appreciate your support!

About Me

My name is Phillip Romero, and I am a family psychiatrist and artist in New York City. 

In 1988, I developed Logosoma Brain Training, a methodology of creative resilience, which integrates:

  • The neuroscience of development and stress;
  • Meditation practice and Buddhist psychology-philosophy; and
  • Focused creativity for adaptive resilience to the adversities of life.

The smART Peace Prize is an extension of my initiative, Art Imperative Quest (AIQ), which explores the linkages between art and neuroscience. 

I launched The smART Peace Prize as a way of linking creativity on a global scale to face the escalating adversities that threaten cultural and environmental survival in the 21st century.

    I am also the Clinical Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Cornell Medical School, and I train Fellows in Child Psychiatry. 

    I have authored two books: The Art Imperative: The Secret Power of Art (2010) and Phantom Stress: Brain Training to Manage Relationship Stress (2010).

    As an extension of my work with AIQ and The smART Peace Prize, I am also the creator/producer of the upcoming documentary film, The Art Imperative Quest: Art = Survival (in progress).

story:
Hello, my name is Schnitzel and I’m a lettering artist!

My garage is not a place for fixing a motorbike or a car. It should be a studio and sign shop. It’s where I can work with enamel on wood and steel next to my digital workstation to do the best and most creative work. It should be a place where customers can come around and drink a coffee or a beer while talking about the job. It’s where everybody who is interested in arts and culture is welcome.

Hallo, ich heiße Schnitzel und bin Schriftkünstler!

Meine Garage soll keine reine Unterstellmöglichkeit für ein Auto oder Motorrad oder was auch immer sein – meine Garage wird ein Atelier für Schrift sein in dem ich mit Farben auf allen möglichen Materialien malen und schreiben kann aber auch einen modernen Rechnerarbeitsplatz habe, um so frei und kreativ wie möglich zu Arbeiten. Es soll aber auch ein Platz sein, wo Kunden auf einen Kaffee vorbeikommen können um Aufträge zu besprechen. Es soll ein Platz sein, wo jeder der Interesse an Kunst und Kultur hat, willkommen ist.

The first step to do is to construct the interior. By now it’s just an usual garage: not-insulated and not very comfortable. I will get timber pilling on the floor and planking on the wall to keep the cold outside. Also I need a heating in there. Further I will change the entrance from a double wing door to a fancy glass door as you see in the video. Though I have a small equity I need a little backing to pay the craftsmen and all the stuff. While doing all the work I can do for myself I can’t do the every day work which means lack of jobs and lack of income. When this work is done I need to do some marketing and relaunch my website to tell all the world about what I can do for you.

Als erstes werde ich mit dem Innenausbau der Garage anfangen. Im Augenblick ist sie noch recht kalt und zügig. Ich werde auf dem Boden Dielen verlegen und die Wände verkleiden. Außerdem wird der Eingangsbereich erneuert und verbessert –  statt der Doppelflügeltür aus Holz wird eine schöne, helle Schaufenster-Glastür-Kombi eingebaut (s. Video). Zwar habe ich etwas Eigenkapital für dieses Projekt, dennoch brauche ich etwas Rückhalt für die Kosten, die auf mich zu kommen. Außerdem wird hier einiges an Arbeit liegen bleiben, während ich mich um den Ausbau kümmere, gerade die Eigenleistungen sind zeitaufwendig. Auch nach dem Ausbau wird noch einiges zu tun sein: Meine Website werde ich relaunchen und mich um das Marketing kümmern, so dass so viele Leute wie möglich erfahren, was ich zu bieten habe.

Here you can get a look at the Tee’s you get for your contribution as a ›real Fan‹. You can choose one design.

Hier siehst du die T-Shirts die du als ›real Fan‹ bekommen kannst.

Blood, Sweat & Oil, red or white (Hi-Res in gallery)


Cash Only, black or brown

Tea Time, brown or black

... and that’s how the tee with your name could look like:


I studied graphic design at the university of applied sciences and arts in Hildesheim, Germany with the special focus on calligraphy, typography and lettering. Since my diploma (a brushed typeface) I am a freelance designer and lecturer for calligraphy. At least once a year I take part in workshops with well-known calligraphers. By now I showed my work in several exhibitions – please take a look at the gallery for more impressions of my work.

Schnitzels Garage is my new label for painting signs, cars and motorcycle parts and anything else.

Ich studierte Grafikdesign an der Hochschule für angewandte Wissenschaft und Kunst in Hildesheim mit dem besonderen Augenmerk auf Kalligrafie, Typografie und Schrift im Allgemeinen. Seit meinem Abschluss arbeite ich als freier Designer für diverse Agenturen und kleine und mittlere Unternehmen. Einmal im Jahr nehme ich selber an Seminaren bei bekannten Kalligrafen teil um meine Fähigkeiten zu erweitern. Meine Arbeiten habe ich bereits in mehreren Ausstellungen gezeigt (s. Galerie). Mein neues Wirkungsfeld, die Schildermalerei und das Customlettering habe ich bisher erst bei wenigen Veranstaltungen ausgestellt, aber das Interesse daran hat mich ermutigt dieses weiter auszubauen und meine Garage in ein Atelier zu verwandeln in dem ich meine Kunst professionell ausführen und anbieten kann.

If you can't make a contribution, you can still help to make the project happen, by sharing it with your friends by email, Facebook, Twitter and any other device you can think of. You can also share using the Indigogo share tools.

Thanks for looking at the campaign!

Falls du nicht die Möglichkeit hast mir finanziell zu helfen, dann kannst du mich trotzdem unterstützen indem du diese Kampagne unter deinen Freunden per Twitter oder Facebook teilst.

Vielen Dank für dein Interesse!

BTW: Here is a clip about me and my garage for a regional tv program:


... and here are Woody and Phoebe, who will join me working in the garage. They’re so cute, aren’t they!

story:
Matt's Friends Helping Matt

We have all been on the receiving end of Matt Huntley's help at one time or another. And we're also all big fans of his work (no, not that boring IT stuff, the bodypainting stuff) (check out some of his work here: http://mhuntley.wix.com/bodypaint-by-numbers). He's too proud to ask for help, but I'm not too proud to ask for help on his behalf. I've known Matt since 2006, and as his friend and neighbor and Facebook tormenter, I feel uniquely qualified to help get this thing started. But I'll need your help to help him. 

What We Need & What You Get

The goals of this trip are two-fold. A trip to the World Bodypainting Festival in Austria (http://www.bodypainting-festival.com/en/), followed by a stop in NYC to paint a handful of other folks on the way back to Portland. The costs break down as follows:

  • Airfare: $3,782 (I know. International airfare ain't cheap. Especially with an added stop in NYC.)
  • Hotel in Austria: $689
  • Food ($40/day in Austria): $360
  • Paint (estimate): $350
  • Paypal (or Indiegogo - not sure) Fees: $366
  • Registration: $46
  • Total: $5,227 - This excludes some other incidental cost. But if we can cover this much, he should be just fine.

Unfortunately, I have nothing to offer in return. But if you have ideas of how you can chip in to offer rewards to donors, let me know. 

The Impact

Matt's art is incredible, and his passion about it has overcome backaches, headaches, bellyaches, and all kinds of drama from other people involved. I believe him making this trip will be an incredible boost to his portfolio in this field, improve his already enviable skill set, and give us all some really cool pics we can enjoy while we're supposed to be working. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Matt would also love it if a model (or two) or photographer wanted to join him for this adventure. Ask him about it.

story:
Ask and you shall receive 

Per the request of many interested buyers, we have put a rush on what our January page of the calendar will look like! There will be more images to come, we hope these little teasers will spark your interest and help us raise money for some great causes! Also, HAPPY NEW YEAR!


Just your friendly neighborhood engineers

There's this popular misconception that engineers do nothing but study and drink mountain dew, and we're trying to shatter that image.  We're some fun-loving engineers at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign who're raising money for our favorite charities, and we could use your help!  

We're putting together a 12-month calendar (January 2015 - December 2015) with guys who are currently studying engineering, holding puppies and wearing swimsuits.  Get one for yourself, and a few to share!  It'll be the perfect addition to any desk, bulletin board or bedroom wall.  All profits will be donated to support the Champaign County Humane Society (http://www.cuhumane.org/) and Techbridge (http://techbridgegirls.org/). 

Our game plan

We're taking pre-orders for the calendars.  They're $10 each, and you can buy one, two, five, ten or fifty, depending on how many you want to share!

You can also support the campaign by nominating a friend to be considered for one of the months ($5) or by pooling with some friends to choose someone to be the model for a month ($250 - only 2 spots available!).

There's fairly little overhead - just the cost of printing and shipping - but in order to have anything left to donate, we need to raise more than they cost to print and ship.  Depending on how many are ordered, the calendars will cost anywhere from $2-$6.  The more we sell, the more your contribution will make a difference!

We can ship the calendars to anywhere in the US.  If you're currently a U of I student and wouldn't mind picking up your order, we'll be handing them out at Engineering Hall to save on shipping!  Please add a comment with your order if this would work for you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't want a calendar for yourself, please share this campaign using the links at the top of this page, and tell all of your friends about it, too!  We want to be able to donate as much as possible, so let's spread the word to do some good!


Sharing is caring!

The Charities

Here's a little bit of information about the charities that this campaign will support:

The Champaign County Humane Society is a non-profit organization based in Urbana, IL that aims to prevent cruelty to animals, to promote animal welfare, to educate the public about the humane care and treatment of animals, to increase public awareness of the companion animal overpopulation issue, to provide solutions, and to provide high quality shelter, medical, and adoption services for animals when necessary.  They are an independent organization that is not supported by local tax dollars or a national organization.


Techbridge is a non-profit organization based in Oakland, CA that launched in 2000 as a program to expand the academic and career options for girls in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). Since their founding, they've worked with over 4,000 girls in grades 5-12 through their after-school and summer programs in the San Francisco Bay area. They believe every girl needs personal and consistent support to succeed, and to that aim they've created resources for educators, families, and role models who make up her support network.

And that's it!  Please help us support these causes by ordering calendars and spreading the word!  Thank you for your support!

Just your friendly neighborhood engineers
 There's this popular misconception that engineers do nothing but study and drink mountain dew, and we're trying to shatter that image.  We're some fun-loving engineers at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign who're raising money for our favorite charities, and we could use your help!  
We're putting together a 12-month calendar (January 2015 - December 2015) with guys who are currently studying engineering, holding puppies and wearing swimsuits.  Get one for yourself, and a few to share!  It'll be the perfect addition to any desk, bulletin board or bedroom wall.  All profits will be donated to support the Champaign County Humane Society (http://www.cuhumane.org/) and Techbridge (http://techbridgegirls.org/).    Our game plan
We're taking pre-orders for the calendars.  They're $10 each, and you can buy one, two, five, ten or fifty, depending on how many you want to share!
You can also support the campaign by nominating a friend to be considered for one of the months ($5) or by pooling with some friends to choose someone to be the model for a month ($250 - only 2 spots available!).
There's fairly little overhead - just the cost of printing and shipping - but in order to have anything left to donate, we need to raise more than they cost to print and ship.  Depending on how many are ordered, the calendars will cost anywhere from $2-$6.  The more we sell, the more your contribution will make a difference!
We can ship the calendars to anywhere in the US.  If you're currently a U of I student and wouldn't mind picking up your order, we'll be handing them out at Engineering Hall to save on shipping!  Please add a comment with your order if this would work for you.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't want a calendar for yourself, please share this campaign using the links at the top of this page, and tell all of your friends about it, too!  We want to be able to donate as much as possible, so let's spread the word to do some good!

Sharing is caring!
   The Charities Here's a little bit of information about the charities that this campaign will support:



The Champaign County Humane Society is a non-profit organization based in Urbana, IL that aims to prevent cruelty to animals, to promote animal welfare, to educate the public about the humane care and treatment of animals, to increase public awareness of the companion animal overpopulation issue, to provide solutions, and to provide high quality shelter, medical, and adoption services for animals when necessary.  They are an independent organization that is not supported by local tax dollars or a national organization.

Techbridge is a non-profit organization based in Oakland, CA that launched in 2000 as a program to expand the academic and career options for girls in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). Since their founding, they've worked with over 4,000 girls in grades 5-12 through their after-school and summer programs in the San Francisco Bay area. They believe every girl needs personal and consistent support to succeed, and to that aim they've created resources for educators, families, and role models who make up her support network.
And that's it!  Please help us support these causes by ordering calendars and spreading the word!  Thank you for your support!

story:
Public Art for the Broadway Bridge in Portland, OR:

Greetings to bridge, public art and yarn lovers!  Bridge For Blankets is a community-based knit project, and temporary public art installation, set for install on the Broadway Bridge in August, 2013, as a part of the PDX Bridge Festival.  2013 is the Centennial Anniversary for the Broadway Bridge, and Bridge For Blankets is our way of drawing focus to this historical structure’s role in the Portland community.

This public art installation consists of 4 -18’ x 21’ knit banners hung outside the drawspans, on both the North and South sides of the Broadway Bridge.  The construction of these banners depends upon the support of 150+ knitting volunteers, local mainly to the Portland area.  After the project has been taken back down, these knit banners will be broken down into 42 - 6’ x 6’ afghans, washed, and donated to Portland area homeless shelters (i.e. Human Solutions & SnoCap).

Who is Helping Us?

Multnomah County is lending us their skilled engineers, those that manage and care for the Broadway Bridge, to help Bridge For Blankets go up on the Broadway for the month of August.  We are very grateful for their enthusiastic support of this multi-purpose art installation, and can’t wait to see the banners brightening up this iconic, brick-red bridge.  We need help raising the funds for installation materials and equipment rental, and that is one of the reasons that we are campaigning for your support on Indiegogo.

The knit banners will all be constructed from a colorful array of Cascade 220 Superwash Wool – a wool that will not felt, allowing the homeless shelter recipients to wash these blankets just as they would any other blanket.  Abundant Yarns (http://www.abundant-yarn.com) and Cascade Yarns (http://www.cascadeyarns.com/) have teamed together to offer us a significant discount on the wool we need to for the project, and for that, we are delighted beyond belief.  However, just as with the installation costs, we need your assistance to pay for the large yarn order.  It costs more to create an afghan from quality natural fibers, but we also know that using natural fibers makes the resulting charitable gesture mean more to the recipients.  Please help us pay for the yarn today by making a tax-deductible donation to Bridge For Blankets.

***** We have all the knitting volunteers that we require for this project.

 

How You Can Help:

We invite you to show your support and enthusiasm for what we are doing for the Portland community, and donate generously to Bridge For Blankets on this page.

When you make a donation of $130+ to our project today, you have paid for the yarn for one entire knit blanket.  We accept all donation levels; no donation amount is too great or too small.

Spread the word about this project by sharing the link to this crowdfunding page with your friends, family, neighbors, and co-workers.  Tweet, post on Facebook, and cast an even wider, and more personal, net by sharing our fundraising story via e-mail.  Want some 1/4 sheet cards to hand out to promote the project in hard copy form?  E-mail me at tyler.mackie@gmail.com.

We absolutely could not realize this project without your help.  Donate today, and help us bridge the gap, and restore lives for those within our homeless communities.

UPDATE: We have all the knitting volunteers that we require for this project.

story:
WATCH VIDEO ABOVE ^^^^^^^^

Who am I? For starts, my name is Jillian Bruschera. Stemming primarily from my social and artistic engagement with the Columbia College Chicago community as a student and a teacher, The Mobile Mill isinspired by three years of arts education in bookmaking, printmaking, and papermaking at Columbia’s Center for Book and Paper Arts in Chicago, Illinois.  The idea grows from my experience as a graduate student pursuing a MFA in Interdisciplinary Arts: Book and Paper and is influenced by my work as an educator.

What is The Mobile Mill? The Mobile Mill is an automobile outfitted to enable hand papermaking production, popping up anywhere, at any time. Like food trucks, a studio-on-wheels moves the making experience to, well, anywhere.

The Mobile Mill is a place where people can learn about paper and how to make paper. It is a space for new learners, practicing artists and potential collaborators. As a maker with a considerable interest in repurposing materials, this studio will concentrate on making paper from paper. Not only are the remnants of our human consumption free and easily-found, but the use of recyclables also serves to demonstrate ecological awareness through art education. I will teach participants how to put discarded paper products to use through hand papermaking methods. I am currently developing educational materials and curriculum for workshops, open-studios, and artist-in-residencies. Additionally, I would like to develop a mobile artist residency, initiate guest artist-led-workshops, and form cooperative arts initiatives.

Impact: The Mobile Mill has the potential to generate a type of interaction with community that considers a larger human ecology.  I think it is incredibly important that artists spend time outside of their insular studio practices – my teaching practice is one means of stretching my artistic practice beyond myself.  Encouraged by a human connectedness to others, I aspire to create work that acts as a mediator between peoples. Art exists between people. As a moving-space able to interact between edges, The Mobile Mill considers art-making – in my case, the making of paper – as a way to engage in a variety of communities and dialogues. 

As a portable space, there are endless opportunities for collaboration, and locations are perhaps infinite: schools, camps, art studios/galleries, festivals, farmers markets, craft fairs, pop-ups in parking lots, parties in the park – anywhere a car can go, this paper truck can go. This type of mobility is especially important when considering slashes in school budgets and the subsequent elimination of arts education. A form of creative pedagogy, a mobile classroom can go into a school and bring an art experience to a student.

Help Me Hit the Road: The Mobile Mill project obviously requires substantial financing if I am to actualize it. Meaning it simply isn’t possible without your help. Your donation will help cover the initial costs of:

1. Acquiring a Truck: I need to purchase some sort of used moving van, step-van, retired service vehicle, or food truck. 

2. Parts and Labor for Retrofit: The interior of this truck will be outfitted as a workspace for hand papermaking. This means “everything that can happen in a fixed paper studio but on a small mobile scale.”  Table-top work surfaces, cabinetry for storage, and select machinery (including a Hollander beater and a drying system) will be built out of stainless steel and waterproofed wood. I am raising money to cover the costs of these raw materials. Additionally, I will need to hire and pay a small team of builders (including a car mechanic, a wood-worker, and a welder) to help get the job done right. 

This truck will, at least, serve as a container for supplies that can function within the interior of the vehicle and operate independently outside of the vehicle. My designs aim to maximize the van’s ‘box space’ by creating dual-function elements and all-in-one machinery. For instance, a pull-out ramp on the back of the truck could also operate as a table-top working surface.

Please visit my Tumblr page www.themobilemill.tumblr.com to view additional design sketches.  I am continuously creating initial sketches of my vision, though the final design is dependant on whatever truck body I end up acquiring. These designs continue to change with the research process. I am already in conversation with a spectrum of individuals such as: auto-body mechanics, car dealers, small business owners, contractors, designers, college professors and teaching-artists, food-truck operators, academic administrators, other papermakers, and art studio technicians.

Down the Road: An even bigger, future goal is to build what I’m currently calling a “Mobile Makers” network that would operate similarly to the food-truck system. There are definitely other ‘art trucks’ out there in the world; how neat it would be to congregate? Just as food-trucks can convene (such as San Francisco’s Off the Grid), I imagine that an educational crafts-on-wheels community could do the same.

Beyond $$$ donation, you can help support this project through:

1. Equipment or Material Contribution: See a need you can fill on my current wish-list? I will gladly take any hand-me-down equipment or raw material donations.

  - Box van or step van (in good working condition)

  - DMV registration and vehicle insurance

  - Vats, felts, and moulds/deckle sets for papermaking

  - Hollander beater  

  - Box fans for drying

  - Raw materials: stainless steel, waterproofed wood (or lumber and polyurethane)

  - Roadside emergency kit (fire extinguisher, flares, jumper cables, et cetera)

  - Small, portable water tank

  - Small, portable electric generator

2. Lend a Hand: If you’re local to the Chicago area and consider yourself a handy person when it comes to trucks and/or plumbing, wood or metalworking -- maybe you’d be willing to help out physically by taking part in the building process. Or, share your skills and expertise by way of an interview.

3. Spread the Word: Feel free to share this project campaign via word of mouth, a tweet, a post on your blog, an email to a friend – whatever it takes. Please help me get the word out about this project.

Thank You! This project has already received generous donations of time and energy from friends, faculty members, and mentors at Columbia College Chicago, my Chicagoan friends, family and even relative strangers. I appreciate all the help I can get.

Feel free to email me at themobilemill@gmail.com if you’d like to know more or are interested in supporting this project in another way.

story:
What is the Aerial Expo?

The first annual Aerial Arts and Fitness Association Expo will be held this year in the beautiful central city of Des Moines, Iowa. This is THE go to event for anyone that has a love of playing in the air. We are bringing you world-renowned headliners and show stopping acts from around the globe.

Aerialists from all over are coming for a weekend of fun, workshops, shows, and competitions. In between it all, hang out with everyone during the open aerial gym time. Are you ready?  Because we have a weekend worth of friendship mingling, training and a whole lot of aerial fun coming your way!

What is the Aerial Arts?

Aerial art is a beautiful style of modern dance that blends gravity defying moves with the use of hanging equipment. Aerial silks, trapeze, aerial hoop, aerial rope, aerial hammock, and aerial net are a few of the more popular apparatuses, although aerialists are also known to invent their own equipment. 

What happens at the Expo?

Competitions

This competition, the first aerial competition of its kind, was designed just for amateur aerialists and aerial students to have a platform to compete, show their skills, and grow. There are two levels, beginner and intermediate, so there’s a competition perfectly suited for every contestant to let their aerial skills shine on stage!

http://aafaexpo.com/competition/

Workshops

Come learn new skills and tricks on all types of apparatus with our superstar workshop leaders including the amazing pole and aerial wonder Suwasit, the beautiful aerial duo Womack and Bowman, and the flexi Caty Mae.

http://AerialExpo.com/masterworkshops

And More

There’s so much more to see and do at the AAFA Aerial Expo! From the Friday night Misfit Carbet, to the amazing variety showcases, children’s workshops, seminars, and in between it all is the opportunity to hang around and try new things and mingle with new friends on aerial apparatus.

What can I do to help?

But before we can fly our way into your heart we need your help making this fabulous event happen. Your donations will not only snag you some great swag only available through the Indiegogo Fundraising Campaign, but all the money we raise will go directly towards paying for our venue. This venue will not only be home to our amazing showcases and competitions, it will also house vendors, workshops, and the after party. If you are interested in providing a perk such as circus classes, circus equipment for our fund raising, or volunteering at the event, please let us know. 

The $1,000 you help us raise will help cover a percentage of the cost of renting the venue for the weekend, but we don’t have to stop there! If we raise $8,000, it will cover the entire cost of the expo!

We couldn’t do this without your help! Share the link and keep up to speed on all things aerial by liking us on Facebook.  We want to bring aerial arts to the world and we want you to be a part of it.

Thank you in advance for all of your support!

story:
We are determined to bring all six Striver’s Row poets to Chicago. After having plenty of opportunities to witness the magic of the collective on the east coast, we want the writers, and lovers, and intellects, and activists of our hometown to experience it as well. Upon returning to Chicago, we discovered that many of our mid-western counterparts were already huge fans. So many people here are already spending hours on end watching YouTube videos and scouring Twitter and Tumblr pages in search of Striver’s Row gems. So, we figured it was time for Chicago to have an official "Row" experience.

This campaign is to fund the performance and travel fees of the collective for a show to take place early summer 2014.

story:
Image Credit Aaron O'Connor of The Arctic Circle Residency

Hello,

My name is Stephan Jahanshahi, I am a visual artist working primarily in photography, and I have been given an extraordinary opportunity.  This June, I will leave my home in New York City and depart for the island cluster of Svalbard, where I will board a sailing vessel to spend the solstice month at sea above the Arctic Circle with a small group of artists, scientists and educators.  The goal of this expedition is to generate new work in response to one of the most enigmatic and rapidly changing landscapes on our planet:  The Arctic.

My initial interest in the Arctic Circle Residency stemmed from my time in Canada where I began to incorporate elements of the landscape into my artistic practice, exploring the distance I felt between myself and the environment.  I found the static definitions of place, especially in relation to identity to be problematic and began the first in a number of photographic series exploring my feelings of displacement.  My explorations have centered on human impositions upon landscape such as borders or the narratives surrounding invasive species, linked primarily by what I consider the failing of static language used to describe a natural world that is in constant motion and fluctuation. 

  The Arctic Circle offers a unique environment to explore these themes as it is the part of the world that rebels the strongest against our conventional attempts to navigate, define and classify.  A conservationist friend and frequent collaborator explained to me that the Arctic Circle is defined as the latitude at which the sun does not dip below the horizon on the summer solstice, making it a place defined not by hard borders or flags but by celestial perspective.  It struck me as a beautifully exciting idea to define where you are by the light of the sun.  As so much of my work has tied understanding where I am to the same constructs as who I am, I feel a place defined in such an unfamiliar way offers an exciting opportunity to expand the dialogue within my practice. 

My practical goals for this expedition are to come back with the raw materials that will eventually inform the creation of a body of work to be exhibited and potentially published.  I will be working primarily in digital and analogue photography as well as video and sound recording, capturing as many elements of the environment as I can in order to reconstruct and elaborate on this experience in a foreign place.  To do this, I need your help.

I am asking for your help in raising the funds I will need to pay my portion of the expenses for the expedition, as well as my personal supplies for the trip including film, rental equipment and cold weather gear.  Through generous donations and hard work I have accounted for the majority of my funding independently, and I am asking you to help me bridge this last gap.  My gratitude for your support will be everlasting, I invite you to be part of an opportunity that will be the adventure of a life time!

-Stephan Jahanshahi

For more information about the residency program visit their website at http://www.thearcticcircle.org/#

What I Need & What You Get

The remaining funding I require is for residency fees and art materials (primarily analogue photography equipment) to the amount of $3000.  In return for your generous donations the following rewards are available:

Kudzu Explorers Button - $25

4x5 inch inkjet print, edition of 15 - $50

8x10 inch inkjet print edition of 15- $75

8x11 inch Unique Multimedia Print - $100

20x24 inch inkjet print edition of 10 - $200

Bundle including one 4x5, one 8x10, and one 20x24 inch print - $300

The Pioneer - $900+

The Pioneer package is a customized three-piece art object.  I will work with you to design a custom flag representing you or your company and plant that flag above the Arctic Circle for a photograph. Upon my return from the arctic you will receive a 20x24 inch print of the photograph, a map portion showing the location your flag was planted and the flag itself.
story_txt:
Image Credit Aaron O'Connor of The Arctic Circle Residency

Hello,



My name is Stephan Jahanshahi, I am a visual artist working
primarily in photography, and I have been given an extraordinary
opportunity.  This June, I will leave my
home in New York City and depart for the island cluster of Svalbard, where I
will board a sailing vessel to spend the solstice month at sea above the Arctic
Circle with a small group of artists, scientists and educators.  The goal of this expedition is to generate
new work in response to one of the most enigmatic and rapidly changing
landscapes on our planet:  The Arctic. 
My initial interest in the Arctic
Circle Residency stemmed from my time in Canada where I began to incorporate
elements of the landscape into my artistic practice, exploring the distance I
felt between myself and the environment. 
I found the static definitions of place, especially in relation to
identity to be problematic and began the first in a number of photographic
series exploring my feelings of displacement. 
My explorations have centered on human impositions upon landscape such
as borders or the narratives surrounding invasive species, linked primarily by
what I consider the failing of static language used to describe a natural world
that is in constant motion and fluctuation. 

  The Arctic
Circle offers a unique environment to explore these themes as it is the part of
the world that rebels the strongest against our conventional attempts to
navigate, define and classify.  A
conservationist friend and frequent collaborator explained to me that the
Arctic Circle is defined as the latitude at which the sun does not dip below
the horizon on the summer solstice, making it a place defined not by hard
borders or flags but by celestial perspective. 
It struck me as a beautifully exciting idea to define where you are by
the light of the sun.  As so much of my
work has tied understanding where I am to the same constructs as who I am, I
feel a place defined in such an unfamiliar way offers an exciting opportunity
to expand the dialogue within my practice. 

My practical goals for this
expedition are to come back with the raw materials that will eventually inform
the creation of a body of work to be exhibited and potentially published.  I will be working primarily in digital and
analogue photography as well as video and sound recording, capturing as many
elements of the environment as I can in order to reconstruct and elaborate on
this experience in a foreign place.  To
do this, I need your help.
I am asking for your help in
raising the funds I will need to pay my portion of the expenses for the
expedition, as well as my personal supplies for the trip including film, rental
equipment and cold weather gear.  Through
generous donations and hard work I have accounted for the majority of my
funding independently, and I am asking you to help me bridge this last
gap.  My gratitude for your support will
be everlasting, I invite you to be part of an opportunity that will be the
adventure of a life time!
-Stephan Jahanshahi

For more information about the residency program visit their website at http://www.thearcticcircle.org/#   What I Need & What You Get The remaining funding I require is for residency fees and art materials (primarily analogue photography equipment) to the amount of $3000.  In return for your generous donations the following rewards are available:


Kudzu Explorers Button - $25
4x5 inch inkjet print, edition of 15 - $50
8x10 inch inkjet print edition of 15- $75
8x11 inch Unique Multimedia Print - $100
20x24 inch inkjet print edition of 10 - $200
Bundle including one 4x5, one 8x10, and one 20x24 inch print
- $300
The Pioneer - $900+
The Pioneer package is a customized three-piece art
object.  I will work with you to design a
custom flag representing you or your company and plant that flag above the
Arctic Circle for a photograph. Upon my return from the arctic you will receive
a 20x24 inch print of the photograph, a map portion showing the location your
flag was planted and the flag itself.

story:
Help Omaha Zine Fest celebrate independent publishing!

Hi! We're Andrea, Daphne and Kaitlan and we're the coordinators of the Omaha Zine Fest. 
We started this because we want the artists, writers, makers and creators of Nebraska to have a space to meet, hang out, and purchase each others' work. This event might be the first ever zine fest in Nebraska! The fest will feature local and regional zine makers and publishers for a workshops, vending, and more.
The event will be held at 1316 Jones Street, just outside the Old Market in Omaha, Nebraska.  Zinesters from throughout the region will be there.
We need your help to make sure our first event is absolutely awesome. The venue, unfortunately, isn't free. Neither are the tables. We want this event to be free so everyone can be there because it is an important event for the Omaha arts scene.  
Check out more from us at www.omahazinefest.org 

What We Need & What You Get

We need help to make this happen. We're getting a lot of help but events are expensive!

  • Our estimated costs are around $1,500. This is just for the venue and tables! There are other costs including materials for workshops and other miscellaneous items to keep the event running on the day of the festival. 
  • We would like the opportunity to reimburse the people who are giving their time. Any extra money will be given to bands, out-of-town speakers and others who have helped us with the event. Any leftover that will be put directly into next year's event.

Why are we doing this!?

Lots of people make zines and do other creative work in this state but not all of us know each other! We want to foster a community for zine makers, writers, artists and other creative people. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have extra money, that's okay! We still love you so much. 

  • If you have any services you'd be willing to donate, we'd love that. We're looking for volunteers all the way up to the fest and the day of, too! 
  • Tell your friends about the fest. Share this campaign and ask them to donate. 
  • Come hang out with us on the day of the event!
Thanks so much, we love you, can't wait to see you at our festival in March!!!
Daphne Calhoun, Andrea Kszystyniak, Kaitlan McDermott
