story:
What is it?

It's a calendar! And when 2019 is over, it's 12 Badass prints!

Each month features a hand-drawn portrait of a Badass Woman and important dates to remember.

Including such badasses as:

Coretta Scott King
Nellie Bly
Tammy Duckworth
Lucy Parsons

AND MORE

Important dates include things like:

July 2: Civil Rights Act (1964)
September 4: Beyoncé's Birthday
October 26: Brownsville Clinic Raid (beginning of Planned Parenthood, 1916)

 

 

How much is it?

Each calendar is priced at $20, with discounts for bulk orders
(4 for $70, 10 for $150, 20 for $200)

**If you would like an amount not listed as a perk, OR if you intend to pick up locally in Philadelphia, Bethlehem, or New Orleans, please click BACK IT and enter the appropriate amount (without shipping). For example, if you want 6 calendars for $100, or 30 calendars for $300. Please contact me if you have any questions! thebadasswomen@gmail.com **

The goal fund of $6000 approximately covers printing costs

Pre-ordering guarantees you get a copy and helps me know how many to ultimately print.. and it helps me pay for printing!

Pre-ordering during this campaign includes FREE shipping for individual calendars and significantly discounted shipping for bulk orders!

 

Why a Badass Women Calendar?

I was blown away with the support that the 2017 and 2018 Badass Women Calendars received, and I'm so excited that y'all want more!

Since the first Badass Women Calendar I made (right after the 2016 election) I've seen so many other awesome artists creating portraits of incredible women to celebrate their achievements.

In this edition of the Badass Women Calendar, I hope to especially lift up some people who you haven't heard of, or whose badassery you hadn't quite comprehended (...with a few badass classics thrown in).

I also have always strived to include a diverse group of women, with the goal of highlighting folks who haven't traditionally been celebrated. I am increasingly trying to include more international badasses, and especially women of color, indigenous women, and queer women.

I'm excited to announce that this year I will be donating a percentage of the profits from the project to an organization that specifically supports women of color in the US (this is part of my commitment to address racism and sexism through my small business). UPDATE: The nonprofit this project will be contributing to is Black Women's Blueprint.

Getting Going

Even in August I'd already gotten several requests and questions about the 2019 calendar... so I'm getting going way earlier this year.

I am thrilled to be working with Fireball Printing again to produce the calendar-- a local Philadelphia company I truly admire for its transparency, environmental options, high quality products, and customer service, and they employ a bunch of women.

This pre-order campaign will help me cover the cost of printing.

        

Is it rad?

Yes it is rad. I was pretty sure it was rad when I first started this project, but I have been really touched at how much support its gotten, and I'm so jazzed that so many people are hyped about celebrating badass women.

It has been awesome not only to support myself as an artist and activist with this project, but because I'm able to sell the calendar in local shops across the country, I'm supporting many women-owned businesses as well.

Risks & Challenges

If you pre-order a calendar, you will definitely receive one (unless some unforeseen circumstances prohibit the whole project from finishing, in which case, you'll receive a refund).

There is a small general risk your delivery could be delayed by USPS. (If you do not receive your calendar by the Nov. 1, please contact me)

Other Ways to Be Involved

Even if you can't pre-order a calendar right now, you can totally share this with your mom and hint that it would make a GREAT gift, or tip off your local badass boutique to order some wholesale.

Please share this with someone who you think would love this project! <3

Finally, head over to @thebadasswomen on Instagram and give me a follow if you can!
Find out more at www.thebadasswomen.com

story:
Introduction

Hello, everyone, this is @_shinee5_!

**Before anything else please make sure that you are NOT an overseas fan, I have posted all the GOs I have gathered up until now on a thread, please go there. Anyone overseas who has already spoken to me about how you will get the dolls without a GO, please continue reading!**

I'd like to thank everyone who has been interested in Jonggie! It means a lot to me that you guys love him. In a way, it's my way of coping with the tragedy that we all have endured. So I'm very happy knowing you guys support my project.

This is non-profit and any leftover funds after packaging and shipping the dolls will be donated to a suicide awareness organization in honor of Jonghyun.

 

Product Description

The official price for each set of one doll with the included six outfits is $25 USD. Each doll set comes with:

  • Panties
  • Corgi outfit
  • "Lonely" Era outfit with Roo backpack
  • "Base" Era outfit with crossbody kazoo
  • "She Is" Era outfit with crossbody book
  • "JAT 2017" outfit with wristlet lightstick

Two bonus outfits are also available for extra purchase:

  • "Poet | Artist" Era outfit
  • "Deja Boo" Era outfit with crossbody mouthwash bottle

The Deja Boo and Poet | Artist outfits are $5 USD each and are NOT included with the six outfit + doll set.

 

EMS and Domestic Shipping Fees

This Indegogo is mainly for putting the doll into mass production after I approve the final prototype. Any leftover funds will be used to begin covering EMS (from our manufacturer to me) and domestic shipping costs. Whatever amount I still need after that will be my goal for another Indegogo where you will be able to pay the shipping fees and add your shipping information so you can finally get your doll(s)! There is not currently an estimate for EMS nor domestic shipping fees since I have not received the dolls yet, but I will be updating this campaign with any information I receive along the process.

 

Almost done!

After you finish completing your payment to the campaign, please fill out this form here so I can better keep track of all your information when I begin the shipping process: https://goo.gl/forms/U6ckNwxuUJJsOYpy2

 

Contact Me:

If you ever need to contact me with questions, comments, and/or concerns, you can contact me anytime! I try to reply within 48-72 hours, but if you do not hear from me, feel free to remind me. :)

EMAIL: shinee040890@gmail.com
TWITTER: @_shinee5_

story:
Ambiguous Arts is YOUR community support network. For six years we have been working behind the scenes to give artists access to audiences, grants, showcases, collaborative experiences and more. Our mandate is to match emerging artists along side established artists to develop larger audience bases and create mentor ship opportunities, to cross pollinate audiences for interdisciplinary artists, and to allow a space for collaboration and creativity to foster between artists of different mediums, and arts leaders. We are a registered, volunteer run, not-for-profit society supporting BC artists and arts leaders, and have put on 12 interdisciplinary shows, 5 free outdoor one day festivals, 3 fundraisers for other not-for-profits, 4 international showcasing opportunities for artists, mentorship, and much much more. But now we need your help to grow. 

This year Ambiguous Arts is expanding into an umbrella organization that will both continue to start our own initiatives, as well as to support other arts leaders through mentorship, sponsorship, insurance, promotional help, resource sharing, grant support, and not-for-profit status.

"Ambiguous Arts is an organization that makes artists feel like anything is possible. When working with Ambiguous Arts I always know a powerful night is ahead of me. This organization brings art and audiences together in a way that is rare and profound.
"They remind me of the early days of rock 'n' roll, when organizers would promote artists just because they felt those artists had to be heard. Ambiguous Arts pour their heart and soul into every event. Their professionalism and organizational abilities cannot be understated." 
-James Burrows, professional musician, editor and co creator of The Toronto Tempest, avid Springsteen fan.

We have huge things brewing, including a new career development concert series, ongoing international showcase support for artists, aiding the growth of Seed to Sea, Campbell Bay Music Fest, and Triple A Productions, a new concert series in Victoria whose proceeds will go to an award for BC artists. Along with these initiatives we strive to continuously break down the wall between artist and audience, and to create unique opportunities for experimentation and collaboration.

Ambiguous Arts is also very excited to use our experience and resources to support outside initiatives that need help to get off the ground. 

"Ambiguous Arts is a kick-ass, hoedown-able, exciting, new fashioned, musical, whimsical, fun loving, inventive, foxy, Canadian as hell, serious as shit, group of dedicated adventurers, animators and anarchists. Just the kind of folks that I like to work with…." 
-Mitch Podolak, founder of Winnipeg Folk Festival, Vancouver Folk Festival, Edmonton Folk Festival, Calgary Folk Festival, and Executive Director of Home Routes

In addition to everything above, other projects we are working on this year include artist residencies, mentorship programs, arts panels, and arts collaborative festivals. 

But to even start towards these goals we have some massive housekeeping that needs to get done. We need to get our skeleton structure strong enough to support these initiatives and that takes funding.

We need $7,800 by Nov 25 to keep our doors open and continue as an organization. This is our very bottom line.

Your donations will help to contribute to:

  • Insurance Costs

  • Professional Accounting 

  • Financial Report Preparation

  • Funding Applications

  • Video Production

  • Initial Project Groundwork


"Campbell Bay Music Festival was built from the ground up following the vision of a group of musicians who wanted to create a music festival for the artists as well as the audience. As it grew in size, so did the challenges of keeping it rolling. Ambiguous Arts Festival Society's mandate resonated very well with CBMF, and as we began working with the Society we were given access to an array of assistance, including sponsorships, grant funding, and simpler licensing.
"The festival is not only made easier by this amazing Non-Profit, but we also get to be a part of a larger arts community. The connections we have made through working with Ambiguous Arts have been valuable and I'm sure they will continue to grow as the society does more and more amazing work within the BC arts and music world."
-Meg Iredale, Operations Manager, Campbell Bay Music Festival.

We’re asking for your support this one time to help us move into the next phase of not for profit work. After this, we will be working with sponsorship and donor support, as well as grants and city funding. The best part? Your support right now will function as more than just financial support. 

We are going to share the success of this campaign with other funders, to show that we have our community already behind us! So every dollar you donate is more than just a dollar, it is a vote of confidence in our work. 

Once we fund PAST our goal of $7800, any additional funds will go DIRECTLY into project funding. In fact, when you make a pledge PAST $7800 you can CHOOSE which project to fund directly!

Perks

Our perks are based on the complete success of our coming year. Not only do we need to complete this crowd-funding round, but we also need to get project funding for individual projects.If we are able to make our goal here, our team is DEDICATED to completing all of these projects and goals. 

So, take the plunge! 


“I have worked with Ambiguous Arts a few times, and believe they are creating some of the most interesting collaborations and performance works in this country, and they deserve your support.”     
 -Darcy McMurray, Contemporary Dancer and Performance Artist. 

Ambiguous Arts has been dedicated to finding out where artists lack support, and filling that niche for the last six years. Now we are looking to expand that support, both for artists and for arts leaders: those folks working away at organizing and creating amazing events and arts initiatives. 

Over time, together as a community, we can develop and share resources, ideas, and support to help foster a uniquely strong and independent arts community in BC. One lead by the artists and arts leaders themselves.

Our team has been involved in various arts initiatives, from management, booking, founding events and festivals, dance, theater, spoken word, and more. 

If you are interested in being involved with Ambiguous Arts, or you have an initiative that you think works with our mandate and vision, please feel free to contact ambigarts@gmail.com. This is YOUR arts not-for-profit. 

"Merridale Cider has always been anything but your run of the mill cider and we love to support amazing not-for-profits like Ambiguous Arts, who consistently break free from the norm. It is a very easy choice to support an organization who puts the amount of love and effort into what they do. Helping emerging artists and festival is such a great part of what Merridale does and in return they help spread what we do to so many wonderful and talented people." 

-Jason Child, Merridale Ciderworks


As you all probably know, there are a constant barrage of risks when working in the arts. Funding is one of them. It is important that you know that this initial start up support of $7800 is just our bare minimum to continue on. After this Gogo goal is reached, it will allow us more time to apply for ongoing funding, project funding, organization funding, and to look for donors and private and corporate sponsorship. 

In saying that, we are also only interested in working with folks who share our same vision in community and arts. We believe that we can support those sponsors and donors as equally as they support us, through showing their commitment to the arts to the arts community. 

Much of the funding provided during this Indiegogo will also go towards helping our staff go after long term funding options. We are excited to be working with a newly emerging expert in community and private donor relationships, some of Canada's top grant writers, and an amazing professional sponsorship consultant. Another thing to keep in mind is after our initial $7800, all pennies go into project funding. And you can pick the project you fund. So lets kick it! 

At this moment, our most pressing matter is financial support. We hope you will find a perk that appeals, and help us spread the word! Every share, like, tweet, ello, or mention to a friend is amazing! 

Ambiguous Arts has had the privilege to throw a fundraising event for ArtsWells Festivals of All Things Art. We have also worked alongside organizations such as Music Yukon, Alberta Music, SaskMusic, The Pan Canadian Initiative, Folk Music Canada, Folk Alliance International, OCFF, and many more. 

"The ArtsWells Festival was extremely honoured and overwhelmed by the incredible job that the Ambiguous Arts team pulled off for "One Night Stand" in Vancouver, a fundraiser for the ArtsWells Festival in Wells. In addition to performances by some amazing artists, Ambiguous Arts also organized the presentation of visual arts everywhere in the venue and extra fundraising projects like a live auction, silent auction and a kissing booth. They got a huge crowd out, probably due to the professional job that they did with the promo, which included beautiful posters all over town and ads in both the Georgia Straight and the Westender, the later of which also did a story on the event and the festival. 
"So not only did they provide ArtsWells with some much needed funds, they also gave us some incredible profile and promotion in Vancouver. As someone who is always on the organizing side of things, especially when it comes to ArtsWells related events, its was a huge gift to arrive at this event and be able to simply enjoy the evenings festivities. I was thoroughly impressed with the countless hours of work that the Ambiguous Arts Society put into "One Night Stand," as I know what it takes to make an event successful. And to think they did it to support a little festival up north, is truly commendable." 
-Julie Fowler, Executive Director, Island Mountain Arts.

Artists we have had the pleasure to have perform at events, or to showcase at conferences include, but are not limited to:

The Cheesecake Burlesque Revue (performance), The Tequila Mockingbird Orchestra (music), Steve Dawson (music), Jim Byrns (music), The Sojourners (music), Quinn Bachand (music), Tillers Folly (music), Kim Beggs (music) , Nick Gregson (visual), Darcy McMurray (dance), Broken Rhythms (dance), Blackberry Wood (music), Miami Device (music), Lady Ra (music), The Tailor (music), Sons of Granville (music), Tim Sars Trio, Duende (music), Flying Fox and the Hunger Gatherers (music), The Fretless (music), Oliver Swain's Big Time Machine (music), Sarah MacDougall (music), Red Bird (music), Dragon Fire Spectacles (performance), James Burrows (music), Rachael Cardiello (music), NicTex (music), Deadhorse (music), Orchestar Slivovica (music), Maria In The Shower (music), Aliah Mcdonough (visual), Travis Bower (visual), Dyana Sonik-Herderson (dance), Missie Peters (spoken word/theatre), Patrick Boyl (music), David Parfit (performance), Jennifer Li (performance), Tom Fyles (performance), Syd Woodward (video), Carolyn Mark, Tim Gosley (puppetry), Madeline Sonik (writer), Dan Wise (performance), Justin Grenda (performance), Jenny Ambrose (performance), Taylamara (dance). The String

If you don't yet know anyone on this list, by next year, we want to make sure you do. Help us achieve our goals! 

Sincerly,

Your Friendly Team at Ambiguous Arts Festivals Society

P.S. We would like to thank the support of The Tailor and Darcy McMurray for their collaboration in our pitch video, Levi Chase for filming, editing, and directing the video, and Michael Rush, Jenny Ritter, Sarah Veness, and Melanie Spence for being super stars.
story_txt:
Ambiguous Arts is YOUR community support network. For six years we have been working behind the scenes to give artists access to audiences, grants, showcases, collaborative experiences and more. Our mandate is to match emerging artists along side established artists to develop larger audience bases and create mentor ship opportunities, to cross pollinate audiences for interdisciplinary artists, and to allow a space for collaboration and creativity to foster between artists of different mediums, and arts leaders. We are a registered, volunteer run, not-for-profit society supporting BC artists and arts leaders, and have put on 12 interdisciplinary shows, 5 free outdoor one day festivals, 3 fundraisers for other not-for-profits, 4 international showcasing opportunities for artists, mentorship, and much much more. But now we need your help to grow. 


This year Ambiguous Arts is expanding into an umbrella organization that will both continue to start our own initiatives, as well as to support other arts leaders through mentorship, sponsorship, insurance, promotional help, resource sharing, grant support, and not-for-profit status.


"Ambiguous Arts is an organization that makes artists feel like anything is possible. When working with Ambiguous Arts I always know a powerful night is ahead of me. This organization brings art and audiences together in a way that is rare and profound.

"They remind me of the early days of rock 'n' roll, when organizers would promote artists just because they felt those artists had to be heard. Ambiguous Arts pour their heart and soul into every event. Their professionalism and organizational abilities cannot be understated." 

-James Burrows, professional musician, editor and co creator of The Toronto Tempest, avid Springsteen fan.



We have huge things brewing, including a new career development concert series, ongoing international showcase support for artists, aiding the growth of Seed to Sea, Campbell Bay Music Fest, and Triple A Productions, a new concert series in Victoria whose proceeds will go to an award for BC artists. Along with these initiatives we strive to continuously break down the wall between artist and audience, and to create unique opportunities for experimentation and collaboration.
Ambiguous Arts is also very excited to use our experience and resources to support outside initiatives that need help to get off the ground. 

"Ambiguous Arts is a kick-ass, hoedown-able, exciting, new fashioned, musical, whimsical, fun loving, inventive, foxy, Canadian as hell, serious as shit, group of dedicated adventurers, animators and anarchists. Just the kind of folks that I like to work with…." 

-Mitch Podolak, founder of Winnipeg Folk Festival, Vancouver Folk Festival, Edmonton Folk Festival, Calgary Folk Festival, and Executive Director of Home Routes


In addition to everything above, other projects we are working on this year include artist residencies, mentorship programs, arts panels, and arts collaborative festivals. 



But to even start towards these goals we have some massive housekeeping that needs to get done. We need to get our skeleton structure strong enough to support these initiatives and that takes funding.
We need $7,800 by Nov 25 to keep our doors open and continue as an organization. This is our very bottom line.
Your donations will help to contribute to:

Insurance Costs
Professional Accounting 
Financial Report Preparation
Funding Applications
Video Production
Initial Project Groundwork

"Campbell Bay Music Festival was built from the ground up following the vision of a group of musicians who wanted to create a music festival for the artists as well as the audience. As it grew in size, so did the challenges of keeping it rolling. Ambiguous Arts Festival Society's mandate resonated very well with CBMF, and as we began working with the Society we were given access to an array of assistance, including sponsorships, grant funding, and simpler licensing.
"The festival is not only made easier by this amazing Non-Profit, but we also get to be a part of a larger arts community. The connections we have made through working with Ambiguous Arts have been valuable and I'm sure they will continue to grow as the society does more and more amazing work within the BC arts and music world."
-Meg Iredale, Operations Manager, Campbell Bay Music Festival.

We’re asking for your support this one time to help us move into the next phase of not for profit work. After this, we will be working with sponsorship and donor support, as well as grants and city funding. The best part? Your support right now will function as more than just financial support. 
We are going to share the success of this campaign with other funders, to show that we have our community already behind us! So every dollar you donate is more than just a dollar, it is a vote of confidence in our work. 
Once we fund PAST our goal of $7800, any additional funds will go DIRECTLY into project funding. In fact, when you make a pledge PAST $7800 you can CHOOSE which project to fund directly!
Perks
Our perks are based on the complete success of our coming year. Not only do we need to complete this crowd-funding round, but we also need to get project funding for individual projects.If we are able to make our goal here, our team is DEDICATED to completing all of these projects and goals. 
So, take the plunge! 








“I have worked with Ambiguous Arts a few times, and believe they are creating some of the most interesting collaborations and performance works in this country, and they deserve your support.”     

 -Darcy McMurray, Contemporary Dancer and Performance Artist. 

Ambiguous Arts has been dedicated to finding out where artists lack support, and filling that niche for the last six years. Now we are looking to expand that support, both for artists and for arts leaders: those folks working away at organizing and creating amazing events and arts initiatives. 

Over time, together as a community, we can develop and share resources, ideas, and support to help foster a uniquely strong and independent arts community in BC. One lead by the artists and arts leaders themselves.Our team has been involved in various arts initiatives, from management, booking, founding events and festivals, dance, theater, spoken word, and more. 
If you are interested in being involved with Ambiguous Arts, or you have an initiative that you think works with our mandate and vision, please feel free to contact ambigarts@gmail.com. This is YOUR arts not-for-profit. 

"Merridale Cider has always been anything but your run of the mill cider and we love to support amazing not-for-profits like
Ambiguous Arts, who consistently break free from the norm. It is a
very easy choice to support an organization who puts the amount of
love and effort into what they do. Helping emerging artists and
festival is such a great part of  what Merridale does and in return
they help spread what we do to so many wonderful and talented
people." 
-Jason Child, Merridale Ciderworks


As you all probably know, there are a constant barrage of risks when working in the arts. Funding is one of them. It is important that you know that this initial start up support of $7800 is just our bare minimum to continue on. After this Gogo goal is reached, it will allow us more time to apply for ongoing funding, project funding, organization funding, and to look for donors and private and corporate sponsorship. 

In saying that, we are also only interested in working with folks who share our same vision in community and arts. We believe that we can support those sponsors and donors as equally as they support us, through showing their commitment to the arts to the arts community. 
Much of the funding provided during this Indiegogo will also go towards helping our staff go after long term funding options. We are excited to be working with a newly emerging expert in community and private donor relationships, some of Canada's top grant writers, and an amazing professional sponsorship consultant. Another thing to keep in mind is after our initial $7800, all pennies go into project funding. And you can pick the project you fund. So lets kick it! 

At this moment, our most pressing matter is financial support. We hope you will find a perk that appeals, and help us spread the word! Every share, like, tweet, ello, or mention to a friend is amazing! 
Ambiguous Arts has had the privilege to throw a fundraising event for ArtsWells Festivals of All Things Art. We have also worked alongside organizations such as Music Yukon, Alberta Music, SaskMusic, The Pan Canadian Initiative, Folk Music Canada, Folk Alliance International, OCFF, and many more. 
"The ArtsWells Festival was extremely honoured and overwhelmed by the incredible job that the Ambiguous Arts team pulled off for "One Night Stand" in Vancouver, a fundraiser for the ArtsWells Festival in Wells. In addition to performances by some amazing artists, Ambiguous Arts also organized the presentation of visual arts everywhere in the venue and extra fundraising projects like a live auction, silent auction and a kissing booth. They got a huge crowd out, probably due to the professional job that they did with the promo, which included beautiful posters all over town and ads in both the Georgia Straight and the Westender, the later of which also did a story on the event and the festival. 
"So not only did they provide ArtsWells with some much needed funds, they also gave us some incredible profile and promotion in Vancouver. As someone who is always on the organizing side of things, especially when it comes to ArtsWells related events, its was a huge gift to arrive at this event and be able to simply enjoy the evenings festivities. I was thoroughly impressed with the countless hours of work that the Ambiguous Arts Society put into "One Night Stand," as I know what it takes to make an event successful. And to think they did it to support a little festival up north, is truly commendable." 
-Julie Fowler, Executive Director, Island Mountain Arts.

story:
On June 16th 2013, two months before returning to the playa, Shipwreck Tiki Lounge, one of Burning Man’s favorite watering holes caught fire and was completely destroyed at her home port in Oakland. 

After a lot of thought (and drinking) we have resolved to rebuild the lounge for the 2014 Burning Man! So with high spirits and full sails we are announcing our fundraising drive to raise a doubloon to make it all happen!

But before we rattle the can we'll describe our theme camp/ lounge to those who were not fortunate enough to see her in all her glory. 

We set up camp on the Esplanade in 08, 09, 10, and 11 until finding a home within French Quarter Village the last few years. This year we will be located on the 7:30 portal in the heart of the red nose district!

In 2012 we gave up trying to build our camps out in the dust and built our bar entirely within the protective enviroment of a 50 foot semi trailer! 

And because of our radical new design that minimizes set up time in 2012 we were open five days before Burning Man even started! 

During the actual event Shipwreck Tiki Lounge was a huge hit. We were open 6-7 hours a day. Many folks would tell us they had traveled from the far side of the playa after hearing rumors of “the air conditioned tiki bar”.

We may never know the exact cause of our beloved lounge's demise but true burners don’t whine, they carry on and persevere! Work on the new Shipwreck Tiki Lounge has already begun. The many damaged nautical antiques are being restored. The beautiful hardwood bar is having its burnt edges sandblasted. But the work is plenty and resources are few. 

By the quick count to get just the bare minimum of the lounge repaired, the cost is just under $5000. There will most certainly be many other costs. 

Our promise to you, our sponsors, will be that the rebuilt Shipwreck Tiki Lounge will be even more beautiful that the original! It will once again be the talk of the town. 

Once inside you will be transported to a magical rain forest of Tiki Gods and scantily clad wahines. 

newly built cave like ceiling at lounge's entrance 

A few of the other many amazing new improvements to the lounge include… ..a three level waterfall and rainforest ...mysterious cave-like interior entrance complete with stalactites. …spectacular black light lit tapa cloth ceiling …ships plank flooring. 

To our supporters and potential sponsors unfamiliar with the tenants of Burning Man it is important to understand that we don’t make any money on this. We don’t “sell” drinks out in the desert. We do it only for our love of tiki, our love of Burning Man and of course our love of throwing a great party!  

All the drinks, transport costs, food and survival necessities are not even included in our fundraiser. All that comes from our own pockets and we’re glad to do it. 

So there it is…we are putting it out there to the Burning Man world and beyond. What is it worth to you to once more enjoy cool umbrella covered drink all the while being 200 miles out into the most inhospitable environment on earth? What’s it worth to you to be part of one of the most worlds most unique tiki bars? 

 Well it ain’t world peace but it ain’t bad. 

As is customary with on line fundraisers we will offer a series of premiums to show our appreciation to all our supporters, burners, tiki freaks, and all lovers of crazy, improbable artistic creations out in the desert!

So with high spirits and full sails we are announcing our fundraising drive to raise a doubloon to make it all happen!But before we rattle the can we'll describe our theme camp/ lounge to those who were not fortunate enough to see her in all her glory. We strive to bring out to the desert an authentic old school tiki bar experience that includes plenty of tikis, a mystical tropical environment, and of course a stiff cool drink with a little umbrella! ShipWreck Tiki Lounge on the Esplanade 2011We set up camp on the Esplanade in 08, 09, 10, and 11 until finding a home within French Quarter Village the last few years. story:
What We Do:

We love art, we love dance, we love creativity, and we love the diversity and unique culture of people around the world. TriplicArt looks to combine all of these elements and provide a place where the younger generation in two remote indigenous communities in the Amazon can learn new forms of expression while maintaining their cultural identity and traditions. We want to leave a legacy space for artistic development in these communities and to provide a global platform for their talents to be seen, appreciated, and recognized.

Triplicart 2014:

In January 2015 we will be returning to the 'Umariacu' village in the Amazon to run a series of week long workshops. This year we will be adding a second week, and a second village, 'Belem Do Solimoes', to the itinerary. 

These communities are on isolated, indigenous land reserves with very little access to the outside.  They are also in an area of Brazil near the borders of Columbia and Peru where there is heavy drug trafficking and many young people quickly fall into this dangerous lifestyle. 

Typically, youth in these communities only receive 2 hours of school per day, so our aim is to be able to provide a week of classes focused on art and culture to provide another outlet to focus their energy. We will also strive to incorporate local traditions, styles, and mythology along with our diverse artistic backgrounds to create paintings, photographs, and choreographed dance routines that reflect their culture and heritage. Finally, their work will be showcased in a community wide exhibition and performance at the end of the week.

Our Dedicated Team:

Lavoisier Clemente is the founder ofTriplicArt. Lavoisier has a passion for people and art and was inspired to create TriplicArt while assisting in health and wellness workshops in the indigenous communities of the Amazon in his native Brazil.

Greg Swales is a fashion photographer and painter. He has been focused on creating visual art since very young and has led many visual art programs for universities and colleges in North America and he was part of the initial development team that ran workshops in TriplicArt's pilot program in 2013.

Keila Ramirez is the newest addition to the team and brings with her a background in community development and project management. She has a passion for dance and will be leading salsa, and afro cuban dance workshops and developing a choreographed performance with the students.

What We Need:

Supplies are expensive and often times hard to find in these remote areas, so our short term goal is to be able to leave the communities we visit with enough supplies for them to keep creating and keep the programs running after we leave. Supplies can be anything from paint brushes, paint, canvases, paper, to digital cameras, video recorders, cd players, and instruments.

Our long term goal is to help nourish the artistic talent in the communities by building a physical space where they can access these resources.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell your friends about this project by sharing the link to our campaign and help us get the word out.

story:
In order to realize my vision, I began by drawing a turnaround of my concept from several angles. 

I then turned to Shinedown Productions and worked with them on the design.  After many months of editing, we came up with the two prototypes you have seen pictured.

What we are coming to you all for is help with funding for this project.  We have paid the factory, so the catfish are being produced; however, plush production is very expensive.  We would like to reclaim some of our expenses, which would help us with the creation of future projects, like more colors and designs of catfish! 

In return, you will be among the first to adopt your very own catfish!  Each catfish will come with an art booklet field guide about this unusual creature.  We are also giving free shipping to all US backers!

We have set this campaign to have flexible funding, meaning that even if we don't reach our goal, your pledges will be collected.  This is because the catfish are currently in production, and anyone who pledges one of our tiers is guaranteed to receive one (or more) catfish, regardless of whether or not the goal is met.  We strongly believe in our ability to succeed in our campaign and have had previous success with our last Kickstarter for umbrellas, where we received 300% funding!

https://www.rainingcute.com

The initial $5,000 goal is going directly toward our production costs.  If we surpass our funding goal, we will be able to recover our shipping and storage costs as well.  This will also mean that more bonus items will be included with each order! 

Thank you for taking the time to read about our project.  Even if you aren't able to pledge at this time, please share it with anyone who might be interested.  Together, we can make catfish a reality!

(P.S. if anyone is interested in purchasing additional catfish (more than 3) or additional art books, please send me a message!)

 

For more of my work, please visit my other social media sites:

http://thebubbleqat.tumblr.com/

http://thebubbleqat.deviantart.com/

https://www.instagram.com/thebubbleqat/

https://www.etsy.com/shop/minkworks

I then turned to Shinedown Productions and worked with them on the design.  After many months of editing, we came up with the two prototypes you have seen pictured.

What we are coming to you all for is help with funding for this project.  We have paid the factory, so the catfish are being produced; however, plush production is very expensive.  We would like to reclaim some of our expenses, which would help us with the creation of future projects, like more colors and designs of catfish! 

In return, you will be among the first to adopt your very own catfish!  Each catfish will come with an art booklet field guide about this unusual creature.  We are also giving free shipping to all US backers!

We have set this campaign to have flexible funding, meaning that even if we don't reach our goal, your pledges will be collected.  This is because the catfish are currently in production, and anyone who pledges one of our tiers is guaranteed to receive one (or more) catfish, regardless of whether or not the goal is met.  We strongly believe in our ability to succeed in our campaign and have had previous success with our last Kickstarter for umbrellas, where we received 300% funding!

https://www.rainingcute.com
The initial $5,000 goal is going directly toward our production costs.  If we surpass our funding goal, we will be able to recover our shipping and storage costs as well.  This will also mean that more bonus items will be included with each order! 

Thank you for taking the time to read about our project.  Even if you aren't able to pledge at this time, please share it with anyone who might be interested.  Together, we can make catfish a reality!
(P.S. if anyone is interested in purchasing additional catfish (more than 3) or additional art books, please send me a message!)
 

For more of my work, please visit my other social media sites:
http://thebubbleqat.tumblr.com/
http://thebubbleqat.deviantart.com/
https://www.instagram.com/thebubbleqat/

https://www.etsy.com/shop/minkworks

story:
About This Project

With the “Chrysalis: A Time of Change” Exhibition, we will showcase the art of a dynamic group of South Florida’s most talented rising artists working in an array of mediums, who are all graduates of the Artist as Entrepreneur Institute (AEI).

This exhibit represents one of the most important annual events for Broward County artists marking a time of change for those on the path of making their art, their business. The exhibit runs from May 29 – June 24, 2017 at ArtServe, Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

Our first goal is to raise awareness in the broader community -- global and local -- of the high caliber and diverse range of south Florida’s artistic talent. In particular, this exhibit is an opportunity to expand audience for each artist individually and all collectively.

Our second goal is to inspire and motivate our selected artists (and future DBA artists) to shoot for the moon in pursuing their passion for creating art and making their art, their business. Unique to this collective of DBA artists is training in social media marketing which builds upon business skills learned during AEI.

Our final goal is to reinforce the importance of art and cultural entities as important economic contributors to the community. Your support enables each artist an opportunity to not only exhibit their art, but also sell their art. In doing so, the artists grow as artist entrepreneurs and all involved benefit-the artist, the collector, the gallery and the community.

Who is DBA 2017: “Chrysalis ~ A Time of Change”?

   Erin Bassett, Silk Fabric Sculptures, 

@erinbassettartistry 

   Lee Brock, Digital Painting, @leebrockdesign

   Mary Belle Cordell, Porcelain Painting, @marybelle.cordell

   Marie Donze, Reverse Abstract Painting on Transparent Glass @MarieDonzeFineArt

   Yeshiva Lex, Musician, Songwriter, Lead Vocalist of NMBR11

   Anabel Rub Peicher, Sculpture, @anabelrubpeicher

   Ruth Sharton, Acrylic Abstract Painting,

   Harriet Silverstein, Mixed Media with Pastel on Paper, @harrietsilversteinartist

   Serafima Sokolov, Oil and Acrylic, @serafimasokolov

   Marilyn Valiente, Watercolor, @marilynvaliente  

   Richard White, Mixed Media. @richardwhitestudio

   Curator Phoenix, Nature and Wildlife Photography, @phoenix.spiritdiva

   Co-Curator Bunny Sheffield, Watercolor, @sheffieldfinearts

For more on each artist and their works in the Chrysalis Exhibit

Why is this important?

To be an artist is to see the world in new ways. With “Chrysalis: A Time of Change” Exhibition, we want to help showcase the art of a dynamic group of South Florida’s most talented rising artists, many of whom are emerging or mid-career artists; assist in growing their careers as artists by bringing them well deserved exposure; and help more people feel the benefit of an artist’s attention to – and care for – the surrounding world.

Why Indiegogo?

Community. Art enriches the entire community, not just those making it. So we want to let the community enrich itself. With your support, we can make sure the “Chrysalis: A Time of Change” Exhibition fulfills its promise for these participating artists. Indiegogo also enables us to share the progress of the artists and the exhibit with a creative and committed global audience.

What Will Your Contribution Support?

With your help, the “Chrysalis: A Time of Change” Exhibition can emerge. Your contribution means that associated expenses not covered by the limited budget are met and ensure a successful exhibition. You will quite literally be breathing life into the “Chrysalis: A Time of Change” Exhibition vision. Funding for this project is provided in part by the Broward County Board of County Commissioners as recommended by the Broward Cultural Council.

Read more on history of DBA exhibits

Risks and Challenges

Phoenix, an award-winning nature and wildlife photographer whose works are collected worldwide, has organized and curated 11 solo exhibits to date, serves as President of the National League of American Pen Women-Fort Lauderdale Branch and has curated numerous juried exhibitions. In partnership with ArtServe, Broward County’s arts incubator, there is little to no risk to prevent the show and the rewards from going forward. Indiegogo is an important ingredient in supporting this project and with a successful campaign, we are confident this project will move forward on schedule.

Be Social. Follow Us.

Website

Facebook

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I give for more than one reward?

Yes, you can (thanks!). This has to be done in two separate transactions. Make your first choice by mousing over the reward you want (the button then turns pink), and complete the transaction; then, return to the project page and do the second one.

How can I donate but NOT choose a reward?

Thank you! Simply click the pink "BACK IT" button at the TOP of this campaign. Please note, if you do this, you don't get the choice of a reward.

I'm having trouble contributing, can you help me?

We'd love to help you. First you might want to see if your problem is covered here. If not, please write to us (info@photographsbyphoenix) and we'll try to help!

Can I pay with Paypal?

Sorry, unfortunately not. Indiegogo has recently changed payment providers and no longer accepts payments through Paypal. All major credit cards are accepted.

Can I pay by check or bank transfer?

We are happy to accept donations in any form. Please contact us if you prefer not to use a credit card and we will find a solution.

* What will I receive for Perks with Art ?

With the intent to not burden any one artist more than another, perks that include art (levels $100, $300, $500 and $1000) will be distributed in a random order to ensure that a piece of art from each artist is distributed before beginning the cycle again. Chrysalis artists represent various mediums - including oil, watercolor, glass, ceramic, digital art, silk fabric, porcelain, mixed-media, music and photography - and smaller works and/or quality giclee prints (up to 11"X14" depending on the artist) without frames will be shipped.

Sponsors

Blick Art Materials

Lift Digital Media

Rafiq Jordan Video Services

The Video Factory

 
Tate Earle
 
Bellamoon Desserts
 
The funding for this project is provided in part by the Broward County Board of County Commissioners as recommended by the Broward Cultural Council and is supported in part by an award from the National Endowment for the Arts.

story:
Hey! Salut! Halló!

Our names are Selina and Meaghan, and we are two redheaded Canadian artists living in Nova Scotia and Montreal. Our campaign is for friends, family and very generous strangers who want to help us get to the NES Residency in Iceland by September so we can practice what we love. 

Together we have worked hard to fund our art and travel, but seeing as most of our working hours are unpaid, we are asking for donations. In exchange we want to include you in our artistic practice! If you make a contribution then we will be delighted to paint or draw, ’en plein air’, part of the Icelandic landscape that you helped us reach, and we will send the art we’ve made back to you! Much of our artwork is about long distances, reimagining community, gestures of support, and mapping the spaces which we occupy- so the  cross-country-commerce of receiving the benefits from a donation is an artwork in itself. 

What we need to make this campaign successful is nothing astronomical- so please contribute whatever is comfortable- knowing that 15$ can buy the brush that will paint the ocean, 30$ will supply the film needed for documenting performances in volcanic fields, and 50$ will pay for our food so we can avoid eating raw fermenting shark for breakfast. 

It is also important to mention that our intentions of working within the Icelandic landscape will mirror our eco-oriented practice in Canada: remaining respectful and diligent when it comes to natural beauty, conscientious of its rare and fragile ecosystems. Funding this residency will provide us with more financial leniency towards making eco-friendly decisions regarding food, travel and supplies. 

There are different ways in which you can support artists, and we’re lucky to receive the loving and motivational support that it takes to keep creating. If you would like to know more about the projects we will be working on, or offer support in other ways, please feel free to contact us by email, or check out our websites (both mentioned above), where you can find our previous collaborations and the Icelandic work (published this winter). 

Supporting the Arts is a crucial way of maintaining healthy cultural diversities, allowing for cross cultural discussions, of building new histories, and celebrating the role that beauty still has to play in our world. To work and live as an artist is challenging and has risks, but it is well worth it for us all. Get the word out- We’re going to Iceland! We need your help! We will send your our art! Thanks very much, Þakka þér fyrir!

story:
Our Story

Contemporary Art Exhibition

16 November 2011- 7 January 2012

Manila, Philippines


Exhibition Venues and Major Partner Institutions

•Cultural Center of the Philippines
•School of Design and Art, College of St. Benilde
•Vargas Museum, University of the Philippines


The Impact

Building a house that comforts and connects; teaching others to heal and empower through art; transforming plastic caps into an art piece, converting Facebook entries of Overseas Filipino workers into sound and visuals; telling the story of the migrant worker through a sound installation, workshops and performance. These and many more, from artists  all over the world, who will come to Manila for an art exhibition called Nothing to Declare.

 

The exhibit is open and free to the public and is the starting point for its

• Educational Components

• Teacher training and art production workshops

•  Essay writing contest

•  Artist talks

• Possible parallel events with collaborating institutions with similar initiatives


The organizers have been using personal resources for the past two years. Artists who were selected out of more than 100 proponents are generously giving of themselves and will pay for their own airfare, among other expenses.  However, we need additional funds for secretariat and installation supplies and materials, transportation expenses, insurance, cocktails, and fees for workers.


Be part of making this important exhibition happen in Manila. Contribute any amount to help us mount the exhibit and develop public programs to reach more people. You can also help us spread the word.

story:
Greetings, humans! I’m Megan Kennedy, a writer and artist from Salt Lake City, Utah and owner of Abuse of Reason Art and Photography. I’ve been doing art for over ten years now, and have been given some amazing opportunities, including being published internationally and working with musicians and authors to achieve their dream project covers. Fans of the official Bioshock Facebook may recognize my work “Rapture”, which was featured there last year and has since become the best-selling print in my gallery.

For the last two years, I have participated in Craft Lake City, Utah’s second-largest arts festival, and each year has been more successful than the last. I feel my studio is on the cusp of a fantastic explosion into greatness I’ve only yet dreamed of, and I want to give it the rocket fuel it needs to make that happen.

Previous years at Craft Lake City, I’ve gone small with only a table set-up and a modest display. This year, with the festival expanding to two days, I want to upgrade to a booth and expanded print selection to draw the crowds in like never before. I’m also looking to be a part of the Urban Arts Festival as well this summer, which is expanding to the Gateway mall. My only obstacle to this goal is being a broke college student. I’m asking for your generous contributions to help me solidify Abuse of Reason Art as a business by investing in a stand-out festival presentation this year.

--

Last year's booth

--

What This Campaign Will Fund:

  • Print displays for the larger booth space: We are penny-pinching folk and will stretch every dollar contributed by exploring creative and non-traditional display options, such as old window shutters, magazine racks, etc., to be both budget-friendly and eye-catching for the festival.

  • Prints: The majority of the contribution will be spent purchasing prints to sell. We will have a range of smaller sizes (4x6-11x14), as well as larger poster-sized prints, and hopefully even a canvas or two available for the festival public.

  • Various business expenses: Business cards, plastic bags for print purchases, battery-operated lighting for the booth after dusk, clear bags and cardboard backing to protectively package prints, frames for the poster-sized prints, printing of signs/price tags, etc. This will also help us cover the entry and booth rental fees of the festivals.

--


Rapture

--

What You Get:

For a $1 Contribution: You get a ginormous THANK YOU from AOR for your support of the arts. At the festivals, we will have printed a list of names of every donor, and any donation amount gets your name on that list for all the festival to see. Your name will also be entered in a drawing for an 18x20 print of “Rapture”.

For a $10 Contribution: Send us a photo of you, your mom, your dog, whoever, and we will zombify them!

For a $20 Contribution: We will send you a 4x6 print from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.

For a $25 Contribution: We will send you a 5x7 print from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.

For a $30 Contribution: We will send you an 8x10 from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.

For a $50 Contribution: We will send you an 11x14 print from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.

For a $100 Contribution: If you are in a band, an author, or have some other comparable project, I will do your cover art. My work has been commissioned internationally by musicians, indie authors, and publishers like Random House; I guarantee you professional quality work. You can find my portfolio at:

http://www.facebook.com/abuseofreason or

http://abuseofreason.deviantart.com

For a $150 Contribution, you have several choices: If you are in a band or an author, I will set up a photo shoot with you and provide you with promo pictures you can use on social media, show flyers, book jackets etc. If you’re SLC local and just need some traditional photos, we can also set up a photo session for anything you want! All options receive a CD with high-res copies of photos, with 10-15 edited, and full copyright release to print and post as you so desire.*

For a $200 Contribution: You will receive both promo photos AND cover art for your project. (SLC locals for photos)*

For a $300 Contribution: We will send you a gorgeous 26x26, ready-to-hang canvas print of your choice from the AOR Etsy Store: http://www.etsy.com/shop/AORArt

For a $500 Contribution: We will send you the 26x26 canvas of your choice, as well as certificate guaranteeing that the print you selected will NEVER be printed in large-format again. You will own the one and only copy of this print in wall-hangable size. (Only exclusion to this being “Rapture”, which has already been printed in large-format prior to this campaign.)

For a $1000 Contribution: I will work with you on a commission of your choice. You don’t have to be in a band or an author; any art you want to see done, I will work with you to create it. Once we create your dream work of art, we will send you a 26x26 canvas print of your commission. This work will NEVER be sold by me in ANY format; not on Etsy, not at festivals, never. It will be a one-and-only piece for you, generated from your beautiful brain.

*Please note: photoshoots are not included for residents outside of SLC. However, if you’re outside the area and willing to come to the Salt Lake Valley at your own expense, arrangements can be made.

--

Cover for "Coffee and Cockpits" by Jade Hart

--

The Impact

Contributions to this campaign will be far-reaching and felt long after this festival season is over. Displays purchased for the festivals can be re-used for years to come, allowing me to apply to bigger festivals without worrying about running with the big dogs on presentation. Prints that remain unsold after the festival will immediately be up for sale on my Etsy store, as well as becoming surplus inventory for future festivals, art galleries, etc., which will again enhance my reach to new audiences. Everything this campaign is funding will allow my business to run smoother and reach higher for months and years into the future.

Aside from the material impact, the exposure gained through this festival will obviously impact the growth of my business, and potentially expand my clientele of authors, musicians, etc., who come to me for commissioned work. The money I make from these commissions literally sustains my survival during the school semesters, allowing me freedom to pursue my education whole-heartily. Art is what I love doing, and I would be endlessly grateful if I were able to transform this business into something making enough to contribute to my family’s budget (beyond just surviving).

--

When I Grow Up

--

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that even in the best of economic times, it’s not always easy to support the arts financially. Anything you can do to spread the word of this campaign, or of Abuse of Reason Art, will be incredibly appreciated!

    • Share this campaign!

    • Share my Etsy Store! Every print sold here will help me reach my goals: http://www.etsy.com/shop/AORArt

    • Share the AOR Facebook! http://www.facebook.com/abuseofreason

    • Share the AOR Twitter! @AORArtandPhoto

    • Got a friend in a band, or one about to finish the Great American Novel? Let them know about my contribution rewards for CD/book cover art! My work has been commissioned internationally, by indie authors and by publishers like Random House. I guarantee them professional quality work.

    • SLC locals, get out to Craft Lake City this August!

    • Support your local arts wherever you live. Culture in the US needs a boost.

For a $25 Contribution: We will send you a 5x7 print from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.
For a $30 Contribution: We will send you an 8x10 from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.
For a $50 Contribution: We will send you an 11x14 print from the AOR Etsy Store, chosen and signed by the artist.
For a $100 Contribution: If you are in a band, an author, or have some other comparable project, I will do your cover art. My work has been commissioned internationally by musicians, indie authors, and publishers like Random House; I guarantee you professional quality work. You can find my portfolio at:
http://www.facebook.com/abuseofreason or
http://abuseofreason.deviantart.com
For a $150 Contribution, you have several choices: If you are in a band or an author, I will set up a photo shoot with you and provide you with promo pictures you can use on social media, show flyers, book jackets etc. If you’re SLC local and just need some traditional photos, we can also set up a photo session for anything you want! All options receive a CD with high-res copies of photos, with 10-15 edited, and full copyright release to print and post as you so desire.*
For a $200 Contribution: You will receive both promo photos AND cover art for your project. (SLC locals for photos)*
For a $300 Contribution: We will send you a gorgeous 26x26, ready-to-hang canvas print of your choice from the AOR Etsy Store: http://www.etsy.com/shop/AORArt
For a $500 Contribution: We will send you the 26x26 canvas of your choice, as well as certificate guaranteeing that the print you selected will NEVER be printed in large-format again. You will own the one and only copy of this print in wall-hangable size. (Only exclusion to this being “Rapture”, which has already been printed in large-format prior to this campaign.)
For a $1000 Contribution: I will work with you on a commission of your choice. You don’t have to be in a band or an author; any art you want to see done, I will work with you to create it. Once we create your dream work of art, we will send you a 26x26 canvas print of your commission. This work will NEVER be sold by me in ANY format; not on Etsy, not at festivals, never. It will be a one-and-only piece for you, generated from your beautiful brain.
*Please note: photoshoots are not included for residents outside of SLC. However, if you’re outside the area and willing to come to the Salt Lake Valley at your own expense, arrangements can be made.
--

Cover for "Coffee and Cockpits" by Jade Hart
--
The Impact
Contributions to this campaign will be far-reaching and felt long after this festival season is over. Displays purchased for the festivals can be re-used for years to come, allowing me to apply to bigger festivals without worrying about running with the big dogs on presentation. Prints that remain unsold after the festival will immediately be up for sale on my Etsy store, as well as becoming surplus inventory for future festivals, art galleries, etc., which will again enhance my reach to new audiences. Everything this campaign is funding will allow my business to run smoother and reach higher for months and years into the future. 
Aside from the material impact, the exposure gained through this festival will obviously impact the growth of my business, and potentially expand my clientele of authors, musicians, etc., who come to me for commissioned work. The money I make from these commissions literally sustains my survival during the school semesters, allowing me freedom to pursue my education whole-heartily. Art is what I love doing, and I would be endlessly grateful if I were able to transform this business into something making enough to contribute to my family’s budget (beyond just surviving).
--

When I Grow Up
--
Other Ways You Can Help
I understand that even in the best of economic times, it’s not always easy to support the arts financially. Anything you can do to spread the word of this campaign, or of Abuse of Reason Art, will be incredibly appreciated!


Share this campaign!


Share my Etsy Store! Every print sold here will help me reach my goals: http://www.etsy.com/shop/AORArt


Share the AOR Facebook! http://www.facebook.com/abuseofreason


Share the AOR Twitter! @AORArtandPhoto


Got a friend in a band, or one about to finish the Great American Novel? Let them know about my contribution rewards for CD/book cover art! My work has been commissioned internationally, by indie authors and by publishers like Random House. I guarantee them professional quality work. 


SLC locals, get out to Craft Lake City this August!


Support your local arts wherever you live. Culture in the US needs a boost.

story:
DREAM SWING 2013

 

    Hello, my name is Joe Beal, some of you may know me as Sexy Situation. I am an artistic welder and a single dad of three amazing kids. We live in beautiful Bend, Oregon. I have been welding and creating for many years. In the past most of my work has been custom cars, bicycles, and welding and fabricating for skateboard parks. In 2002 I had one of my custom bicycles featured in Lowrider car magazine.

    In 2012 after having a dream about building a 25' high pendulum swing, I got the project funded here on Indigogo and was able to see my swing project on the playa (my virgin burn) making my dream a reality!
 
    As I was setting the swing up on the playa my wheels started turning as to what I would be doing to the swing next year!

    Since Burning Man 2012 I have begun creating aerial rigs, fire performance props, playa bikes, circus equipment, and some Custom Lighting...


    By helping fund the Dream Swing project you will not only be helping me make another dream come true. You will also be helping me share the love with all on the playa once again. 

 

 

                                                     

 

    My vision is to expand the Dream Swing and build it into an intergalactic bus stop on the esplanade. It will be six feet taller making the entire swing 30 feet tall, it will have ornate benches at all four corners, multiple bars rising from the benches to the top of the swing covered in LED lights, 8400 LED lights making it even more of a beacon of light on the playa.

 


     Expanding on my vision I will create a place to rest and relax before heading off on your next adventure as well as create love and light on the playa...There is just something so romantic about swinging together.

    It was so fantastic hearing people talk about using the dream swing as a beacon to guide themselves around the playa in 2012, as well as grow loving friendships with new people while swinging...


Please donate if you can and take advantage of all of our fun perks!!

Alien baby's will cry if the Dream Swing is not at burning man 2013

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 Dream Pink! Sticker

 

 

 

 Dream Pink Bracelet 

 

 Dream Pink Bandana

 

Amazing hand made Steampunk Playa Pendent, created in Albuquerque, New Mexico by my beautiful friend Jenn

 


    By helping fund the Dream Swing in 2013 you will make it possible to purchase the steel, electrical wiring, LED drivers/power supplies, LED light strips, powder coating and painting of new steel pieces, supplies to make cushions for the benches and swing, welding wire and gas, supplies to fix up the trailer that will get the swing to the playa this Year..

    The Dream Swing project has already been blessed with the gifting of a 6' x 16' flat bed trailer to set up for hauling the swing. So amazing!!

 
    If the Dream Swing is not fully funded in the next 38 days you will all get your money back and all the people will be sad!

P.S. Remember alien baby's will cry if the Dream Swing is not at burning man 2013... just sayin'

  
 
PLEASE HELP ME BRING THE MAGIC BY GETTING THE WORD OUT!

I understand some of you can’t contribute financially, but you can still help!

By posting on facebook, blogs, twitter...etc.

Tell your friends, family, and coworkers!

Also give Indiegogo share tools a try!

 
Love and (((hugs))) Joe "Sexy Situation" Beal

story:
Hello!

I’m Eamon Espey, a cartoonist from Baltimore with two books published by Secret Acres, Wormdye (2008) and Songs of the Abyss (2012). My drawings have appeared in art shows in such places as New York and Istanbul  and in print in Sweden’s Galago Magazine and Washington DC’s Bash Magazine.  

For this project, I have collaborated with Lisa Krause to create a puppet show based on one of my comic stories that was collected in my new book.  Lisa is a sculptor and puppeteer who has studied in the Czech Republic and has worked with Bread and Puppet in Vermont.  She’s been an associate artist with Black Cherry Puppet Theater in Baltimore since 2009.

The purpose of this fundraiser is to raise money to aid in travel cost for our national book and puppet show tour. Indiegogo is way for us to get the last amount we need quickly, and offer you our arts and crafts in return.  Although we’ve been working very hard and have already saved a great deal, we’re not rich. Far from it. We’re putting everything we have into this project. The $1000 goal we are trying to make here is a only a small fraction of what we have already spent and what we anticipate spending. Anything will help and will be deeply appreciated.

 

Songs of the Abyss is a graphic novel that diagrams the psychic history of human beings. It is a journey through chaos in search of peace. There are five chapters in which grotesque and spiritual themes overlap. All is rendered in black ink with precision and care. The cover is stained glass. I made it in the basement of our home. Songs of the Abyss is my personal record, creed and poem.

 

Making a Puppet Show:

There are no words in Songs of the Abyss so that left the question of how would one have a reading for promotional events if there is nothing to read? The answer was very simple and suggested by Lisa.

Together we turned one of the chapters into 22-minute puppet show performance. Although we started with the comic, once we began collaborating new possibilities and interpretations began to emerge. As we continued working the show grew in concept and in scale. The result is unlike any creative project I have ever been a part of.

While we were writing and building, Stephen Santillan was simultaneously composing a soundtrack. He would send us pieces of what he was working on and we show what we were doing. Stephen’s entrancing and ethereal music really helped define the tone and movement of the show. At times it was uncanny how in sync the sound was to the visual elements. We’re very grateful and lucky to have such a talented friend.

Now that we've performed in Baltimore, New York City and Washington D.C., we are taking it on the road. We are packing everything into our 2001 Toyota Corolla and going on 8000-mile road trip.

On that trip, we’ll be performing at a variety of venues across the country and will be at two comics festivals: The Small Press Alternative Comics Expo in Columbus, Ohio and Stumptown Comics Festival in Portland Oregon.

We leave for our first show on April 11, 2013 and last tour date is on May 18, 2013.

 

The Story of Ishi’s Brain:

 Ishi’s Brain is based on the true story of a man that has often been referred to as “the last wild Indian.”  Lisa and my version turn the story into a science fiction ritual where a lone spirit spends his final days and an alien shaman helps guide the dead into the next world.  Although the ideas presented are highly imaginative, the intent comes from a place of reverence and the utmost respect for the original people of America.

 

What We Need & What You Get

While we are working as many jobs as we can and have almost met our goal, we need your help!

  • We anticipate our expenses for the tour to be around $5,000.  
    • ($1,200 in gas alone.)

  • We've already spent $1,500 on car maintenance in preparation for the trip and around $1,000 to make the show.

  • Your contribution in any amount will help ease the burden for us, because we're paying for this all ourselves.        

  • To thank you for your contribution, we’re offering some great things that have never been available from us before. Things we’ve made especially for this fundraising campaign- so think of it as a presale or something to get us a bit of gas money!  The rewards include 1” buttons, patches, stickers, t-shirts, posters, replicas of our shadow puppets, a copy of Songs of The Abyss, original artwork published in the book, and more.  Lisa will even make a custom puppet for you.  Seriously. 

    All donations of $5 or more receive a postcard and 1"button

    Custom orders will be received by 2014 and amulets or stained glass before winter 2013

 

The Impact 

  • You will be part of us sharing our work. Through your contribution, you will help us bridge communities of puppetry, comics, and music. You can follow our journey on our tumblr/tour blog.

  • You can feel good because many of the places on our tour will be free/donation based, and others are very low cover.

  • You can get stuff we made directly from us. Your contribution will help us out now- when we need it most! 

We’ve already saved a good percent of our projected costs, and it’s going to happen- it’s just really hard to swallow, because we’re going for broke here. We're putting all we have into this.  It’s been really hard to come up with the money, but it’s even harder for us to ask for help! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute, but here are some other ways you can get involved:

  • Tell everyone you know about our project.

  • Loan us your roof rack's cargo box.

  • Make us some peanut butter & jelly rice cake sandwiches or a mix CD for those long drives on the west coast!

  • Come see our show!!!

 

For more information on our project and tour dates visit Lisa's blog. 

You can listen to Stephen Santillan's music here

 

Thank you for your time and your support!

 -Eamon and Lisa

 

 

And special thanks to our friends and family that helped us make the show: Michel Anderson, Chuck Espey, Andrew Liang, Russell de Ocampo, Mary O’Flaherty,Stephen Santillan, Jennifer Strunge, Deitra Thompson, Emily Uchytil

story:
El Oceano An Interactive Ocean at Burning Man 2k15

  


   


  Thank you for viewing my project. This will be my forth Burn and El Oceano's third. He was nothing but a little dream in my eye... during my first burn there was a moment where I sat on a couch high atop a scaffolding and thought, "Where's the Ocean?" So the following year I built El Oceano he was not nearly the Ocean I imagined but he was an Ocean and I loved him. Every morning and evening I walked out to 3600 and 1:15 where he laid I cleaned whatever moop that was in or around him and made whatever adjustments needed, as well as a few new friends. I heard stories from campmates of bonding within the waters of El Oceano. I saw burners napping within El Oceanos waves.  Three years later and now I need your help in making El Oceano even more fun and interactive. Each year that past I've made due with very little funds and would like to expand this year.

   And with your help we can and add lights, more Burner treasures, astro turf to lay on and more fabric to thicken the waves and create a side border.                                                                     


     

   Deep inside El Oceano I would love to have more prized treasures within his treasure chest, such as but certainly not limited to... clean socks, snack bars, chap stick, bandanas, tooth brushes, sunscreen, water, undies, batteries, bandaids, eye drops, cough drops, scruchies, glass repair kits, bandaids, finger nail clippers, sunglasses,  you get the idea.


 I will also add a copy the Ocean Gaurdian pledge inside the treasure chest in hopes of spreading a bit of Ocean awareness and a Ocean Explorers Sea Log where expressive burners can write a story, joke or draw a picture to share with others. With your help we can add reusable astroturf or green carpet underneath El Oceano's waves to create a perfect napping place, as well as build a rip curl to create the perfect amount of shade for during those hot sunny days.  


*If you donate $50 your name will be included in a special thank you within the treasure chest, you will also receive an El Oceano T-shirt and button, along with an El Oceano print.                                                                                                                                          

*If you donate $100 your name will be included in a special thank you within the treasure chest, you will also receive an El Oceano T-shirt, button and one of the characters from the stop anime in a mini shadow box along with an El Oceano print.



  I hope that EL Oceano adds to the memories of traveling Burners and perhaps gives them something they needed. Also that by reading the pledge they leave the Burning Man with more respect and appreciation for our waterways.  

       Please help me make El Oceano the Ocean I know he can be!                                      Also please share this link too! :D
