story:
In the video above, Make Studio Artist Jerry Williams and founding staff member Cathy Goucher speak with reporter/meterologist Ava Marie in an appearance on Baltimore's WBAL-TV.

 

About Make Studio

"Make Studio has provided a forum for my son to sell his artwork... Never before has he been able to market and earn money from his work. My son has sold several art pieces last year and this year... This has increased his self-esteem... He proudly says he is 'going to work' not 'to school'."

Make Studio’s mission is to provide multimodal visual arts programming, including sales and exhibition opportunities, to adults with disabilities in a supportive and inclusive environment. We aim to put art and abilities to work, ultimately making art more inclusive in Baltimore. A secondary, but important, aim of Make Studio is to educate the public about the abilities and creative potential of people with disabilities.

Make Studio responds to the striking need for person-centered, employment-readiness services for people with disabilities. The art process provides a strengths-based vehicle to give voice to perspectives, set goals, learn new skills, and take on leadership roles, ultimately helping individuals transition to the world work and independent living. In addition, adults with different abilities who would like to pursue arts careers often face social and logistical barriers to starting a sustainable practice on their own. To meet this need, we operate a professionally-equipped, community-integrated studio. Program artists come to the studio to receive individualized facilitation in developing their own artistic styles, learn presentation and marketing skills, and develop translatable vocational skills. Make Studio also provides exhibition opportunities that not only increase self-esteem and sense of community, but often result in sales providing income to our artists. (Make Studio artists sold almost $10,000 worth of artwork in 2012-early 2013 alone.) 

As Make Studio celebrates its 3rd year of providing services to artists, the demand for our program has increased. However, the resources available to keep our studio doors open have not.

If Make Studio is going to continue providing strengths-based opportunities to artists with disabilities, we will need to expand our studio hours, our exhibition activities and outreach, and our ability to serve artists who have no funding for services.

Please help us to continue fostering the vast creative talent and ingenuity of these artists!

All funds raised towards our project goal of $2500 will be put directly towards program operating costs, to include art materials, studio rent and utilities, and exhibition expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us on Facebook and follow our artists' blog to stay up-to-date with our events and happenings. You can visit our website for more information, and to shop our artists' wares, at make-studio.org.
story_txt:
In the video above, Make Studio Artist Jerry Williams and founding staff member Cathy Goucher speak with reporter/meterologist Ava Marie in an appearance on Baltimore's WBAL-TV.
 
About Make Studio

"Make Studio has provided a forum for my son to sell his artwork... Never before has he been able to market and earn money from his work. My son has sold several art pieces last year and this year... This has increased his self-esteem... He proudly says he is 'going to work' not 'to school'."
Make Studio’s mission is to provide multimodal visual arts programming, including sales and exhibition opportunities, to adults with disabilities in a supportive and inclusive environment. We aim to put art and abilities to work, ultimately making art more inclusive in Baltimore. A secondary, but important, aim of Make Studio is to educate the public about the abilities and creative potential of people with disabilities.
Make Studio responds to the striking need for person-centered, employment-readiness services for people with disabilities. The art process provides a strengths-based vehicle to give voice to perspectives, set goals, learn new skills, and take on leadership roles, ultimately helping individuals transition to the world work and independent living. In addition, adults with different abilities who would like to pursue arts careers often face social and logistical barriers to starting a sustainable practice on their own. To meet this need, we operate a professionally-equipped, community-integrated studio. Program artists come to the studio to receive individualized facilitation in developing their own artistic styles, learn presentation and marketing skills, and develop translatable vocational skills. Make Studio also provides exhibition opportunities that not only increase self-esteem and sense of community, but often result in sales providing income to our artists. (Make Studio artists sold almost $10,000 worth of artwork in 2012-early 2013 alone.) 
As Make Studio celebrates its 3rd year of providing services to artists, the demand for our program has increased. However, the resources available to keep our studio doors open have not.
If Make Studio is going to continue providing strengths-based opportunities to artists with disabilities, we will need to expand our studio hours, our exhibition activities and outreach, and our ability to serve artists who have no funding for services.
Please help us to continue fostering the vast creative talent and ingenuity of these artists!
All funds raised towards our project goal of $2500 will be put directly towards program operating costs, to include art materials, studio rent and utilities, and exhibition expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

Join us on Facebook and follow our artists' blog to stay up-to-date with our events and happenings. You can visit our website for more information, and to shop our artists' wares, at make-studio.org.

story:
3 Months after Hurricane Sandy

When a natural disaster strikes, it is the physical devastation that we focus on. Though Sandy hit New York City over three months ago, many of us have horrific images of the hurricane still fresh in our minds. Some of us came out relatively unscathed, but for so many New Yorkers, the reconstruction process has just begun and the emotional devastation remains palpable. The Hurricane Sandy Art Relief Caravan Project was founded to serve the most vulnerable amongst us: children. 

Hurricane Sandy Art Relief Caravan Project:
Artistic First Responder

As Artistic First Responders, we put our expertise in the healing power of art to work immediately after a crisis begins. We augment the work of other critical relief efforts through visual art-based programs that support expression, and enable a safe space for emotions to be shared. Since we began the Art Relief Caravan Project our volunteer team has been comprised of educators, artists, and art therapists and students at the NYC Graduate Art Therapy Department. We are a colorful caravan, united in our desire to help our community find beauty, solace and support in moments of darkness.

The one-year project targets 200 children and teenagers in the areas of Far Rockaway, Gerritsen Beach, Coney Island and Red Hook.
 
One outcome of the year long project includes four public exhibits of the children's art. SCROLL TO THE BOTTOM TO SEE A FEW OF THESE IMAGES....
 
 

What We Need & What You Get

Our total budget of a full year of weekend programs in these neighborhoods is $73,925.00. These costs cover Caravan staff, art supplies, transportation, meals for participants, and any unforeseen costs related to workshop spaces.

Depending on the number of children and teenagers at our workshops there will be four to eight educators, artists, and art therapists leading the program. Depending on the location and the amount of art supplies we need to rent one to two cars for the day. We plan on serving either one full meal or a snack to all participants depending on the time of day and length of workshop.

Want more details about our program? Here are our project phases:

Phase 1:  (Re)building children and youths’ emotional well-being and enhancing resiliency:
Guided self-reflection on the experience of Hurricane Sandy using creative modalities to convey feelings, explore fears, and express hopes and desires; Guided group discussion of experiences and observations; Personal narrative projects that children and youth pursue over the course of a year through video diaries, paintings, comic books, journals, and photography
 
Phase 2: Developing skills to deal with stress and conflict:
Workshops for children and youth and their caregivers in conflict resolution and stress-reduction employing creative activities such as improvisation and role-play; Workshops in creating environments conducive to open, supportive communication about Hurricane Sandy and its aftermath.
 
Phase 3: Encouraging inter-personal communication and establishing the group as a place to learn and practice coping skills:
Regular talk-back sessions for children and youth to share progress of individual narrative projects; Workshops on the global environment and critical analysis of the circumstances leading to the super storm; Joint artistic collaborations to build empowerment; sharing and presentations of art work to families and the public; Forums for inter-generational and inter-cultural communication and dialogue within the surrounding neighborhood leading to the installation of permanent artwork in the participating communities.
 
Phase 4: Mentor Training & Program Assessment:
Train teenagers and older children as peer mentors to younger participants; Apply assessment rubric to program including interviews and psychological consultations; Organize think tanks with participants on how the program can be improved.
 

Project Outcome

At the end of the first year of the Art Relief Caravan Project, we expect to see a marked increase in participants’ sense of well-being and hopefulness, feelings of personal achievement and worth, capacity to deal with new stresses and loss as they occur, improved conflict and stress management skills, greater sense of connection to others and use of a group setting for support, better relationships with caregivers, fewer “risky” behaviors, and a deeper understanding of the circumstances and aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.


We would like to thank HooplaHa for our wonderful video! And Tammy Han, for her extraordinary support!

Can't contribute financially? That's Okay!

  • Please share this campaign with your friends, families, colleagues, perfect strangers. Every bit of word-of-mouth will help us!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share on Facebook and Twitter
  • SEE SOME CHILDREN'S ART BELOW....

 

Hurricane Sandy

One child's painting of a boat being pushed by the waves during the storm.

One child's picture of his basement that was flooded. "An unsafe place," he shared.

 

One teen's drawing of a staircase to what will become his new home after the storm

story:
During a revolution, everybody has a weapon. Politicians use their policies while people take to the streets with their chants, their art - or even, their cameras.

 
Jonathan Rashad is a self-taught Cairo-based photojournalist and citizen journalist covering events in Egypt as they have unfolded over the past 4 years. Whether it's fierce clashes happening in Tahrir Square or a tragic train crash killing tens of innocent people, Jonathan is sure to be at the scene exposing parts of the truth that all too often go unseen. At times, it's costed him his safety and sometimes, his own sanity.
 
Over the years, Jonathan has had the challenge of working as a freelancer, but it's a path he has chosen in order to tell Egypt's story the way anyone should see it. Freelance photojournalists would never get compensated if their gear is broken, stolen or confiscated for instance.
 
The only problem now is that his camera has worn out and his wide lens needs replacing.
 
Citizen journalism has admittedly played a crucial role during recent events across the nation. And in a country where certain freedoms are being stripped away from the people, it's a citizen's duty to keep their efforts by any means, whenever possible.
 
Jonathan is working on a photo documentary about the Egyptian revolution (which will be released in 2014) and he's keen as ever to continue documenting Egypt's struggle but he needs your help. Your support means to him more than you could possibly know.  
 
-
 
The price for freedom is always steep, as more than 1200 were killed - since the 2011 Egyptian revolution erupted - during clashes with police, army and pro-government supporters.
 
 
  
---
 
Why $8500?
 
$6000 to buy a Nikon D4
$1900 to buy AF-S NIKKOR 24-70mm f/2.8G ED lens
$220 to buy EN-EL8 rechargeable Li-ion Battery
$340 is the 4% charged by indiegogo.com 
 
---
 
 

  • "Sexual Harassment in Egypt"

The United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women published a report showing the most recent statistics of sexual harassment in Egypt. The study shows that 99.3% of Egyptian women have experienced some form of sexual harassment.

Jonathan prefers not to say so much details about the photo-story, as it will be a breaking one and it will take a long time to finish. But - briefly, he wants to focus on the fact that most of women in Egypt experience sexual harassment on a daily basis.

 

  • "Street Children of Cairo"

Street children suffered a lot from police brutality over the past decade, especially after the revolution. You could see the street children who clash with riot police these days for instance. 

Jonathan wants to follow a street child (or a specific group of street children) for a while and document their daily lives, to focus on the struggle those kids go through, as well as the variant reasons for the existence of 'street children' in Cairo. 

----

 My interview with Jadaliyya regarding freelance photojurnalism in Egypt.

 

Donating, sharing the campaign on Facebook or Twitter, or spreading the word to your colleagues and friends around would help me get back on track to continue documenting Egypt's ongoing revolution.

story:
Hi everyone! My name is Stacey. I am a full time artist who designs enamel pins.

I started @oldstoriesph on Instagram as a way for me to share my art and designs to the world.

This campaign is a step to making my work as an artist into a brand that creates fun, collectible and wearable art through the help and support of people in this community.

 

 

IMPORTANT:

1. This is a FIXED funding campaign.

- Funds will be returned at the end of the campaign if the initial goal is not met.

2. Pledges are charged immediately.

- Unlike Kickstarter that charges at the end of the campaign - you may be charged immediately upon pledge but this does not mean that it goes directly to me. I get funds at the end of the campaign.

3. SURVEYS will be sent to all backers via e-mail when the campaign ends.

- Remember to check your emails if you have backed this project. This is where you will choose which designs you are ordering. And please make sure to provide a valid email that you will have access to.

4. Please make sure to double-check your shipping information and email.

- To make sure that your pins arrive safely to the correct addresses and that I may easily contact you for future updates.

5. Lastly, if you're interested in any designs that are not yet unlocked, don't hesitate to make your pledge so we can all reach the goals and unlock them together! :D Thank you!

 

THE COLLECTION

All prices during the campaign are discounted from regular price once listed on my shop. Once certain funding goals are met - more of the designs will be "unlocked" and available at the end of the campaign. There will also be "freebie" stretch goals as extra rewards for those who back this campaign. :)

DITTO FILLER PINS CAN BE PLEDGED FOR. The pair count as a pledge for 1 pin. :) You can also get 1 of the two (random) by pledging for 5+ pins.

You can manually add to your pledge. Click "Back it" and add $11 for every extra pin on top of your pledge.

The Pins

FUNDS

To have enamel pins produced is a lengthy and costly process and can only be made using the funds from this campaign if the minimum goal is met. I will be shipping and managing everything from the Philippines, but I will be having them made outside of the country by a manufacturer that I trust with producing only high quality pins.

These funds go completely to:

- 80% Manufacturing and shipping.

- 12% Backing cards and packaging materials.

- 8% Indiegogo & other Fees.

 

OTHER REWARDS

All designs are already revealed. The only other possible stretch goals would be shiny variants or more freebies.

- Every pin pledge gets a matching sticker of their pin design choice.

- All prices on this campaign are discounted from regular price once sold in my store.

- Early bird tiers will be available with further discounts.

 

Production and Shipping Timeline

Once the funding campaign has ended, production can begin. It takes about a month to manufacture.

After grading and packing all orders I'll be shipping them via local post. All mail is registered and can ship anywhere internationally. This usually takes 2-4 weeks with a tracking number. (Not accounting for possible delays)

If everything goes smoothly, your package will arrive by late April/early May. You may always contact me for any inquiries regarding your package.

 

Risks & Challenges

***Please note that this timeline is only if no manufacturing and/or shipping delays occur. I have no control over the manufacturing side (and if there are defects I may have them remade because I wont send defective products) and I also have no control after I have released your package for delivery. This is an estimate time and some packages may arrive sooner/later than others.***

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount of support that anyone could ever give is very much appreciated.

If you can share this campaign in any way, please do - and a big thank you to you!

Indiegogo has share tools available to share on other social media platforms.

You may also check or tag my main page on Instagram @oldstoriesph where I post all my updates and announcements outside of Indiegogo. Thank you so much!

story:
Hello Everyone!

As many of you know, our friend Mariah Miranda is a very talented young artist and will be studying photojournalism and mixed media art at Corcoran College of Art + Design. She is leaving next week for Washington DC and her exciting new adventure, living her dream!

From very early on Mariah has been able to touch and move people through her writing, poetry, and art.  At twelve years old she wrote a piece for a writing contest entitled, "My Brother, My Hero" , about her older brother's deployment to Iraq.  Although a work of fiction, the feelings she evokes in her readers are very real.  As I read it, I never once questioned that she was drawing from true memories of the frantic trip to see her brother before he deployed.  It turns out there was no such trip.  At 12, she was able to take the emotions and angst that surrounded a trying event, and give them identity.  Give them a story.  She won first place for this piece, in a category aimed at 13-18 year olds. 

Over the years Mariah has developed into an artist of many mediums, thriving on not just expression through words, but also paint, pencil, and ink.  But some of her most impressive work has come from behind the lens of her camera.  She began taking photos about a year after winning the writing contest.  While on the road with her mother (Janel Miranda) who was filming a documentary, she took with her a small Kodak camera, a gift from her sister.  While Janel was getting interviews, Mariah was snapping photos, and a camera has been in her hand ever since.  With an eclectic porfolio ranging from portraits and nature shots to photos of live bands and low-light images, she has been able to gain acceptance into her choice photography program at The Corcoran College of Art + Design. Based on her portfolio she was awarded the William Eggleston Photography Scholarship. Eggleston is considered the father of color photography. Mariah's essay for the James "Jamon" Hickem Art Memorial Scholarship for a fellow Hickman High School artist so inspired his aunt that she created a second scholarship for Mariah called the Soul of the Artist.

Mariah's talent and hard work have gotten her into Corcoran. She and her mother have managed to get together almost enough money to make her dream education a reality.  They were selling their car to help fund the cross-country move, and Her dorm is an apartment with kitchen so the funds were needed to support her first few months. Her mother has nearly completed her film and finances are challenging until then. Unfortunately, Mariah was involved in an accident a few days ago which totaled the car. It was an old car valued at $3,000 but was only covered by liability insurance, rendering it a total financial loss. After the accident Mariah looked at me with tear filled eyes and said, “I've just destroyed my future in one fell swoop”.

This young lady is far too talented and has worked too hard to let this minor bump get in the way of her future. I want to help get her to DC without the stress of worring about money. I'm asking everyone who knows and loves Mariah to help see her through this.  We all know what it's like to be in a financial crunch. It seems that money's always tight when we need it most.

The $3,000 loss is very disheartening to Mariah. I understand. That amount of money is difficult for most people to come up with at once. Break it down though and it's not that bad. 300 people x $10 = done and done. Through the magic, voodoo power of social networking we can reach 300 people in no time. If you can't make a monetary contribution you can definitely still help by passing on the word. Facebook it, tweet it, whatever it takes to get it out there.

At this time, in this world of ours, it's more critical than ever to support promising young women like Mariah. Reach out and push her up. It may seem like a small gesture, but it can have a magnificent impact on her life and in effect, all of our lives. After all, today's young women are tomorrow's mothers.  The mothers of our future.

Peace to you all.

If you can't make a monetary contribution you can definitely still help by passing on the word. Facebook it, tweet it, whatever it takes to get it out there.
At this time, in this world of ours, it's more critical than ever to support promising young women like Mariah. Reach out and push her up. It may seem like a small gesture, but it can have a magnificent impact on her life and in effect, all of our lives. After all, today's young women are tomorrow's mothers.  The mothers of our future.
Peace to you all.

story: I am no longer running this campaign. But enjoy the clip on Gemma!
